TALK.START.PARA: —A petition has been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Forests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

PETITION.PARA: Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:

PETITION.PARA: Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

PARA.TAB: Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Employment, Education and Training References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present part 1 of the report of the Employment, Education and Training References Committee on its inquiry into the development of open learning in Australia, together with the transcript of evidence and submissions received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to table the report of the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee on the development of open learning in Australia. When the inquiry was first referred to the committee, the Commonwealth government's open learning initiative was a prominent feature of debate in higher education circles. The OLI had been announced in the 1992-93 budget and the pilot project, TV open learning, was still running its course. But the committee was aware that much was happening in open learning not only in the university sector but in TAFE and schools as well. The committee was faced with a substantial task. In order to address the issues raised, the committee is in fact presenting to the Senate two reports, of which this is the first.

PARA.TAB: This first report looks at the role played by the Open Learning Agency of Australia, the Open Learning Technology Corporation and the more recently established Open Learning Electronic Support Service which is operated by the other two agencies. The committee believes that this first report will provide valuable feedback to these agencies and will contribute significantly to both the formal and the informal evaluation processes to which they are subject.

In part two the committee will address the many other issues that have been raised in the course of this inquiry, including the role of distance education centres in providing open learning; the issue of credit transfer; the relationship of open learning to flexible delivery, especially in the TAFE sector; the professional development of teachers; the potential for open learning in workplace training; and the potential advantages offered by the information superhighway. Open learning has been actively promoted in recent years as a way of enhancing the access to education, especially to higher education. In part one of our report we have concentrated our attention on the open learning initiatives at the tertiary level and in particular the Open Learning Agency of Australia.

The OLAA is a private company owned by Monash University in a consortium with a number of other institutions. It was set up as a vehicle to improve access to higher education for people unable to gain entry through the conventional means of tertiary entrance score or various mature age programs. It was hoped when it was initially established that the OLAA could achieve this at minimal cost.

Students in these programs pay $300 per unit to study through one of the participating universities. The committee believes that the Open Learning Agency of Australia should be a fully integrated component of the higher education sector. It should operate to serve the university sector as a whole. A sense of ownership is crucial to the ongoing commitment to the OLAA by our higher education institutions. So we have recommended in this report a restructuring of the agency.

We recommend that the government enter negotiations with Monash and the AV-CC with a view to placing the Open Learning Agency of Australia under the auspices of the AV-CC. In that way, it should have an assured broad base of support across the whole university sector. It is also extremely important in terms of facilitating credit transfer between universities.

The committee is also concerned that the funding attached to students entering higher education through the OLAA is insufficient for the universities providing the open learning courses to sustain their efforts without a severe compromise to the quality of education received by OLAA students. Either the university which is participating has to put in additional funding and resources or the lecturers provide many of these services out of the goodness of their heart. It is not really a satisfactory way to sustain an operation and it certainly is not a satisfactory way for expanding an operation in a university sector that is already strapped for resources.

Of the $310 that is provided through this OLAA mechanism, students are paying for a 13-week course but only $185 of that amount goes to the university providing the course. We have in evidence received responses from universities that indicate that only about $100 of it actually finds its way back to the teaching faculty.

The evidence that we have received has made it abundantly clear that this is nowhere near enough to meet the costs of providing a quality course, let alone the student back-up and library support that normally goes along with study at a tertiary level. Universities are cross-subsidising the OLAA because they believe that it is important for them to be involved in open learning programs. But for the $185 per unit they simply cannot keep up the standard of provision necessary, particularly for the large number of students who are involved.

If this system continues, it would have major implications for the degree status of those who graduate through open learning programs. We have, therefore, recommended that the government provide funds equivalent to 50 per cent of the EFTSU for students entering the system through the Open Learning Agency of Australia. This will enable them to provide universities to teach these students properly and to maintain the standards of courses.

The international perspective is also an important one to keep in mind. The OLAA has the potential to serve Australia's interests in the global education market—all the more reason for integrating the OLAA properly into our national university system and ensuring the quality of its services are backed by adequate funding. The broadcasting of educational television programs into South-East Asia is bound to create even greater demand for our courses, and we must be in a position to meet that demand with a quality product.

Given that the OLAA is concerned with access to higher education by people who would otherwise face significant impediments to further study, we also want to see equitable arrangements in place for the payment of fees. We have recommended that the rules governing the open learning deferred payment scheme be modified to bring them into line with HECS. At present, open learning students have to study more than a 75 per cent load over more than one study period in order to have access to deferred payment provisions. This works against many of the more disadvantaged students. Students with a disability are required to take on a 75 per cent or more load, and that is particularly unfair.

The committee is supportive of the work being done by the Open Learning Technology Corporation but is concerned that its commercial orientation might put at risk the important aspect of public benefit. This is most important at a time when the advent of the information superhighway places enormous challenges before the community and educational users.

We are also very conscious of the people side of the educational technology debate. Courseware must be designed with a strong focus on learning styles of students and the role of teachers as managers of learning. There must be professional training available to both course developers and teachers if the methods of open learning are to be fully effective.

As far as course development is concerned, it is most important that Australia continue to produce high quality courseware. The competition from overseas sources will be intense, and it is essential that our courses be relevant to their students and appropriate to Australian conditions and culture.

The Open Learning Electronic Support Service—OLESS—was launched on 14 September 1994 as a $1.4 million pilot. For a fee of around $70 per open learning study unit, OLESS will provide access for students to electronic mail, bulletin board services, file transfer facilities, course information and access to some library catalogues and administrative services. The government has declared that it is prepared to commit up to $10 million towards full implementation of the service, and the committee will be monitoring that project very carefully.

We would like to see such a service available to all open learning students across all education sectors. There are already many communication networks in place, and these could be linked to provide a comprehensive national education communication service. When I was in the United States about three months ago, I saw much evidence of these sorts of networks developing, particularly in states such as North Carolina, which are linking every public and educational institution by the year 2000. We need that similar visionary scheme in Australia, and OLESS, which is providing the technology and software base for open learning students, could do this and provide our students with information that will give them access to a worldwide system.

During the course of this inquiry, the committee visited a number of states and territories and witnessed the innovative applications of interactive technologies and open learning methods to a whole range of education and training needs. We spoke to course developers, teachers, trainees, administrators and policy advisers who are contributing to the development of open learning in all educational sectors. The committee was impressed with the developments and will be commenting in greater detail on these in part two of the report. I would like to commend the work of my colleagues in this committee. It is a unanimous report, and I commend the committee's report—Inquiry into the Development of Open Learning in Australia: Part 1—to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (INFRASTRUCTURE BORROWINGS) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Mr President, this bill will amend the law relating to Infrastructure Borrowings, giving effect to new taxation and administrative arrangements for Infrastructure Borrowings as foreshadowed in the "Working Nation" Statement on 4 May 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill will amend both the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Development Allowance Authority Act 1992. "Working Nation" announced that the date of effect would be from 1 July 1994. This has changed to the date the bill receives Royal Assent.

The introduction of Infrastructure Borrowings was first announced in the "One Nation" Statement on 26 February 1992. The measure was intended to encourage the private sector to make a real commitment to the provision of publicly accessible infrastructure, on a commercial basis.

Those infrastructure projects with lengthy construction periods may not produce assessable income for some years and may accumulate tax losses in the early stages of development. Therefore, where taxpayers borrow funds to finance the construction of those projects, they are often unable to access the interest deductions available to them.

By making interest on Infrastructure Borrowings non-assessable to the lender and non-deductible to the borrower, the tax benefit of the interest deduction is transferred to the lender in the form of non-assessable interest income. This enables companies to raise funds at a lower interest rate, thus reducing the borrowings costs.

The bill will extend the range of sectors within which projects may be eligible for Infrastructure Borrowing financing and will modify the administrative and taxation treatment of Infrastructure Borrowings. These amendments are intended to make Infrastructure Borrowings more attractive to investors and to facilitate even greater private sector provision of publicly accessible infrastructure.
I turn now to a more detailed discussion of these amendments.

Under the original arrangements, eligibility for Infrastructure Borrowings is restricted to the construction of new land transport facilities, seaport facilities and electricity generation facilities.

The bill proposes to broaden eligibility for Infrastructure Borrowings to include aviation facilities, electricity transmission and distribution and gas pipeline facilities, water and sewage treatment projects and other water infrastructure, including bores and associated pumping equipment.
This will provide a greater opportunity for private sector investment in these areas.

Broader eligibility for Infrastructure Borrowings is in line with the important role enhanced efficiency in these sectors has in the Government's micro-economic reform program and the assessment that such infrastructure projects can make an important contribution to economic development and international competitiveness.

The existing law covering Infrastructure Borrowings is contained in Division 16L of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and is administered by the Australian Taxation Office on behalf of the Commissioner of Taxation.
The Infrastructure Borrowings measure is not operated currently as a program with a formal approvals process.

The bill will introduce new administrative arrangements for Infrastructure Borrowings. The Development Allowance Authority will be responsible for the approvals, management and monitoring functions relating to Infrastructure Borrowings.

Under the new administrative arrangements, prospective borrowers will need to apply to the Development Allowance Authority for eligibility to issue Infrastructure Borrowings. When the Development Allowance Authority is satisfied that the applicant has met all eligibility criteria, it will issue a certificate in relation to the borrowing.

The Development Allowance Authority may cancel a certificate if the conditions attached to it are breached. Where a certificate is cancelled it is proposed the certificate holder will be liable for the payment of a charge. This is designed to provide a deterrent to the borrower breaching the conditions while not penalising the lenders. The Infrastructure Certificate Cancellation Tax Bill 1994, which we are debating cognately, forms part of this proposal.

As with its current functions, the Development Allowance Authority will continue to work closely with the Australian Taxation Office. The Australian Taxation Office will retain responsibility for ensuring compliance with the tax laws.

The Development Allowance Authority having responsibility for Infrastructure Borrowings will provide a single point of contact and a greater flow of information between the public and private sectors. This will enable the Infrastructure Borrowings initiative to be promoted more effectively in the business community and among the general public.

As the Infrastructure Borrowings measure will operate on an on-going basis, and the Development Allowance Authority will now have the role of administering the concession, section 98 of the DAA Act, which provided that there would be no substantive appointment of the DAA on or beyond 1 January 1997, will be repealed. This, in effect, results in the Development Allowance Authority being an on-going position.
Design of the Concession
Under the existing treatment of Infrastructure Borrowings, interest on the borrowings is non-assessable to the lender and non-deductible to the borrower.

The aim of this is to lower the cost of finance for certain infrastructure projects. Therefore, Infrastructure Borrowings can be issued at a lower, after-tax rate. This will be attractive, in straight price terms, to taxpayers with marginal tax rates higher than the company tax rate.
However, tax exempt interest may not be as attractive to all lenders, for example investors with tax rates below the company tax rate such as superannuation funds.
Providing a tax rebate instead of non-assessable interest income will help increase the attractiveness of Infrastructure Borrowings to low tax rate investors.

The bill proposes to change the design of the tax concession to provide for the option of a tax rebate of 33 per cent as an alternative to the current non-assessable income arrangement. The interest payments from Infrastructure Borrowings will continue to be non-deductible to the borrower.
Investors will be able to elect whether to treat interest as exempt or to include it in assessable income and receive a tax rebate of 33 per cent of the amount.

The non-assessable treatment of interest will remain attractive to investors with tax rates above the company tax rate, while the option of a rebate will make Infrastructure Borrowings attractive for taxpayers with marginal tax rates below 33 per cent.
This modification is designed to increase the pool of funds available to private sector infrastructure providers wishing to access Infrastructure Borrowings.

Under the existing legislation, companies wishing to issue Infrastructure Borrowings must intend to own, operate and control the infrastructure project for at least 25 years from the time the facility becomes income producing.

This requirement is intended to restrict the transfer of infrastructure projects from the private to the public sector. However, it also prevents the transfer of ownership to other private sector investors.
The bill proposes a relaxation of this requirement.

The sale of infrastructure assets will be permitted within the 25 year period where the prospective buyer is sufficiently commercial to meet the other borrower requirements for Infrastructure Borrowings. Only a body which is approved by the Development Allowance Authority will qualify as a suitable purchaser of an infrastructure facility.

This amendment will make the requirements more consistent with business practices, while ensuring that the infrastructure facility continues to be operated by the private sector, on a fully commercial basis for 25 years.
Under the current arrangements, Infrastructure Borrowings receive concessional treatment for a maximum period of ten years.
The bill will extend the existing maximum term of ten years for the tax concession to fifteen years. However, the term of the borrowings is not restricted to fifteen years.
This will facilitate investment by the private sector in infrastructure projects with very long construction periods, that are expected to be in tax loss for more than ten years.

The legislation contains an amendment to the operation of Infrastructure Borrowings additional to those announced in Working Nation. This amendment is required to remove references to outdated Loan Council procedures in the existing legislation which refer to "global borrowing limits". The amendment replaces the eligibility requirement relating to the Loan Council with new guidelines designed specifically for Infrastructure Borrowings. The new guidelines are designed to determine the commerciality of government owned bodies and will be published in the Commonwealth Gazette.

The Government believes that the changes proposed in the bill will increase the level of private sector investment in infrastructure. A responsible acceleration of infrastructure investment can facilitate increased competition and maximise Australia's potential for sustainable growth.
The estimated cost to revenue is expected to be nil for 1994-95, $9 million for 1995-96, $18 million for 1996-97 and $34 million for 1997-98.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
INFRASTRUCTURE CERTIFICATE CANCELLATION TAX BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Mr President, this bill will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to impose a tax on the certificate holder as a consequence of a breach of the conditions relating to a certificate issued allowing the holder to raise funds through Infrastructure Borrowings.

SPEECH.PARA: New administrative arrangements for Infrastructure Borrowings were announced in the Working Nation Statement on 4 May 1994.

Under these arrangements, prospective borrowers will need to apply to the Development Allowance Authority for eligibility to issue Infrastructure Borrowings. When the Development Allowance Authority is satisfied that the applicant has met all eligibility criteria, it will issue a certificate in relation to the borrowing.

The Development Allowance Authority may cancel a certificate if the conditions attached to it are breached. As a consequence of the breach, the certificate holder will be liable for the payment of a charge. This is designed to provide a deterrent to the borrower breaching the conditions while not penalising the lenders.
This bill gives effect to that charge.
The imposition of a tax as a consequence of the conditions relating to infrastructure borrowings will apply from the date the bill receives Royal Assent.
The imposition of this charge will reduce the potential for future losses to the revenue.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the bill.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

The objective with these proposed amendments is to clarify that voluntary work is given the same precedence as self-employment, group or cooperative work. Voluntary work can give extremely valuable skills and experience to unemployed people, especially as a precursor to paid employment.

PARA.TAB: We believe the government should have more flexibility with advocating voluntary work. As can be seen from the wording of the clause, we have allowed for the fact that if people are offered paid employment, this would usurp the voluntary work option in the case management activity agreements. We have already had this discussion in various ways during the debate on the bill so far. I urge the committee to support these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Australian Democrats support these proposed amendments as an attempt to introduce greater flexibility and the opportunity for voluntary work to be recognised in the way that it should be. The debate was conducted last night over about six chapters, so there is no need to repeat it. I concur with Senator Margetts's reasons for this being an important amendment.

—As Senator Bell has remarked, we canvassed the arguments for and against some of these clauses extensively last night. I indicate that the coalition will not be supporting proposed amendments Nos 16, 17 and 18.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

PARA.TAB: As the Greens frequently articulate, we are very supportive of self-employment as an option for unemployed people. If we are to be realistic about what jobs are available for this whole labour market program and how many people will get into formal jobs, we should recognise that self-employment is a viable option to working for an organisation and can provide useful activities and life skills to unemployed people.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

SPEECH.PARA: 20Clause 44, page 27, after subclause (2), insert the following subclause:
"(2A) A person is not to be taken:

TAB.TAB: (a)to have failed to agree to terms of the agreement proposed by the case manager within the meaning of subparagraph (2)(a)(iii); or

Amendment 20 is the same as the amendment the Greens moved in relation to the youth training allowance. As we all know, the employment services legislation overrides anything in the youth training allowance, so it is imperative that we consider carefully this amendment and that it is supported.

PARA.TAB: This amendment, we feel, rights the balance a little more fairly so that unemployed people get some negotiating rights and are not seen to be delaying the agreement or failing to agree to it if they are willing to keep negotiating until a mutual decision can be made. As it stands, clause 44(2)(b)(iii) is written in such a way that people will be cut off from their allowance for failing to agree to the case manager's agreement. This is a ludicrous situation where people have to be passive and disempowered by having to accept something that they may not want to agree to. But they have little choice or else they will be cut off from their allowance. The Greens believe that opening this up into a more two-way negotiation rather than having it one way will have better outcomes and less draconian laws.

I would like honourable senators to picture what it would be like for a person who is in this less powerful situation and who is given an agreement to sign—an agreement which, because of the lack of desire of the government and the opposition, does not specifically allow for negotiation because negotiation, we were told last night, was a dirty word that did not need to be and should not be included because it gave too much flexibility.

Therefore, considering that negotiation is not a right under this particular process, consider what choice people have when an agreement has been written up by perhaps private case managers who would like to get these people either off their books or into something to which they may or may not be suited so that they get the money back. What choice do these people have? They can say no and be cut off from their allowance, or they can say yes. Is that the choice that we are leading to? Is this what the government, the Australian Democrats, the opposition and the Greens sat down to talk about? Is this actually what we agreed to? Or has one department, as we predicted, overruled another already? Has the consequence of trying to deal with a Social Security issue and allowing DEET to overrule it already claimed its first victims—the unemployed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Margetts indicated, this amendment goes to the heart of what this business is all about. This amendment has been the subject of considerable discussion with the government and with representatives of the departments. We believe that it brings to the entire bill a flavour of identifying what the bill is about and what the process is about. The subheading on page 27 of the bill reads, `Failure to negotiate a case management activity agreement'. This section will apply if:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)a person has been given notice . . . of a requirement to enter into a Case Management Activity Agreement; and
(b)the Employment Secretary is satisfied that the person is unreasonably delaying entering into the agreement.
The reasons for delay would be:
(2) The Employment Secretary may be so satisfied:
(a) because of the person's failure to:

PARA.TAB: (i)attend the negotiation of the agreement; or
(ii)respond to correspondence about the agreement; or
(iii)agree . . .

SPEECH.PARA: As far as any common understanding of the English language is concerned, `negotiate' means that one would attend and there would be the potential to disagree. Negotiation is hardly undertaken in any aspect of life where initially the negotiating parties agree. If they agree when they first meet, of course, there is no negotiation; it becomes an agreement. But to negotiate an agreement means to seek to resolve the disagreements and to arrive at a satisfactory position after some discussion and some amendment of the original positions.

PARA.TAB: That is all that this amendment is trying to achieve—a process by which the negotiation can take place and original propositions can be modified and finally concluded. The position has been put to us that to alter it in such a way as this amendment does would allow matters to go on ad nauseam. That is not the case. This is an attempt to redress the imbalance which is placed in the process by deeming that people have failed to hold up their side if they fail to agree. That proposition is manifestly unfair, it is obvious that it is unfair and it should be modified in the way that is proposed here. We strongly support the amendment and we will support it defiantly if there is any suggestion that it will not succeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not be supporting this amendment. I would not go as far as Senator Bell did when he said the position had been put that negotiation could continue ad nauseam if this amendment were passed. The view of the coalition is that to put down guidelines for negotiation other than that which is already put forward in the legislation could lead to a fair degree of what I would call non-productive activity. Therefore, we will not support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not accept this amendment. I think it is important—particularly in the light of Senator Bell's suggestion that there might be a division about this; it is a matter of some importance—that we put on the record a few other aspects of this debate which Senator Margetts elegantly left out. I refer, for example, to her suggestion that if there is not an agreement, down comes the axe and, thwacko, you are gone—no compact, no allowance. That is not exact at all. I say to Senator Bell that in terms of negotiating, he actually read out that the legislation requires people to attend a negotiation. I notice we do not say they should `attend and enter into', which is what the debate on the same issue was about when I was here last night.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, the legislation allows for a very large amount of flexibility and understanding. Section 124(2)(a) of the act provides that payment of allowance must continue pending review of the failure to agree to terms. That is an important point that Senator Margetts failed to contribute in arguing for her amendment. To further quote from the guidelines:

SPEECH.PARA: If a client is making a genuine attempt to negotiate but is clearly unhappy with a particular term, reasonable efforts should be made to reach consensus with the client either by modifying the term or, in some cases, replacing it with a term proposed by the client which achieves the same purpose.

They are fairly clear guidelines which suggest that there is not an arbitrary decision made unilaterally and which contain language which is aimed very much at trying to agree on what is best for the client who is entering into this compact. But at a certain stage we have to say, `We are serious about this and we do not want'—in Senator Troeth's words—`non-productive activities continuing for too long'—mainly because the principal concern of government is that those long time unemployed are assisted into employment.

PARA.TAB: The balance struck in this legislation more than justifies the government not accepting this amendment from Senator Margetts. A lot of this discussion was being run through in this place last night and, as Senator Margetts said on a previous occasion when discussing a previous bill, I do not think it is helpful to put the amendment without putting all the relevant parts of the legislation that already cover many of the points she raised by way of arguing for the amendment. We oppose it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I in no way pretend to know exactly every section and subsection of this act and I would be pleased for the minister's guidance. She mentioned 124(2)(a).
—Of the Social Security Act.

—Well, there you go: the Social Security Act. Our original contention was that a lot of this stuff was recreating bits that were already in the hands of another department and Senator Margetts pointed to the fact that there seems to be a bit of an interdepartmental feud here. So it is very difficult to know who is running the show. When the three of us who are conducting this debate from the coalition, the Democrats and the Greens received advice from departmental officials, we were led to believe that the Employment Services Bill was intended to override the youth training allowance bill.

PARA.TAB: This amendment refers to part of the bill which needs to be clarified. For the minister to quote to me a section of the Social Security Act which virtually drives this and to say what ought to happen, without this bill itself explaining it, is symptomatic of our problem, because this bill says—and it is unequivocal in this fashion; it does not say anything else—that this clause will apply if the person fails to agree to the terms of the agreement proposed by the case manager. It does not say `fails to arrive at a negotiated position'; it says `fails to agree with what is proposed by the case manager.' That is so one-sided that anything contained in the Social Security Act, as far as I am concerned, can neither modify nor illuminate it sufficiently for it to be described as a fair negotiation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add to the comments of Senator Bell. I know of circumstances—and anyone who does not believe me perhaps ought to ask an unemployed person, because I am wondering whether the department has done so—in which people in situations of relative powerlessness have been contacted and told that they are to attend a meeting at a certain time the next day or at a particular time which it is almost impossible for them to get to.

PARA.TAB: When we are talking about not attending meetings, we are not necessarily talking about people who think, `Oh, I am not going to go in today.' We are actually talking about someone without transport being required, on very little notice, to attend a meeting which it might be almost physically impossible to get to on two buses or a bus and two trains—or that person might miss a connection, miss a bus or something of that nature.

So we are not talking about people who can zap into their Maseratis and get anywhere they want at any time. We are talking about the possibility that a person's powerlessness and lack of resources may, in fact, be used against them. I warrant that, if it is possible and if there is a commercial benefit for doing such, it is not beyond the realms of possibility that such will happen.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

These amendments are a result of my dismay at the harsh penalties in this legislation. Bearing in mind that this legislation will govern people from the age of 15, the current penalties are a maximum of six months imprisonment for those not providing information and 12 months imprisonment for those giving false evidence or false documents. This applies to both unemployed clients and case management service providers.

PARA.TAB: We have removed the criminal penalties and replaced them with suspension. Therefore, a case manager would have to cease work and recipients would cease receiving their allowance. There is an option for each party to be reviewed—the case manager through ESRA, and the recipient through the Social Security Appeals Tribunal—by the normal review process. As has been mentioned by Senator Chamarette on numerous occasions, there is a criminal code for people who criminally defraud the system. It can cover those cases of criminal fraud. It is not necessary for it to be in this type of legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes amendments Nos 21, 22 and 23. The effect of these proposed amendments would be to downgrade to an enormous degree ESRA's powers to gather information and to conduct investigations. For example, in a worst case scenario, people or entities with contracted case managers can avoid an investigation even for matters relating to fraud against the Commonwealth and/or provide information which they know to be false for a relatively minor penalty.

PARA.TAB: The gaol terms which are the penalties set out in the bill are a far more reasonable deterrent. It should be noted that the clauses as drafted in the bill provide full protection for people who provide information which, although it may subsequently prove to be inaccurate, was provided in good faith in the belief that it was accurate. The provision is a standard penalty provision which accompanies the information gathering powers of a statutory authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will also be opposing amendments Nos 21, 22 and 23. Similar to the remarks made by Senator Sherry, we believe that the penalty should apply to a person or entity who contravenes subsection 1. For that reason, we will be opposing the amendments.

—Could the minister elaborate on the statement that these penalties are commensurate with the other penalties for the information gathering capacity of a statutory authority? I think they were the words he used. Could he demonstrate that similarity by referring to another situation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

These amendments are similar to my amendments 5 and 6, which I previously moved. The intent is to apply the same principle to group enterprises and cooperative enterprises as are applied to self-employment. Again, it is a question of what is the best economic test of viability that should be applied where there is community or public interest benefit involved. It seems to me to be self-evident that we should have a more flexible test to expand the breadth of the jobs compact.

PARA.TAB: Again, I do not see any need to keep adding words. They are obviously having little effect. The words have already been put forward with regard to amendments 5 and 6. Amendment 8 is a consequential amendment to No. 7. Amendment 11 is again partly consequential. The amendments seek to ensure that we do not preclude continued participation in a community based cooperative if that participation continues to be a public benefit, notwithstanding that a job seeker has been involved with the activity previously. In other words, we do not want to have a rigorous cutting off of the benefits that the job seeker derives from being involved in a community enterprise. It seems to me that this makes—and I am sick of using the word—commonsense. This is how life works. People are involved in things and people are contributors. There really should not be bureaucratic axes coming down to separate them from real life. Just because it looks good on paper does not mean that that is how things work.

I am sure the parliamentary secretary would be aware of the cooperative which has delivered a number of jobs in the Glenorchy municipality. Glenorchy Resources reclaims discarded materials and employs around about 20 people at the moment. Some of those jobs are very flexible in terms of teaching driving delivery skills and the sort of work one would obtain as a courier—delivering parcels and messages. If some of these young people were to move away from that employment, but voluntarily contributed to that community enterprise, then the bill as proposed would preclude them from being involved if they wanted to enter into a jobs compact program subsequent to their leaving the other community enterprise. They would be precluded from being involved in any way. These amendments deliver the sort of flexibility which is necessary to live life in a real sense, rather than in a bureaucratic sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard a number of debates in very recent times about the fact that Australia has a very high real interest rate. That would indicate that we have or shall have a capital shortage of some sort and that people will be looking carefully as to the source of investment funds. It seems that the creative solution a number of people are coming to in a number of places is joint capitalisation—that means, a number of people who are unemployed or whose job looks to be not as secure as it was and so on are planning for their future by pooling their skills and their resources. This seems to be a very sensible solution. It also seems to be a way of meeting local—
—It is called a partnership, if you have ever been in business.

—Senator Panizza said that it is called a partnership. I am not talking about a partnership. I am talking about something that is not very well recognised in Australian law or even in the state laws of this country. Cooperative ownership, which is quite different from partnerships, is something that I am working on. I know that other people are very interested in it.

PARA.TAB: This very sensible option has a lot of trouble operating under the current laws—under the new enterprise scheme and so on—because it is not recognised. It is not recognised because somehow or other it does not exist legally. Therefore, people have to work under all sorts of other laws that do not exist for cooperative ownership. Cooperative ownership is very sensible. It allows shared risk. It allows people to work together and to build up their skills. It exists and is operating in a number of places throughout Australia. A cooperative association in Queensland is doing some amazing things. Areas such as Maleny are quite advanced in this respect.

If, as a federal parliament, we physically work against the exciting and useful things that can be done by cooperative ownership, cooperative enterprises and community based enterprises, we are showing that we do not understand the real world and do not understand that the last thing we should want to do is become totally dependent, in a situation of possible capital shortage, on overseas investments so that communities will be dancing to the tune of overseas investors rather than being able to find their own solutions to their own problems.

What we are talking about relates very closely to rural and regional viability. If the opposition cannot see that, I am not sure where it is at. We are talking about the recognition of cooperatives and the possibility of cooperative ownership being a way for the community to seek its own solutions. I fully support Senator Bell's amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will be opposing these amendments for the same reasons that I mentioned last night. I would not like Senator Margetts to think that the opposition does not recognise the very valuable contribution of, and the sense of personal fulfilment that many people gain from, the creative activities that she mentioned. But I also feel that the remarks I made last night, about the possibility of government subsidising people's hobbies, still apply to these amendments. For that reason we will be opposing them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes proposed amendments Nos 7, 8 and 11. We oppose amendment No. 7 because it seeks to draw community based and artistic work into the same ambit as the new group or cooperative enterprise clauses. For the same reasons advanced in opposing amendment No. 5, the government considers that this is inappropriate and confusing, given that the former type of activity is unpaid and aims to help job seekers find possible avenues to paid employment, whereas the latter two activities are aimed at giving job seekers the opportunity to achieve income self-sufficiency. Amendment No. 8 is opposed because it is technically related to No. 7.

PARA.TAB: We oppose amendment No. 11 because it is unnecessary. As has previously been explained, voluntary work is clearly designated in the legislation as a separate category of activity from group or cooperative enterprises. A person would, therefore, not normally be precluded from undertaking a group or cooperative enterprise activity where they had previously engaged in voluntary work.

Senator Margetts's comments about investment issues, cooperatives in general and the management of enterprises contained some valid points, but not in the context of this legislation. This bill is not the place to be defining the role of cooperatives, in an economic and legislative sense, in our society. We will debate that issue next year, but not now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am astounded by the parliamentary secretary's last statement. Since it is what this amendment is concerned with, why not debate the role of cooperatives in society right here and now? As Senator Margetts mentioned, cooperatives are being forced, in a pioneering sense, into delivering the goods; they are employing people and creating employment. What is wrong with recognising that in this legislation? The real world is not compartmentalised; the real world is integrated. This legislation will affect what goes on elsewhere.

PARA.TAB: While Senator Margetts was talking, I was reminded of something that should impress Senator Panizza. I cannot remember which particular Wimmera town it was—either Kaniva or Jeparit, or one of those small flour milling towns somewhere between Stawell and Horsham—but in one of those towns, over the past couple of years, the community has gathered together and decided to revitalise one of the old flour mills.

For many decades flour mills were the heart of Victorian industry but became redundant after multinationals or large companies took over the industry. The group of people had little capital and were unable to pay each other in real cash while they were beginning. But they invested their debt in a cooperative sense and were able to establish a very viable industry after a year when they had milled enough wheat, had established a market and were starting to return a profit. It was then that the cooperative members were able to be paid in cash rather than kind.

This enterprise was successful only because they did not follow the conventional model of borrowing money, being obliged to a bank and paying award wages from an administrative staff to a labouring staff; rather, they entered into it in a cooperative manner and invested their debt with each other. I know that that is what Senator Margetts was talking about and I know that there are many other examples around Australia. Why not talk about this here and now? It is about employment. Our amendment seeks to make such things more possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have another question in relation to that: has the parliamentary secretary heard of the local enterprise trading system or, as some people call it, the local energy transfer scheme?
—Yes, I have.

—Does the parliamentary secretary know how these particular groups of people who are pulling themselves and their communities up by their bootstraps may or may not be affected by this particular piece of legislation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —We understand the legislation allows broadly for cooperative enterprises to operate. One of the reasons for not defining in this legislation is that they can continue to do so.
—I remind the committee that work is for people, not people for work and certainly not people for square holes, putting round pegs into square holes. One just cannot operate in that fashion.

PARA.TAB: As we all know, there is a great attempt by the government at the present moment to so restructure the legislation and to so restructure the statistics as to get out from the unemployment statistics as many people as it can. That is not really what the exercise should be all about. It ought to be about fulfilling the expectations of people. It ought to be about empowering people to undertake the activities that they wish to undertake and which have some community benefit.

I recall a previous Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, saying, I think on advice from his Treasurer, that we should as a modern society acknowledge that there will never be a situation where all people who desire to be in employment will be able to be in traditional employment. We should be looking at socially constructive alternatives.

I am talking not about the make-work programs that were part of the RED scheme and so on but, in relation to this particular piece of legislation, about people possibly being forced by their case managers out of work they are doing which is a socially constructive alternative. I think the purpose of Senator Bell's motion is to acknowledge that.

The current Treasurer (Mr Willis) is on record as saying that one of the major problems with unemployment at present is the labour force participation rate. Obviously, if we had the participation rate now that we had 20 years ago there would hardly be an unemployment problem. Unemployment would be down to perhaps two per cent or three per cent.

Somebody made a suggestion that there should be a freedom of choice. One of the problems with this government is that it is not giving a freedom of choice for persons to engage in socially constructive alternative work, whether it is paid work in the traditional sense or whether it is unpaid work that is a constructive alternative with social benefits to the whole of the community.

I have previously indicated in this place that that is the approach that should be taken in respect of parenting. Why should a family be forced to have both spouses in the paid work force if one of them makes the decision that they want to be engaged in the full-time care of young children? Why should that be the case? The mindset of the government is against that. One of the major problems that that is causing is the high unemployment rate.

At the other end of the scale, the long-term unemployed, the case managers are given quite strong powers under this employment services legislation. Senator Bell is trying to get the government to acknowledge that there are socially constructive alternatives, that jobs are being done in the community which are not, in the traditional sense, employment but are nonetheless work, and are nonetheless satisfying work, for those who are undertaking it. I can think of a number of examples. The department would have a number of examples as well—at least I hope it does.

Initiatives and ideas are growing in this area. They will overtake all of our thinking in the years to come. We should not be in a straitjacket, and we should not put the case managers in a straitjacket. We certainly should not put those who are the victims of unemployment in a straitjacket, as would be the case if the types of amendments that are being proposed by Senator Bell and Senator Margetts were defeated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only concur with Senator Harradine. I ask the parliamentary secretary or the minister—they are both at the table—at least to consider that a cursory examination of this might lead to the dismissive remark that was made earlier, that such amendments could possibly allow people to continue in their hobby and be paid by the government. I think that slightly more examination—another five seconds worth—of what is being proposed would dismiss that proposition. What we are trying to do here is to add to those conditions that the Employment Secretary can be satisfied about which, as paragraph (b)(ii)(A) of amendment No. 7 says, `will result in some benefit to the community'. That is not a very complicated sentence. It either will or it will not.

PARA.TAB: If it is a personal pursuit of one's philatelic or numismatic hobby, it may not result in a benefit to the community and it would not satisfy that clause. If, however, people were involved in learning some of the rudiments of communicating politely with people and participating in the Meals on Wheels program and they were deriving some benefit from it, that should not preclude them from being a participant in this area. That is all we are saying. It should be a very easy measure to decide whether or not it will result in some benefit to the community.

I appeal to the minister to at least acknowledge that and recognise that we are not trying to propose that people can sit at home, twiddle their thumbs and pretend that that is a worthwhile activity. We are trying to recognise those things which the community values.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the remarks made by Senator Bell, I would like to put the coalition's views on the record. I think he described the remarks that I made earlier about government subsidisation of hobbies as dismissive. All we are saying is that if we try to measure something that is of some benefit to the community, with due respect, I must point out to Senator Bell that this is a very nebulous concept. Who is to measure what is of some benefit to the community? How do we measure what `some' actually means? That is the question that the coalition is raising and that is why we are unable to support the amendment.

—The skills of case managers, I was led to understand, would be such that they would be able to judge a whole lot of things, such as the relative benefits of a certain course in putting people into certain kinds of employment, whether a person is ready for employment, if not, why they are not ready, and so on. It seems that a lot of skills are assumed but are not written into the legislation. If we are expecting those kinds of skills from case managers, I think we can probably assume that they can work out whether or not an activity is likely to be of public benefit.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 9Clause 41, page 24, paragraph (2)(b), line 25, omit "paid employment" (twice occurring), substitute "self-employment or paid employment".

This is only a small amendment but it is potentially important. The minister, as was the case previously, may be able to assist me. It seems to me that paid employment does not appear to be defined anywhere in the legislation. It may include self-employment; it may not. I believe that in many cases involvement in a cooperative or a network is likely to result in a person acquiring sufficient skills to branch out on their own in self-employment at a later date. Participation in such organisations should not be precluded simply because it must lead to paid employment.

PARA.TAB: Last night I described the flavour of this bill as establishing some degree of difference between paid employment and unpaid employment. I think that is a difference we can no longer afford following Senator Harradine's contribution. He suggested that in the future we may not be able to afford that distinction and we may need to redefine in legislation what is recognised as valuable employment. Again, amendment No. 9 allows us to remove the difference that the bill brings to these definitions so that we would find it easier to place a value on that employment which is not paid. I can think of a vast number of contributions to our community which are not paid, which the community values and which nobody in their right mind would deny as real, useful employment.

In New South Wales some volunteer fire brigade members are challenging the notion of voluntaryism and are actually putting in a claim for payment when they are fighting fires on state land. That debate is certainly worth having, but it is a debate in which we would have to bring into question the value that the community places on certain work and the assumptions the community makes about what volunteers will or will not do. As far as I am concerned, it is a debate in which I would expect a very strong case to be made that the community values highly employment which is not necessarily paid. In this amendment I seek to remove that distinction so that those who are not being paid can still be considered to be valuably employed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will be supporting amendment No. 9. We value highly the concept of self-employment and we would wish to see that included. Therefore, we will be supporting the Democrats.

—The Greens support Senator Bell's amendment. I would also like to add that I believe over time in our society with the changing nature of our industry and our economy to internationalisation there will be the necessity to redefine work—work out what is work and what is not work. We are just beginning to see in this debate the necessity to start doing so and I hope it is sooner rather than later that the government and the opposition bite the bullet to bring this debate on in a more constructive way.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be accepting this amendment. I do not want to trawl across the many points that have been raised by me and others for the government in the passage of this legislation. Of particular concern might be the case manager's assessment of any level of income of a person working in this sort of situation. That is just one of a number of points that I could go over. I think most of them have been canvassed, so I just point out that the government does not accept this amendment.

—Without wishing to prolong debate on this quite small amendment, I would like to mark the capacity that the coalition has displayed in paying careful attention to what is being done here and in recognising the value of this particular amendment. I suggest that the government should carefully consider each amendment. To dismiss all of our amendments as being useless is, I think, a judgment which they are not worthy of. I acknowledge and emphasise the coalition's attention to detail and recognition of the merit of this particular amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 12Clause 42, page 26, after paragraph (1)(g), insert the following word and paragraph:
"(ga) the work is unlikely to result in sustainable long term employment assuming reasonable diligence on the part of the employee; or".

We have discussed the effect of this particular amendment before—it seems several times now—but I wish to emphasise it. The remarks I made in conclusion of our discussions about the previous amendment apply very strongly here, and I hope the government can consider the individual merit of this amendment. The coalition has shown that it is capable of distinguishing between the individual amendments that we have proposed.

PARA.TAB: In this case, I would like to emphasise that this amendment seeks to ensure that an unemployed person should not be required to take a job placement if that work is unlikely to result in sustainable, long-term employment—assuming reasonable diligence on the part of the employee. As Senator Margetts pointed out before, the secretary or the case manager is being imbued with all sorts of skills and abilities in this legislation. To make our amendment work, it would require some sort of assessment by the secretary. If the unemployed person disagrees with the secretary's assessment, there will be an appeal right. This is just and fundamental.

Unemployed people should not be forced to take up positions which they know are not sustainable. I defy the government to prove otherwise, but there is implicit, as an intrinsic part of this legislation, pressure for case managers to conclude their management. Let us remember that they are not only case managing four or five people. It may be quite easy to meet the hype of this legislation and all the theories behind it if a case manager were only responsible for five or six people. In fact, they could get to the stage where it is more than 100, or perhaps even more than 200 people, that they are attempting to find placements for. So I defy the government to deny that there is some pressure on case managers to actually conclude and receive the cash payment on the outcome.

Therefore, there is this pressure. It is unemployed people themselves who will be the recipients of that pressure in the long term. They should not be forced to take up positions which they know are not sustainable. If the people or the department knows that they are only there until the jobstart subsidy gives out, what sort of a job future is that? It is no better than the vacuum that some people find themselves in now.

So this provision will place more emphasis on the quality of placements. I deliberately emphasise that word `quality', and I think it deserves to be looked at. A placement is not just a placement. If we are going to case manage people and go to the trouble of identifying individuals and what is necessary for them and make the effort to separate them and look at their individual requirements, the quality of the placement is the very thing that needs to be emphasised.

In speaking about this, I am reminded of a speech given by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in Parramatta on Friday, 2 December. I have a transcript of the PM program involving Monica Attard and reporter Kevin Wild, which quotes the Prime Minister and his intentions. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to take young people who are part of the 14 per cent, who run the risk of falling out of the system and believing that nobody wants them and society isn't interested in them. This is our way, the government's way of saying, we are interested, we will pick you up, we will individually enquire about you, we'll take a personal interest in you and we'll put you back in the system.

If the Prime Minister really means that, and if this legislation is going to be the vehicle for doing it, we need to be concerned about the quality of their placements and not just treat them as a number or as part of a block of people. We need to look at their individual placements and give them the capacity to say, `No, that is not for me. No, that is not a real job. No, that will not last for any length of time.' If we cannot do that, the Prime Minister was talking hot air.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens will be supporting Senator Bell's amendment for the reasons that he stated.
—The coalition will not be supporting this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not accept this amendment. I accept Senator Bell's sentiments; no-one opposes them at all. He asked whether people could prove it. I do not know what qualifies as proof. Certainly my own experience of working in community health a few years ago and certainly a lot of documented evidence shows to the government's satisfaction that, very often, short-term work leads to longer term work. It does a whole lot of things, including getting people into go-back-to-work mode and so on. To put a restriction of six months on what kind of work one might want to contract for people to enter into would, we believe, be unduly restrictive. The evidence shows that short-term or casual work provides valuable experience and people either continue in that job or it leads to them finding work in other areas.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 13Clause 42, page 26, subparagraph (2)(a)(ii), line 22, omit "90", substitute "45".
14Clause 42, page 26, at end of paragraph (2)(b), add "and the person is prepared to commute.".

These amendments deal with what is a reasonable commuting time. The current bill proposes a two-tier test. The first tier says that if the trip is less than 90 minutes one way—that is, three hours per day—it is reasonable and that the person must commute. The second test goes further and says that even if it is more than three hours total in a day, and if the employment secretary believes that a substantial number of people commute, it is reasonable to demand that they commute. I do not know how many people that is. We have talked this morning about what the word `some' means. In this case, we have the word `substantial'. I suggest that it is about as precise. It leaves it pretty much open-ended.

PARA.TAB: Our amendment says that an unemployed person, even one with children, will be required to spend up to three or even four hours per day commuting or face the penalty of a loss of benefits. It is true that the second section is appealable. The first is not; it is a set test involving up to three hours. You must do it; there are no ifs or buts. What adds to the difficulty is that the government is yet to finalise its arrangements for fares assistance. Three hours travelling on public transport does not come cheaply. We really do not know what the cost might be. I suggest that it would be substantial.

Our amendments deal with the problem in two steps. We seek to reduce the maximum time for reasonable commuting by half from 90 minutes one way, or three hours in total, to 45 minutes one way or an hour and a half, or 90 minutes total, for the day's commuting. This sets a minimum time below which the person cannot refuse a position on account of unreasonable commuting. That is not to say that everybody would refuse it on that basis. It is just a minimum time below which people could not.

Let us be clear what we are establishing here. We are saying `below which a person cannot refuse'—not that they must refuse anything that is above 45 minutes but that they fail the test if they refuse it below 45 minutes. I think that is fair. Forty-five minutes normal commuting would cover the vast majority of the usual commuting routes in Australia.

The only exceptions would probably be from the outer fringes of Sydney and Melbourne to the other side. I do not think we should be setting our standards by the yardstick of outer suburban Sydney. Whatever they do there, I do not think, can be described as normal. Perhaps everything they do is abnormal—I do not know. I think a reasonable minimum standard should be one which is reasonable for the vast majority of Australians, with appropriate exceptions built in for a minority. Ninety minutes is not acceptable for a majority.

The limited case of the Sydney or Melbourne outer suburbs could be dealt with by the second part, that is, where a substantial number of people are already commuting. That is a qualifier. Nobody could argue that a substantial number of people are commuting from Campbelltown to Sydney or from Dandenong to Melbourne; it is not a substantial number. Clearly, that would be a reasonable requirement for travel. But very few people travel or should be required to commute from Beenleigh to Strathpine in Brisbane or from Elizabeth to Noarlunga in Adelaide each day. That is not a normal and recognised sort of journey, and I do not think that anybody could describe it as something that a majority of people do.

The first test is a stand-alone test, and I would commend it to the committee. If the department wants a person to travel further than that, then the decision would be reviewable. It is only a test below which a person cannot refuse to participate.

I would also point out that the proposed section goes much further than the current tests on commuting in the Social Security Act for newstart and, I presume, jobstart. I know, for example, that even in the Open Learning Agency there is a definition of commuting which is more like 45 minutes or 60 minutes. It certainly is not 90 minutes. We have had an argument about consistency several times in this debate, and I know that this is not one of those consistent provisions.

There is a third test—and this is where we should pay a little more attention—that is, where the travelling costs exceed 10 per cent of the wage offered. Remembering that under the jobs compact we are talking about training wages for, say, 20-year-olds of $270 or $300 a week—even less for younger workers—three hours daily travel on public transport could quite quickly add up to $30 or $40 a week, which would exceed that 10 per cent. That is a better measure of the significance of the travel.

Under newstart, that would be regarded as unreasonable because it is on a wage of $300 or $400, but under the jobs compact it is not regarded as unreasonable by the government. So we need to look here at the consistency angle very carefully—not only the time but also the cost.

The second limb of the unreasonable travelling test is the `substantial number are already travelling' test. This limb applies only where the client has private means of transport or public transport readily available. That is also unreasonable. If they cannot get from A to B, then obviously the commuting is unreasonable.

I think these tests are pretty logical and I wish to foreshadow that, if my original amendment fails to get up, I will be moving a further amendment to reflect the current newstart provisions as a minimum. Although I have sought leave to move amendments 13 and 14 together, I would suggest that amendment 13 is extremely important.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to remind the government that under Australia's greenhouse commitments we are meant to think about how we can cut down such things as unnecessary use of transport and so on. If people are required to change two buses and a train or something of that nature to get to work and it takes up to 90 minutes each day in each direction, basically three hours is a lot of time out of their lives. One would assume that it is acceptable for people to have some personal life as well. There will be a lot of pressure on such people to gain access to some form of private transport in whatever way they can, if that were the requirement under this bill.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, more people would be forced to use private transport because, quite frankly, how many people have three hours of every day that they can devote just to getting to and from work? I, therefore, submit that this is not very consistent with the country's commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not support these amendments. We believe that the current provisions are adequate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not support these amendments. Again, the language that Senator Margetts just used suggests that 90 minutes is a requirement. It is not a prescriptive reference; it is an enabling reference. For example, it enables people—and I think Senator Bell alluded to this—from north of Sydney, where the community in large numbers regularly takes up to 90 minutes to commute to Sydney, to do this. We would not want to say to any other person in that community that he or she should not be able to behave like other members of the community in going to and from work.

PARA.TAB: It is important to know that it is not a requirement for case managers to find work that is 90 minutes away. But, if up to 90 minutes is consistent with the general behaviour of people in that community, it is entirely reasonable for the case manager to include that. I am interested to know whether Senator Bell's amendment No. 19, which he will move later, includes the 90 minutes time. This seems to be somewhat contradictory amongst his own amendments.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 15Clause 44, page 27, omit subparagraph (2)(a)(iii), lines 28 and 29, omit the subparagraph, substitute the following subparagraph:
"(iii) reach mutually agreeable and reasonable terms for the agreement with the case manager; or".

This amendment modifies the test slightly and requires some element of agreement to the secretary's proposal of what is reasonable. I move this amendment to emphasise that case management activity agreements should be that—agreements. If people are required to travel for excessive periods of time at substantial cost and inconvenience, in principle, the subject and the manager should agree on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens support this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes this amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 16Clause 44, page 27, subclause (2), line 24, omit "The Employment Secretary", substitute "Subject to subsection (2A), the Employment Secretary".
17Clause 44, page 27, after subclause (2) insert the following subclauses:
"(2A) Subparagraph (2)(iii) does not apply until either:

PARA.TAB: (a)the person, at the request of the Employment Secretary, and after reasonable notice, attends a meeting with the case manager and the Employment Secretary and they:

TAB.TAB: (i)review any proposed agreement; and
(ii)review the reasons for the failure to reach mutually agreeable and reasonable terms for such an agreement; and

PARA.TAB: (iii)fail to reach agreement on those or other mutually agreeable and reasonable terms; or
(b)the person fails to attend the meeting referred to in paragraph (a).".

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments go to the heart of the jobs compact. It is a key component of case management activity agreements. I suggest that it is not possible to define an action as an agreement if one side is dictating the terms and the other side is complying. I would have thought that the Labor Party, of all groups of people, would recognise that that is not an agreement but an imposition.

PARA.TAB: The idea of reintroducing long-term unemployed into the work force must be based on coopting, cooperation and encouragement. If this jobs compact is to work, it must involve the long-term unemployed in a positive way. It must engage them. It must reflect the sorts of words that I have already quoted from the Prime Minister. It must do that in the legislation. It must respond to individual needs and it must be based on tailoring agreements accordingly. Proposed section 44 starts with the wrong assumption. It starts with the wrong word. It starts with the wrong sympathy.

I have learned that we cannot look for poetry, emotion and humanity in legislation; but when we have the opposite, we should recognise it. `Failure to negotiate' was a key phrase in a film that I once saw; I wish Senator Loosley were here to tell me which one it was. The film, which depicted very inhuman management of a southern United States boot camp, illustrated what happens when there is failure to negotiate.

To have those words at the beginning of a set of criteria in a bill before the chamber is, to me, anathema. It starts from the wrong premise. The clause attempts to bring about an agreement. But it will not do so if we start from the premise that it is somebody's fault if agreement is not reached. The bill sets a negotiating environment in which agreements are to be reached. It says that if people fail to reach an agreement their unemployment benefits will be cut off. It is right and correct to say that, if the process fails, we cannot implement what the process was supposed to implement. That is fair enough. But to start from this premise and to adopt this attitude is illustrative of what the problem is with this legislation.

What we have in proposed clause 44 is a negotiation process which, if it were not enshrined in legislation, would be declared illegal under the Trade Practices Act. I know that in other sections of legislation a reasonable description of an unfair contract is one which is entered into unwillingly or one in which the process is not fair and properly negotiated. Under clause 44(2)(a)(iii), an unemployed person is deemed to have failed to reach an agreement if that person fails to agree to the terms set out by the case manager. If people do not accept that fait accompli, they are turfed out. The more I read this provision—and I have read it only a couple of times—the angrier I get about it.

We have moved three amendments. The first—amendment No. 15—sought to delete clause 44(2)(a)(iii) and replace it with a requirement that a case manager and an unemployed person must reach mutually agreed and reasonable terms for the agreement. I would have thought that it was almost impossible to argue against that; but we had a fairly swift dismissal of that amendment.

Amendments 16 and 17—which we are talking about now—require the department to attempt to mediate a solution on mutually agreeable terms. It is one last attempt at reaching an agreement. I would have thought that this government, of all governments, would do this. This morning I reminded honourable senators of the words breathed by the Prime Minister on Friday, 2 December—that the government would individually inquire about these people, take a personal interest in them and put them back in the system. This is not the government that is reflected in this wording. The government has not provided for a last attempt to mediate, to inquire about people individually and to look after them.

This is an opportunity for the department to ensure that case managers are not insisting on unreasonable conditions, and that the department meets its obligations under clauses 39(6) and 39(7) as to what can constitute a case management agreement. If the mediation fails to come up with an agreement, a person is deemed to have breached it and, subject to any appeal, his or her benefits are cut off, we believe that is a reasonable process and one that reflects the intentions expressed by the Prime Minister.

These amendments give meaning to the word `agreement' in the term `case management agreement' as well as to the nice words that we have in clauses 39(6) and 39(7). They also help avoid the allegation that, with this bill, the government is legislating for approval of unconscionable conduct and introducing unfair terms.

The government has a chance with this small adjustment to rescue the proposed legislation from the flavour with which it is soaked—the flavour of one-sided deals. I appeal to the government to recognise that that is what we are trying to do. We are only trying to fix the legislation. We are not trying to change its direction or make it into something it is not. In fact, we are trying to deliver what the Prime Minister said he is delivering.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will not be supporting amendments Nos 16 and 17.

—I want to add to what Senator Bell said and make a very quick appeal to the minister to consider these amendments.
