When I have the permission of the people concerned, I will be submitting to her evidence I gathered on a recent visit to central Queensland. According to a number of sources there—not just one but a number of organisations involved in case management and caring for young people who are being case managed—there is already evidence of very inappropriate counselling and very inappropriate questioning of people, going to details such as where they sleep, with whom they are living, and what their accommodation is like. There is a power situation. When people have power over others—in the end they have the ability to say whether people's incomes will continue—it can lead to the sort of very inappropriate relationships to which this chamber, and certainly this government, would not want to be party. I again appeal to the government to support the amendments moved by Senator Bell.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is not accepting these amendments. The point I particularly want to make to Senator Bell and Senator Woodley is that it is important to know that the agreements allow the case manager considerable flexibility in the negotiation process. In particular, the agreements do not have to be finalised in one sitting. If a job seeker is not happy with a particular terms that his or her case manager has included, there is provision for a cooling-off period which will allow the client to take the agreement away and consider it for up to five days before seeing the case manager again.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that that very much meets the intent of Senator Bell's amendments. I do not think there is a disagreement over the intent of this legislation. The debate is concerned with whether the legislation, as worded, will meet the intent that Senator Bell has mentioned. I think we are starting off with the same intent; it is just that Senator Bell is concerned that the legislation will not give effect to that intent.

There is no doubt that the points that Senator Bell raised are very important. But the cooling off period, the opportunity to not have to finish the negotiation in one day, the opportunity to go away and think about it, the opportunity to get back to talk it through—all of those seem to me to be built-in provisions to ensure just the sort of thing about which Senator Bell is concerned. Those are more than sufficient reasons for us not to accept this amendment, well intentioned as it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given a five-day cooling off period and given the lack of negotiation allowed under this legislation, what would be the point of coming back after the five days and saying, `I did not like it'? What choice would the unemployed person have? If after the five days the unemployed person quite clearly saw the agreement as not being in his or her long-term or short-term interests, what rights would such a person have to say, `No, this agreement isn't for me'?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are chasing paper tigers or something here. Of course, if a person is not content or wants time to think about it, it does not mean that they come back five days later and say, `I've thought about this and now I find myself in agreement with it.' It may be that that is what somebody would do. But it may also be that they would want to change the emphasis or talk about things in a different kind of way. I do not know, and I do not even want to start postulating, what might be in those agreements.

PARA.TAB: However, it is not accurate to say that something is set—`You can think about it for a day or you can think about it for five days but in the end you have to come back and that is definite.' On the advice that I am getting, it is not to be understood like that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may not be understood, but we have been trying to say today that the fact it does not provide any rights of negotiation means that that is exactly the way it can operate, especially if the case management is being farmed off to private contractors—and there is nothing to require the case manager to negotiate a different agreement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just read this out again. It may be that it is not the case managers who have idees fixes. The departmental guidelines on the negotiation of agreements allow the case manager to be flexible. To quote from the guidelines:

SPEECH.PARA: If a client is making a genuine attempt to negotiate but is clearly unhappy with a particular term, reasonable effort should be made to reach consensus with the client either by modifying the term or, in some cases, replacing it with a term proposed by the client which achieves the same purpose.
They are words within the guidelines attached to this bill that go to exactly the point Senator Margetts wants to make.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 18Clause 58, page 39, at end of subclause (2), add "and must not include bonus payments of more than 25% of the total fee if the person secures employment".

This amendment seeks to modify the conditions under which private sector case managers will get paid for the provision of services. ESRA will ultimately determine the conditions for payment, and that is probably appropriate. However, the bill provides no guidance to ESRA on how parliament believes fees for services should generally be determined. We had given to us just now some guidelines and I had, in a previous briefing, read to me some departmental guidelines to which parliament is not privy. The parliament is not to know how such guidelines are determined, how they are applied and whether they are complied with. It is all very well for the minister to read us guidelines, but we do not know the answer to those questions—whether they are actually applied, by whom, and how they are complied with.

PARA.TAB: We also have in this situation an omission—unless the minister can point out to me where other acts of parliament apply; she has done so already in a couple of instances—of what the capacity is of ESRA to determine what case managers will get paid for. In other words, the private sector case managers are to be paid for a provision of services, but we do not really know how that is to be determined. I remind the chamber that this is the first time in Australia's history that a major social welfare delivery function such as employment services has been privatised. I think it is reasonable and appropriate that the parliament provides some guidance on the financial arrangements that impinge on that.

Our amendment seeks to do one thing: set a limit on the maximum amount that can be paid as a bonus if a person is placed. Why should there be a maximum? Why should a big bonus not be paid for performance—in other words, placement? It is because case management must be about making the long-term unemployed job ready. It must be about identifying their individual needs, responding to those needs individually and building up an individual skill base. But if payment is loaded too much towards placement, case managers will not be all that interested in doing very much about all the things I just described. Placement will dominate, as I think it will anyway because of the pressures of numbers and of continuing to act as case managers.

We will find inappropriate placements, probably made only because of jobstart subsidies. I am suggesting here and now that they will become the norm, that they will dominate. When the jobstart subsidy runs out the unready and uncertain unemployed people will be back on the dole queue, but of course they will not be long-term unemployed people any more. They will have another set of queuing qualifications to complete—another hiccup to whatever their plans might be.

The Australian Democrats do not disagree with the concept of some sort of recognition of the success of placing a person and some sort of payment or compensation for that success. But we believe that the vast bulk of payments should be for the provision of the service—the management of a person's case—and that the counselling, the skill acquisition and the management should be what is paid for. If that service is good and well remunerated, the personal needs addressed and the job readiness of the unemployed person enhanced, and if there are jobs out there that job ready person will, by pure logic, eventually take up a position.

Two points can be made in relation to that. A person could be as job ready as is possible but, if the employment prospects do not exist, that person will not be matched with a vacancy. The other point is that, if the training and the job readiness is in an area which is not available in the immediate geographical vicinity, it will be harder for that person to gain employment. So the appropriateness of the counselling, the job skilling, and the timeliness are important factors.

This amendment seeks to set a maximum for bonus payments of 25 per cent of the total fee. That provides an incentive to place the unemployed but it does so without loading it so much as to detract from the real purpose, which we agree with. The real purpose is actually to manage the case, not to get to the end point so quickly just to attract a bonus. We believe that 25 per cent would do that without loading it so much as to detract from the importance of the provision of the case management services.

What we have here follows to some extent the proposition that I put as amendment No. 12 to clause 42, which sought to encourage placements in sustainable long-term employment positions. It has the same logic and it is done with the same intent. That amendment having failed, it does not make this one irrelevant. We are trying to tie the financial incentives to the private sector case managers to fund a process to achieve that aim.

The frustration I feel, having moved so many amendments which have been rejected this morning, is a frustration which derives from having participated in a very long process of negotiation and of genuine interest in this legislation by the Democrats. We had a genuine willingness to accept the thrust of the legislation, not to challenge it in its thrust and direction, but to attempt to modify it. One of the disappointments which I bring to the chamber this morning is that I detect a degree of departmental petulance. It has taken a great deal of forbearance on my part not to get angry about it, because for many months a considerable part of our party's scant resources has been devoted to understanding this confusing bill, to supporting it in its thrust, without getting in the way. But to be confronted with a backflip on agreements reached and directions endorsed as a result of what I think can only be described by the words I used before—departmental petulance—should be mentioned in this place. I make no apology for bringing it up now. The frustrations that have been experienced by both Senator Margetts and me this morning have resulted from a change of mind which has still to be justified on the part of the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is unusual for you.

—Yes. Normally we are on the receiving end of this sort of stuff. We have learnt to be accused of changing our minds and all those sorts of things. Sometimes we admit that we do need to change our position when we have had things explained to us that we were not aware of previously. But in this case, bearing in mind the resources of the government, having led us by the nose for several months and having reached agreements, to be treated in the way that we have over this piece of legislation is frustrating in the extreme and also annoying. That is why I raise it. I have explained what we are trying to do with our amendment No. 18. I know how far we will get with it but I have moved it despite that.

—Right from the beginning, from the second reading debate, the Greens have expressed their concerns about the possibility of the whole system being used by private case management officers and others, and people working in the government sector, to make their life easier by creaming off those people who are easy to place, and putting those who are hard to place at the end of the queue where they will have to start all over again and go through the same process. We strongly support Senator Bell's amendment No. 18 because it at least tries to give some guidelines as to what the limits should be on how much we encourage those case managers to do just that. I would like to ask the minister whether, if this amendment is not supported, the government will be willing to provide guidelines on bonuses and the scales of payments that will be available to the private sector, so as not to encourage this possibility.

PARA.TAB: I want also to take this opportunity to speak at this stage of the bill because this is the last amendment. The debate during the committee stage has forced me to make some brief comments. There has been talk in this place recently of an unholy alliance, usually referring to the situation where the opposition and the Greens agree on a package of amendments to a bill. But last night and today we have witnessed the classic unholy alliance between the government and the opposition. I might add here that, if anyone bothers to examine the voting records they will see that this is the norm in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially the last two days.

—Yes, especially the last two days. What we have seen is an alliance based on a commitment to the principles of economic fundamentalism in which the accountants and the economists hold sway and the concerns of people in the community are largely ignored in the facile belief that improving a set of economic statistics will inevitably provide benefits to the workers in the community. These attitudes are very evident in the explanatory memorandum, where the emphasis is on Australia becoming a `more internationally competitive nation' and on `efficiency and effectiveness'.

PARA.TAB: I thought, perhaps naively, that this bill was about helping long-term unemployed people to gain meaningful employment. These people, by the way, have been left on the scrap heap by this commitment to economic fundamentalism. It appears that I was wrong in my belief that it was about meaningful employment, and the responses from the government and the opposition to the very reasonable amendments proposed by the Greens and the Democrats are ample evidence of that. How many times did I hear that our amendments were unacceptable because they provided too much flexibility? What is wrong with providing the disadvantaged in this community with some level of flexibility as we attempt to assist them back into employment?

This bill is in fact part of the strategy alluded to by Senator Bell in which the unemployment problem is handled by shifting people represented by statistical data from one category to another. Here we have people forced into mickey mouse training programs through the assistance of their case managers in order that the government can claim miraculous reductions in the number of long-term unemployed people. Unfortunately, we are talking about real people who do not see any improvement in their long-term prospects or their self-esteem despite the statistical mirror game.

I only hope that the government, the opposition and their advisers who case managed this bill last night and today will sleep well knowing that, whilst they may have improved some obscure econometric analysis of the unemployment problem, they have done very little to assist unemployed people in this community and their families who are continuing to suffer under this economic fundamentalist regime. Amendment 18 is the last chance to suggest that maybe there are some principles there and we can try to impose them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must rise to make this one last appeal to the government. As I indicated earlier, there have already been, and I have documentation here, numbers of concerns raised about case management and CES case management interviews. I will put on the record some of the concerns which have been raised. People are asked what barriers they have to employment. The obvious reason, lack of jobs, is not considered. Job seekers are challenged to look at themselves to explain lack of employment and to look beyond the obvious external factors such as no jobs available, no experience, et cetera.

PARA.TAB: The internal factors which they are being asked to address can be both demoralising and destructive. Private issues and personal problems are probed. Questions such as the following have been asked. Do you have a drinking problem? Tell me about your home situation? Does your father bash you up? Are you in a relationship? Tell me about school? Did you have any bad experiences? In one interview, the following question was asked and the person could not understand why: Have you ever been unconscious or had a head injury?

In a number of instances, it is the goals of the case manager which are set down not the goals of the job seeker. For example, a case manager told a young person, `There is a LEAP program coming up, so I will put you down for that.' The young person had already decided to do child care. People feel obliged to answer questions which are invasive. When asked about her accommodation, a young person told the case manager it was none of her business. She was told, `It is my business, and I want you to find more appropriate accommodation.' Even if job seekers are told they do not have to answer questions, they do not feel safe to refuse a reply. Their income is at stake, and the case manager is seen as powerful.

These are some of the problems that we are trying to indicate to the government are going to be exacerbated in the coming months and years. I am afraid that if the government cannot hear our appeal at this point—and I do hope that as these kinds of examples escalate and multiply in coming months we will draw them to the attention of the government—it will begin to understand what it is we have tried to say all along.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be supporting amendment No. 18. I would like to say to Senator Margetts that I could not comment on whether or not the seeming alliance between the government and the opposition is unholy. I would have to say, from my brief experience in this place, that it is probably unusual from the legislation that I have seen put forward.

PARA.TAB: The coalition has a genuine commitment to lowering the present number of unemployed people in Australia. If this system, as it has been put forward by the government, can improve that, we will be interested to see the operation of it. I think we have registered some of our concerns about the legislation. There are still some concerns to be registered, which will come out during the consequential amendments. Our purpose in not opposing this bill is a genuine desire to see fewer unemployed people in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is opposing amendment No. 18. The fee structure as proposed by ESRA provides an incentive for employment outcomes. Currently two fees are proposed; namely, a case management fee to be paid up front and a further payment to be paid on successful placement.

PARA.TAB: With respect to the proposed fee structure arrangements, firstly, there will be four different client classification levels, depending on the barriers the job seeker faces to employment. The higher the impediment to employment, the larger the fee. Secondly, the level of the successful placement fee will depend on the client classification level and also on whether the job seeker is placed in subsidised or unsubsidised employment. In the order of half the total fee will be payable on successful placement, depending on the particular job seeker.

Senator Margetts went into a number of matters. I do not want to be provoked at this time of the year, but I have seen a lot of different voting combinations in my time in the Senate. It is not as long as, for example, Senator Harradine, who I am sure has seen a lot weirder and wonderful combinations of votes over the years. We are judging issues on their merits. I will accept the bona fides of the opposition on this issue, just as I will accept the bona fides and the particular position of the Greens on some occasions and reject them on others.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Bell's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: EMPLOYMENT SERVICES (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments to be moved to the Employment Services (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1994 and move:

PARA.TAB: (1)Schedule, page 24, item 11 at end of item, add the following note:
"Note:This item amends the second occurring reference to Subdivision F in Division 1 of Part 2.12.".
(2)Schedule, page 24, after item 12, insert the following item:

TAB.TAB: "12A. Section 630C:

SPEECH.PARA: Reposition at the beginning of Subdivision G (immediately before section 631).".

The government amendments to the Employment Services (Consequential Amendments) Bill make two minor technical changes to correct numbering errors in amendments relating to the Social Security Act 1991.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on amendments 1 to 8. Whilst I will be speaking on amendments 1 to 8, there is an indication from the opposition that it is prepared to support amendments 2, 4, 6 and 8 standing in my name but not amendments 1, 3, 5 and 7. With the agreement of the Senate, I will speak to the groups of amendments separately and indicate where the difference is. I will deal with amendments 1, 3, 5 and 7 first and then with amendments 2, 4, 6 and 8.

PARA.TAB: The rationale for these amendments is that we would like to keep the two pay cheques after a period of notice has been given for cut-off for an allowance. The government accepted that this be put into the Social Security Act earlier this year. It has now tried to remove it because of minor administration problems. What this re-writing proposes to do is to tidy up the legislation so that there are not any administrative problems, to keep the present preferred situation in for unemployed people.

What my amendments 1, 3, 5 and 7 do is to make the notice period very short, that is, three days, and the person is paid the next two payments before getting cut-off. I am sure everybody knows the arguments for this, but whilst I accept that the coalition at this stage is unable to accept this, I would be interested to find out whether it or the government has an alternative suggestion for the `three days' from my amendments.

The government has used the poor excuse that its administrative period takes 35 days after the warning period and that this is an inadequate and variable procedure. It is within the bureaucracy. It is nowhere outlined in the act, and it is definitely not transparent. Most importantly, this administrative waiting period applies only for activity test breaches, such as adjusting allowances for income from work, resigning from a job voluntarily, being retrenched et cetera. This internal administrative waiting period does not exist for administrative breaches—such as requirements to attend interviews, ring, fill out forms and return mail—which account for 6,000 breaches per month.

The Greens believe that it is very important to keep in this bill the sections from the Social Security Act which would govern case management services in this country for all unemployed people. The Greens believe that the government has been backhanded by tending to wipe these sections out of the new bill as if they did not exist and had not served a significant function.

I would like to thank the opposition and the Democrats for their stated intention of support for amendments 2, 4, 6 and 8. As I said, if there is an alternative to the three day cut-off, I would be pleased to hear any suggestions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on these amendments because they bring back into play an amendment I moved earlier this year to some other legislation. The Democrats believe that these amendments are essential to preserving the arrangements put in place by the amendment which I moved to a social security bill in June this year. That amendment said that people must be notified if they are to lose their income support as a result of having a breach determined against them, and they must receive two more payments before any deferment period could take effect.

PARA.TAB: The government has simply tried to dismantle these provisions by moving amendments to this consequential bill in the House of Representatives. I was pleased to see that the House of Representatives Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee gave the government a serve for introducing these amendments as amendments to a consequential bill in another portfolio area. I will not spend time on that issue other than to say that, when people's livelihoods are going to be affected by legislation, it is totally unacceptable to introduce that legislation in a backdoor manner.

Earlier this year, the government introduced much tougher penalties for people who breach the activity test on their jobsearch or newstart allowance. These tougher penalties were supposedly meant as a quid pro quo for all the positive measures—and we recognise those—that the government was going to introduce for the long-term unemployed. Of course, in pushing for tougher penalties, the government ignored the section on page 128 of the white paper which said:

SPEECH.PARA: Program interventions will be more effective where participants are willing and enthusiastic rather than coerced by the threat of penalties related to their income support payments.

It also chose to ignore the statistics which showed overwhelmingly that the old regime of penalties was already very harsh and was working. Under that old system of penalties, of the 146,000 unemployed people who breached their obligations for a first time, only 13,000 committed another breach within three years. In other words, less than 10 per cent of those who were required to serve a two-week deferment period committed another breach. Similarly, of those who breached twice, only about 10 per cent of that 10 per cent breached a third time.

PARA.TAB: Finally, the government also chose to ignore the fact that most of the beneficial aspects of the white paper are not due to be up and running until the middle of next year. Despite the timetable for beneficial measures, the statistical evidence and the urgings of the white paper, the government proposed harsher penalties, and the opposition, regrettably, backed them. To its credit, however, the opposition was prepared to support the Democrats in at least establishing a system whereby people who were going to lose their income support payments would get some prior notice from the department.

It is this system of prior warning that the government is now seeking to do away with. I simply say to the government that all the arguments I presented when first introducing this system still hold and, as such, the Democrats will be supporting the amendments. The government may claim that people are already receiving notice, but that does not line up with the word we are getting back from people in the field.

I would like to conclude my remarks by quoting an unemployed man who wrote to the Senate inquiry which was held on this issue. He said that cutting a person off the dole would bring about nothing short of a personal crisis. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Precipitating crisis in the members of its community would hardly seem to be a worthy government objective.
This is precisely what the extended penalty periods will be doing and the amendments contained in this bill will only exacerbate that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Margetts pointed out, the coalition will be supporting Green amendments 2, 4, 6 and 8. We will not be supporting amendments Nos 1, 3, 5 and 7. I would like to speak to the amendments we will be supporting.

PARA.TAB: The opposition has stated that it agrees with the general thrust of the approach the government is taking in relation to reciprocal obligation requirements to the extent that it can be done equitably. The administration of the deferment period should give a clear signal to a person who has undertaken reciprocal obligations under the activity test agreement.

Given our concern with equity, the coalition has consistently insisted that any amendments to the procedures determined by the Senate in June should be fair to the person whose benefits will be deferred. For this reason, Dr Kemp, the shadow minister for employment, training and family services, requested the government to refer its proposed amendments to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training so that the coalition and the public could have the benefit of a detailed consideration of the implications of the proposed amendments.

In the event, these amendments were not made available to the committee in sufficient time to allow it to reach a conclusion as to their fairness or otherwise. Nor have repeated inquiries by the opposition to the government on this matter produced satisfactory justification for the removal of the provision for the two payment periods following notification of the activity test breach.

Over the last week, while negotiation on this bill has been taking place, the government has indicated on almost a daily basis that it will put forward guidelines which will address our concerns on this matter. In the event, none of these guidelines have been produced—even up to as late as this morning. We simply are not prepared to go ahead and back the government on the basis that the guidelines will be produced some time in the future.

The government has repeatedly failed to justify why people who would be in straitened financial circumstances would immediately lose their benefit when they are making an appeal which could be successful. The bipartisan House of Representatives committee was not prepared to commit itself to outright support for the government's proposal. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: This issue of deferment of allowances is a complex policy matter that the committee has not had sufficient time to investigate.

Its recommendation was that it is essential that sufficient notice be given before income support payments are deferred due to a breach of obligations. That is on page 33 of its report. In relation to administrative breaches, the period of 60 days quoted in the report and referred to by the department in briefings, in our view, is likely to be an extreme case and not typical.

PARA.TAB: The department made the point that the wording of the June amendment was administratively difficult because the department had no way of knowing when a notice of deferment had been received, and that the two instalments of jobsearch allowance should be based on the sending out of the notification rather than its receipt. ACOSS was extremely concerned by the most recent proposed amendments and was also concerned that tighter reciprocal obligations constituted a punitive approach that is unhelpful and runs entirely counter to the case management approach. It agreed that the amendment to allow deferral periods to operate from the time the notice is sent is necessary, but believes that this is only acceptable if there is a period of notice.

The Welfare Rights Centre explained that two extra payments are most important to allow recipients time, firstly, to lodge an appeal against the decision before any financial loss is incurred and, secondly, to arrange their financial affairs before the penalty period takes effect. Accordingly, we are not prepared to accept the deletion of the provision for two additional payments following notification of an activity test breach.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the chamber for coming back into this debate after being out of it for an hour and a half. As I understand it, we are having a general discussion about amendments 1, 3, 5 and 7 which are being taken together, and amendments 2, 4, 6 and 8.

PARA.TAB: The government opposes amendments 1, 3, 5 and 7. Prescribing a three-day limit on the giving of a written notice to the person who has incurred a deferment of allowance is an impossible imposition which displays no understanding of the process involved after the CES has made the decision to cancel a person's allowance. The CES decision is transferred electronically to the Department of Social Security, which in turn must process it and then issue the notice through its mail house facility. As this process is largely automated and depends on factors such as the volume of transactions to be processed at any one time, it would be impossible for the CES or the DSS to meet this limit in all cases. That is why we oppose those amendments. As I understand it, the opposition is also opposing those amendments.

The government opposes amendments 2, 4, 6 and 8 which, I understand, the opposition is supporting and to which Senator Troeth has just spoken. They simply perpetuate the two payments system and are no more workable or acceptable to the government than the amendments introduced into the legislation by the Australian Democrats in July.

The two payment provisions have proved administratively unworkable. For example, the time lapse between the notice of a requirement and the imposition of the appropriate deferment penalty has had to be substantially lengthened because of the need to ensure that the deferment period only commences after the notice specifying the commencement date is actually received by the person. This requirement means that the decision maker must make a decision on an event about which he or she cannot be certain at the time the decision is made. To overcome this uncertainty, additional time has been built into the process to ensure that the legislation is complied with in all cases. This additional time lapse is in the order of two to three weeks, which sends the wrong signals to allowance recipients about the importance of their obligations.

I can assure the chamber that it is not the government's aim to deal harshly with the unemployed; however, it is our responsibility on behalf of the whole community to ensure that they respond positively to the many and varied measures of assistance offered to them. This is the essence of reciprocal obligations, and the success of the CES in helping job seekers is largely dependent on their timely and cooperative responses to the requirements made of them.

In summary, the government's amendments will ensure that a person is given a clear requirement to attend at or contact the CES, as well as an appropriate deadline in having to respond in five to 21 days. Failure to respond to that requirement will generate a second letter which clearly warns people that they risk the loss of allowance if they fail to respond within a further 14 days. The CES can be approached at any time during this process to change an appointment or to listen to a person's reasons or complaints.

In the case of an apparent activity test breach the client is invited to explain the circumstances of his or her non-compliance before any decision is taken to apply a breach and impose a deferment period. When a person is found to have breached a requirement and requests a review of that decision there is discretion for the authorised review officer to continue payment of allowance to the person pending a review of the decision.

The government firmly believes that these procedures are fair and equitable and provide sufficient notice to the person of the consequences of failing to respond to a specific requirement made of the person. To retain a provision which effectively rewards that failure with a two further payments of allowance breaks the nexus between breach and penalty and sends the wrong signals to job seekers about the importance of their reciprocal obligations.

I also want to comment on the guidelines which Senator Troeth mentioned. I have been advised that these guidelines were discussed with Dr Kemp's office on Wednesday following discussions on Monday and Tuesday with Dr Kemp's adviser, a Ms Kate Harvey. Dr Kemp's office did not agree or disagree with the guidelines or accept them but I will just put them on the record.

These are the guidelines which were put to Dr Kemp's office: the powers conferred by sections 124(1) and 125(1) enable the authorised review officer or area manager to decide, with or without a specific request from the affected person, that payment of allowance should continue to the person pending the review of that decision. In deciding whether to exercise this discretion each case should be considered on its merits having regard to all the circumstances presented by the person and other relevant factors.

The following considerations should be taken into account: the potential for financial hardship while the review is being undertaken—that is, whether the person will have sufficient other income or means of support, for example, family or friends; and whether there are alternative means of income support for the person's dependants, if any, bearing in mind that, where people are facing a longer deferment period, they may need the review period to organise their finances.

The second major point in the guidelines is the person's compliance history; a person with no previous record of breaches should expect more leniency than someone who has repeatedly breached before. The final point of the guidelines is whether a person has any apparent physical, mental, or intellectual disability or condition which may be adversely affected if payment is not continued. We believe that those guidelines cover the concerns raised by the committee and that amendments Nos 2, 4, 6 and 8 to be moved by the Western Australian Greens should be opposed.
Progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to deal with a matter of great concern to many sporting people, particularly those who are interested in soccer football as I am.
—We saw your interview on a soccer program.

—I thank the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction for his intervention. I see he is being as helpful as usual. This afternoon Senator Ian Campbell, the shadow minister for sport, will be having an interview with senior members of the Australian Soccer Federation relating to the inquiry by Mr Justice Stewart into certain aspects of transfer payments and other matters of concern to Australian soccer which were first raised in general by the ABC on its Four Corners program.

PARA.TAB: The report of former Mr Justice Stewart, which was due originally to be presented to the federation in September, was delayed until 1 December. In the interim, the Senate has on the Notice Paper a notice of motion that this question should be referred to a Senate committee. This motion has not been brought forward because quite properly its mover, Senator Campbell, wanted to ensure that the Soccer Federation had every opportunity of dealing with this matter in its own way, which was to have its own report.

I commend the Soccer Federation for, firstly, having an inquiry and for, secondly, having someone of the eminence of former Mr Justice Stewart conducting it. However, I pointed out at the time—and pressed the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) on this matter—that such an inquiry would of necessity not provide the protection against legal action that would be needed if its findings were to be publicly released. There would be no doubt that potentially defamatory material would have to be involved in such an inquiry, because there were very serious allegations made.

I had heard allegations, for example, from many people within the soccer community. I used to play in Sydney and was a referee there. Many good friends—most of them, I would be happy to admit, much better soccer players than I was—have been expressing their concerns to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —You must have been a sweeper.

—I hate to admit it, but of all places I was left full-back, which did not seem to fit in with my political orientation. But the right full-back in one team I played with was Dr Klugman, one of Senator Schacht's former colleagues. That was at university.

PARA.TAB: The problem was, as I pointed out, that the lack of legal protection for witnesses and for the report itself was simply unacceptable. That is why I thought there should have been a an inquiry, perhaps a parliamentary inquiry, with particular powers to enable evidence and conclusions to be protected against the threat of defamation action. The Soccer Federation took the view that it could insure against this eventuality and that that would provide sufficient protection. I disagreed and, in fact, we have had lengthy talks about it. I took the view, which now appears correct, that the risks were far too great. I understand that is one of the reasons why this report, which was presented to the Soccer Federation on the first of this month, has not yet been released.

There is no likelihood of its being released in the near future, as far as I can understand. That is the reason why the shadow minister for sport has gone to Sydney to discuss with the top people in the Soccer Federation what the problem really is. Quite frankly, unless there is a very sound reason for the Senate not proceeding with this inquiry in these circumstances, I would be strongly in favour of the Senate proceeding with its own inquiry.

The reason for this is, of course, self-evident: about $2 million a year of taxpayers' money goes towards support and promotion of soccer in Australia. I think that is great and I am all in favour of it, and I do not want to see that put at risk by anything that may emerge from this inquiry. It concerns me that there will be suggestions of a cover-up if the details and the conclusions of this inquiry are not publicly revealed, and that there will be suspicions as to why various matters that should be in the public arena are not in the public arena.

One of the great advantages that would emerge, if the Senate inquiry did proceed—I think notice of that matter has been deferred until tomorrow—is that it would provide the Australian Soccer Federation with an opportunity to have all this material put on the record as part of the evidence of a Senate inquiry and therefore given protection. I would hope that the Australian Soccer Federation would ask us to proceed with that. It seems to me that it would be in the federation's best interests and it would demonstrate that it had nothing to hide.

Quite frankly, knowing some of the people in the Australian Soccer Federation, I would think that the great bulk of them would be of that view, that it would be in their best interests to be shown to have nothing to hide. At the moment, there is no national sponsor for the National Soccer League. I would think the prospects of getting that kind of financial support would be diminished until the sport was shown to be clean, as I hope it is and I feel sure it will be in the future. However, until the Soccer Federation takes that view, questions must hang over the sport. I would hope that when the Senate discusses this matter—hopefully tomorrow—we will take the view that having such an inquiry will be in the interests of the Soccer Federation and of soccer. But I do not want to canvass that debate tomorrow.

There are many additional problems that the Soccer Federation has to recognise it must resolve. There are matters that go beyond the role of the Soccer Federation. It has resolved some particular problems affecting it, but there are matters relating to other proceedings and other prosecutions, in some instances. There are reports from bodies such as the National Crime Authority and there are internal police reports. I would think that those could properly be presented to a Senate inquiry; although, the inquiry may have to be extended beyond the very specific and limited role of Senator Campbell's motion.

I commend the Soccer Federation for having taken some steps in what appear to be matters of concern relating to the potential for a conflict of interest. For example, the annual report of the Soccer Federation for 1993 reveals that:

SPEECH.PARA: A director of the Federation, Mr J. Constantine, is the principal of Constantine & Co., Solicitors. This firm rendered legal advice to the economic entity—
that is, the Australian Soccer Federation—
All dealings were in the ordinary course of business and on normal commercial terms and conditions. Fees paid to Constantine & Co. during the year totalled $72,725.

I see no particular problems with that, but I do not think it is a procedure that all people would be happy with. Obviously, some people would not be happy with it. I think it probably creates an unfortunate impression that when you go into the Soccer Federation's building it is basically the same office—turn left and it is Constantine and Co., turn right and it is the Soccer Federation. In any event, I understand that that matter has been resolved.

PARA.TAB: Another matter has been resolved, that is a director of the federation, Mr Tony Labbozzetta, who resigned during the year, has an interest as a partner in the business Marconi Travel. This business renders service in connection with travel arrangements for the federation in respect of interstate and international travel. All dealings with the business are in the ordinary course of business and on normal commercials terms and conditions. Moneys paid to Marconi Travel during the year in respect of travel arrangements amounted to $129,246.

I make the point once again that when there are those internal relationships there will inevitably be questions, particularly when Mr Labbozzetta, who has been heavily involved with the Marconi club, has been subjected to a fair amount of inquiry under the licensing court actions relating to alleged improper behaviour in the running of that club.

I do not want to repeat the allegations made. The Sydney Morning Herald had an article yesterday with the headline `Marconi president faces 10-year ban'. These are matters on the public record. It was alleged that Mr Labbozzetta was not a truthful witness. My concerns are that this question of travel is a very important one when you are involved in a national sporting organisation. People have to be seen to be purer than pure when they are in this relationship.

What concerns me in particular is that some members of the Labbozzetta family, particularly Francesco who was involved with the Marconi Travel company, have been the subject of an internal police confidential inquiry. Once again, I do not want to canvass the contents of that inquiry. There may be an appropriate time when it can be presented.

There were links with another travel company in South Australia, a company called Sea Air Travel in which Francesco Nicola Labbozzetta was shown as one of the owners for three years. Unfortunately, this company has been involved with another family, the members of which were involved in prosecutions relating to something like $3 million of tax avoided and additional tax relating to understatements of taxation—this was the result of a National Crime Authority report. There were serious allegations made about how that money was earned.

These are all matters that should and could properly be the subject of an inquiry, if that was the course to take. If one rang the South Australia Soccer Federation and said one wanted to go to the World Cup in the United States earlier this year, the travel company recommended by the South Australia Soccer Federation was Sea Air Travel because that company was organising packages.

Once again, it seems to me this raises serious problems, particularly as the family involved in Sea Air Travel, it has been claimed, has been involved in drug dealing. It is recorded as such in the National Crime Authority annual report for 1990-91. In other words, there is a series of problems that need to be looked at and, in the overall issue, these are not directly related to the running of the Australian Soccer Federation.

Soccer has to clear itself of all of these bad associations and it has to start at the top. The best way for the Soccer Federation to do so is to encourage and to support the inquiry by the Senate. All the matters brought up by Justice Stewart should be put on the record so that the public can see that the Soccer Federation has done the right thing in conducting the Stewart inquiry and that there is nothing to hide as a result of that inquiry's ultimate report. I believe that the Soccer Federation made the right decision in conducting the inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to echo concerns which have been raised in a number of forums lately about the arrest rate for Aboriginal people in the town of Wiluna in Western Australia. In particular, the Aboriginal Legal Service in Western Australia has pointed to the enormous increase in arrest rates since there was a change in police personnel earlier this year. There have also been comments from a local justice of the peace, who is quoted in the media as saying that Aboriginal people need to be locked up for their own protection. It is a deeply disturbing situation for such views to be held by a public officer who is able to enforce his views by the power to imprison people.

PARA.TAB: I quote from the West Australian of 7 November about the arrest rate for Aboriginal women in the town:

SPEECH.PARA: From January until August this year, 720 female arrests were made in a community of about 80 women.

That means that, in an eight-month period, every Aboriginal woman in the town could have been arrested an average of nine times. The Aboriginal Legal Service points out that many of these arrests are based on a charge of communicating with prisoners who are on the lawns of the lockup, even though there is an open-gate policy allowing people to visit their relatives. These arrests attracted prison sentences of three weeks, in spite of the commitment of all jurisdictions in Australia to imprisonment being an option of last resort.

PARA.TAB: The comment by the ALS that these charges are being used as a discretionary tool by the police as a means of stopping people talking to prisoners clearly is one that should be taken very seriously. Furthermore, disruption to the lives of families, which must occur time and time again, can only contribute to the pressures and stresses on all concerned. I am sure that honourable senators feel as I do; the prospect of a woman going to see her partner, who happens to be in the lock-up, and then not returning must have serious consequences for her children.

The ALS has conducted extensive research on the situation in Wiluna and has produced a report which presents some very disturbing statistics. I will provide some of the statistics. From 1991-92 to 1994, the total population of Wiluna fell from 400 to 250. Of the people charged in 1991-92, 97 per cent were Aboriginal. During the study period in 1994, 99 per cent of the people charged were Aboriginal. The total number of charges laid in 1991-92 was 522. In the period from 1 January until the end of August this year, 1,071 charges were laid; this in spite of the drop in population. Of these charges, in 1991-92 there were 208 street offences, while there were 846 street offences in the 1994 period. In 1991-92, 184 serious charges were laid, and that figure dropped by half in 1994 to 92. The study draws some interesting conclusions at this point and it refers to age and gender characteristics of the charge patterns. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: Current policing involves the criminalisation of a far broader cross-section of the community than is the norm.
In particular, charge rates for females in the Aboriginal community of Wiluna are more than twice the female charge rate in the general Western Australian population.

PARA.TAB: I make particular mention of the treatment of intoxicated persons in recent Wiluna policing practices. Whereas the numbers of people apprehended as intoxicated have remained largely static, the proportion detained for being intoxicated has risen enormously because police stopped transferring people to their home or to other places. Overall, the report states that the case load of charges in Wiluna shows that a far greater proportion of minor charges and far fewer serious charges are laid than is the case when the whole state is considered,

I have to question the need for such a high arrest and detention rate when it is considered that 88 per cent of charge outcomes result in fines. If imprisonment is an unlikely outcome upon conviction, detention should not be the initial response to the offence. There is clearly no danger to the community in 88 per cent of cases presented; therefore there should be no thought of placing people in the lockup.

We may consider it encouraging to see that fines are being imposed instead of imprisonment terms. However, the pattern in 1994 has been that the real monetary level of the fines imposed has doubled since 1991-92. As a result of this, a great number of people were imprisoned for those fines. To give some idea of the level of fines imposed, for the entire population of some 250 people the fines amounted to an average of $789 per person—man, woman and child—for the period of the study. There is a sense in which this whole issue begs the question whether there are, in fact, too many police in the town. After all, if police are prepared to do the paperwork necessary to maintain such an arrest rate, they obviously have considerable time on their hands.

The justice of the peace, to whom I referred, has been quoted as saying that he thinks the local police strength of seven full-time officers is `about right' for a town the size of Wiluna. In my view, that is an outrageous statement. Extrapolated state wide, that would mean that the WA police force should comprise 43,000—or over 10 times the current police force. While I am sure that we would find elements in the WA community, maybe even in the police force, who would agree, this is palpable nonsense—and I know that there are many members of the police force who would not agree.

I find it quite extraordinary that, four years after the conclusions of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody became known, we are still failing in the crucial area of reducing custody rates for Aboriginal people, and reducing them in areas where there is clearly no threat to the community. When we find that 88 per cent of these arrests result in fines as penalties, and we know they are not serious offences, it is indefensible that we are still continuing with practices that result in this kind of custody rate for our Aboriginal people.

The issue goes to the very heart of the relations between Aboriginal people and the police and also the community at large. There are clearly too many discretionary means by which police—and I do not think this is restricted to Western Australia—can control the lives of Aboriginal people. Arrests for minor offences or infractions have a disproportionate effect when they are repeated time and time again. Such incidents breed the very resentment which has poisoned relations between Aboriginal people and those in positions of authority since colonial times.

Yet there are towns in which tensions between Aboriginal people and police have been reduced and arrest rates have been reduced. There are clear indications that cooperation between the two groups can and does work. For instance, in Broome there is a police-community relations committee which has been instrumental in reducing tensions. The work of the Aboriginal visitors scheme should be commended for the way in which their assistance to police has built up a very encouraging rapport and a capacity to work together on community issues. `Community policing', that code word which seems to have a multitude of meanings, can be made to work when there is a commitment to it. If issues can be addressed as they arise, if tensions can be dealt with by discussion at a local level, then progress can be made. And we desperately need progress in this area because, without wanting to be alarmist, there are lives at stake.

The issue also raises again the matter of the meal allowances which are paid to police officers in Western Australia to provide meals to people in lockups. It comes as no surprise that the response from the highest levels of the police force has again been to say that the matter will be reviewed. But the matter has been reviewed time and time again and always the response has been to keep the system going.

I might add: I first became aware of this problem in 1985. In endeavouring to gain statistics on the rate of juvenile detentions in police lockups, which were not collected, I came upon the very interesting information in the department of community services budget that, for that financial year, $40,000 had been transferred from the department of community services to the police department for the meal allowances for juveniles alone. We know that the rate for adults was even greater so we know it is a longstanding and entrenched problem within the criminal justice system which is allowing a very discriminatory practice to occur.

I consider that the present meal allowance scheme remains open to abuse in a number of ways: police being overzealous in making arrests; police proceeding by arrest where a summons would be more appropriate; prisoners being held in custody longer than is necessary, for example, by delaying bail until after a meal period has expired; supply of poor or inadequate qualities of food to prisoners; and, claims for meals that have not been provided.

The WA police force was recently forced to sack a much respected police officer who had been found guilty in court of rorting the meal allowance system. It is time the opportunity for that sort of corruption was ended. Private contractors have indicated that they would be happy to tender for contracts and that they feel sure that it could be done at competitive prices. If ever there was a government function in Western Australia which should be privatised, maybe this is it.

Clearly, there is a policing crisis in Wiluna. The patterns of policing have changed markedly between 1991-92 and 1994. There has been a change of police staff in the town and it is impossible to escape the conclusion that the changes reflect a different emphasis by the officer in charge. The scope of the changes cannot be explained in any other way. Any privatisation or move to a catering contract will not address the deep systemic problem that is there in our police force unless there is a significant shift in attitudes within the police force that support the measure that is supposed to be prevailing in every jurisdiction in this country, which is that prison is the measure of last resort. It should only be utilised where an individual prisoner is a threat to the community or to himself or herself. It is indefensible to use it in the cases in which it is being used at present.

Every government in Australia claims to be committed to implementing the recommendations of the royal commission. Sadly, there is an enormous gulf between the rhetoric and the reality. This is something we have to get right in this country and we have to do so quickly. There are lives at stake in this matter. We cannot proceed to any reconciliation process if we continue to regard our indigenous people in this way and use the police forces in this country as a way of addressing systemic discriminatory practices.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak once again on the issue of the devastating drought that is affecting Australia and the lack of action by this federal ALP government.

PARA.TAB: The federal government today has the opportunity in cabinet to revise the inadequate policies that it brought in in September. Let us certainly hope that it does. A number of my colleagues and I have been calling on the government to do this for quite some time. Yesterday we had the extraordinary spectacle in this place of this government trying to gag the opposition, which was telling the Australian people and putting on the official record what is really the situation in rural and regional Australia after four years of drought, and the actual inaction of this federal government on this matter.

In contrast, the Fahey coalition government in New South Wales announced a number of initiatives in August and in October and again yesterday at its cabinet meeting which thoroughly address all aspects of this crisis. I will come back to the New South Wales initiatives a little later. If we focus on what this ALP government is doing or, I should say, not doing—

TALK.START.PARA: —One hundred and sixty-four million dollars.
—Over two years.
—You said four in your last speech.

—Of course, that is right across Australia. Let us contrast that with what New South Wales is spending. Would the parliamentary secretary like to give us the figure for what New South Wales is spending? It is above that; it is more than $80 million over one year. We quote figures over one year; we do not follow the dishonest practice of quoting things over several years.

PARA.TAB: Add to that the number of farmers who are being affected: 64,000 farmers in New South Wales. How many of them are getting this aid? Would the parliamentary secretary like to give us the figure? It is actually 1,800—grossly inadequate. Ninety-four per cent of all farmers in drought affected areas get nothing.

Does the parliamentary secretary want to tell us about small business? He could give us the figure on how much the government is spending on assisting small business. According to Yellow Pages Small Business Index, one-third of rural businesses are going to collapse after Christmas. The parliamentary secretary is amazingly quiet. Would he like to tell us how much the government is putting into small businesses? Nothing. It is absolutely zero, and the parliamentary secretary knows it. He would be well advised to sit over there and say very little, as he is doing now, and not point out to the people of Australia how inadequate the government's policies are.

Let me tell the parliamentary secretary this: the government is going to pay at the next election. Even if he has not realised it, most of the marginal seats happen to be in rural and regional Australia: seats like Richmond, Page, Paterson, Macarthur and Gilmore, just to name a few in New South Wales.

This policy that the government has had so far has been roundly condemned by the industry because its guidelines are far too tight. It leaves out areas in northern New South Wales totally: areas around Grafton and Kyogle, areas in the Upper Hunter, and areas around Mudgee. They have severe drought, but because they do not quite get to the figure of 24 out of 36 months they miss out totally. Yet the ecology of the coastal areas like the north coast is far more sensitive than that of inland New South Wales, so 24 months there without rain is far more devastating than it is inland, where the ecology is more acclimatised to a drier climate.

But the government's rule of thumb, across-the-board guidelines do not take any of this into account, and farm families are suffering desperately. They are relying on charity in the absence of any effective social welfare policy for people who have no income. The government will do this for the cities, but will not do it for the bush. Those people have to rely on charity to put money on the table, and that is a disgrace in Australia in the 1990s. It sounds more like the 1890s.

The Yellow Pages Small Business Index, as I mentioned before, said that it goes beyond the farm families, it goes to the business families. Take towns like Moree, for example. Moree relies on the cotton crop—a crop that has totally collapsed because of lack of water. What has also collapsed is the Moree economy: $5 million has been sucked out of it because of this. Usually, 300 people go into Moree at this time each year to harvest cotton. This year, no-one came. Why should they? There is nothing to harvest. So the money that those people generate is not going into the small businesses. What is the government doing to help those people? Absolutely nothing—and that story is repeated right across rural Australia, particularly rural New South Wales and Queensland. The Keating government has not delivered one cent to small businesses in drought relief. Let us hope that in the new package that is coming out it does something about that aspect, as the New South Wales coalition government has.

The New South Wales drought coordinator, Geoff File, has confirmed the point that I made earlier: that the farmhand money and other charity funds are going to dry up before Christmas. Some 5,300 families have received money from farmhand. What are they going to do after Christmas? They are not going to have any money at all; and the government is not going to provide them any unless, in its package today, it rather belatedly does something about this matter.

The Smith Family plans to step into the breach with an appeal called `Christmas to the Bush', and hopes to raise another $4 million. As we know, though, there is not a bottomless pit of charitable money. If the Smith Family is raising $4 million for the bush because the government is not putting funds in, that is obviously going to have a ricochet effect through urban Australia as well. The charity funds that are raised there are going to be less because the charities are forced to respond to this government's lack of response to a crisis in the bush.

Senator Collins has promised to put in a revised package to cabinet today. Let me suggest what it should include. It should include wider exceptional circumstances provisions for those areas that are left out of this 24 out of 36 months criteria. A priority must be put on spending on drought assistance over other programs. There should be a vastly improved income equalisation deposit scheme with significant tax advantages to help farmers drought proof their properties. If this is done, it will reverse the disastrous 1992 drought policy which encouraged people to put things away for tough days. That was the policy in 1992 actually during the drought. It is a bit hard to start putting things aside for a drought when people are in the middle of it. Of course, the policy has been totally inappropriate for current circumstances in the first part of the 1990s and the government should urgently revise and reverse that. Tax breaks also need to be put on farm infrastructure for fodder, storage and dams to assist in bad times. People in the bush are waiting in hope today for these new announcements from the federal government. We hope this time something effective might be done.

In the meantime in New South Wales, the Fahey coalition government is doing something effective. It has already committed $116 million—that is now the cumulative total—on this drought aid compared to the government's figure of $82 million, if we annualise it. Let us compare apples with apples here.

Why has the ALP government not put more money into drought aid? The New South Wales Deputy Premier, Ian Armstrong, says that New South Wales is really appealing for a widening of the exceptional circumstances criteria with this government. However, he says that it is getting nowhere with the federal ALP government. I can share his frustration with the inaction of this minister. We cannot get any sensible answers out of him in the Senate in question time. That is why we have got to keep asking ourselves questions.

In contrast, I outline what the New South Wales government is doing. It has committed to provide financial assistance to farmers to plant next seasons cereal crops. New South Wales will participate in the western division of New South Wales drought recovery package that will allocate $15 million to this devastated region. In answer to a question from his own side, Senator Collins in the Senate in the previous sitting week tried to draw some sort of distinction between the way in which New South Wales and Queensland were treating this money. There are differences at the margin, that is true, but the reality on the ground in terms of the take-up rate is virtually indistinguishable. On many occasions, the minister takes one little kernel of truth, blows it right out and tries to build a big story out of it, when 99 per cent of what he says is nonsense. He did this again in the Senate last week.

The $5 million for small business that New South Wales is providing to drought areas has now been taken up with unbelievable demand. This is something that desperately needs to be put in the government's package today, I would suggest, because the New South Wales government, with its limited resources, cannot carry everything. There is still no federal government response to match this sort of money for the small business people. They are really the forgotten victims of this drought, as I pointed out was the case in Moree. The New South Wales government is acting and its efforts are well regarded. The rural community, small business and farm families await effective action from this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer to Mr Keating's involvement in the policy bungle at Sydney airport. I ask: is it a fact that, as claimed by Laurie Oakes in this week's Bulletin, the `east-west runway was supposed to continue operating, but it was Keating who killed that idea, too, and ensured that all planes operated on the north-south axis'? As it is now clear that initial expert advice to government was that the east-west runway could continue to operate with all flights on and off the third runway going south, will the minister tell us who has lied by claiming it was closed for safety reasons? Has the CAA been corrupted or compromised by this government and this Prime Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The continual campaign of utter deceit that is being run on this issue is astonishing. I took the trouble of accessing Mr Marks's letter. This is the sole information on which the opposition is relying for its newly invented policy of supporting the third runway whilst continuing to support the continued use of the east-west runway—a piece of nonsense, as any reference to the EIS on this third runway will demonstrate.

PARA.TAB: It has been clear from day one that there would be a diminished use of the east-west runway as soon as the second parallel runway was commissioned. It was canvassed in the calculation of the EIS, which is fairly accurate, that there would be a net reduction in the number of people seriously affected by noise because it would benefit those who were living on the east and west of the airport, which is exactly what has happened. I ask those opposite to tell me how we can accomplish that end without diminishing the use of the east-west runway. It is a logical nonsense. The entire opposition campaign is based on a letter from Mr Marks that was written, I think, last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order.
—What is the point of order?

—The point of order is that this answer has nothing to do with the question. The question had nothing to do with Mr Marks; it had nothing to do with a motivation for a campaign; it had nothing to do with our policy on the east-west runway. It simply asked whether Mr Keating was the one who wanted the north-south runways to be used at both ends. The minister has read Laurie Oakes's article as well as we have. He is able to answer that question, and he is choosing not to do so. Mr President, you have heard enough by way of non-answer to be able to direct the minister to answer the question.
—There is no point of order.
—On the point of order: the answer to the question was—
—He said there was no point of order.
—There was no point of order? Fine.
—I already said there was no point of order.
—I have here the letter from Mr Marks. It is about time it was tabled because it is this letter, as the Hansard record will demonstrate, that is at the core of the opposition's claims—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order.
—I will table it anyway.

—Obviously the minister has a piece of paper—he is quite welcome to table it if he wishes—that has nothing whatsoever to do with my question. My question related to a quote from Laurie Oakes in this week's Bulletin that said that the idea to kill off the east-west runway was Mr Keating's. Is that right or wrong?
—I have indicated there is no point of order along those lines. The answer so far has been relevant.

—The answer is no, it was not, which is what I have said all week. The opposition is basing its claim that the east-west runway can continue to operate—and, therefore, this is a political decision—on the basis of a letter written by Mr Marks which Senator Parer has quoted from three or four times without producing. As I suspected, the letter—and I will table it—simply states in response to a question on the technical aspects of the paper:

PARA.TAB: The suggested preferred runway usage outlined in your paper is a workable method of processing air traffic.

ANSWER.PARA: That is all it says. As I pointed out before, there is a world of difference a mile wide between saying that a runway system is workable and saying that it is the safest system. Any runway system can be made workable if one wants to slow down the frequencies of the aircraft and give aircraft time to clear each other. Simultaneous operations can be made workable.

PARA.TAB: This statement of Mr Marks on which Senator Parer rests his entire case is entirely consistent with the CAA's advice delivered to a meeting of aviation representatives on 24 November; that is, that the decision to do this was an operational decision taken by the Civil Aviation Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on! You know that is wrong.

—Senator Parer should check with BASI. International practice has proven that a parallel runway operation is safer than a cross-runway simultaneous operation. It is totally consistent with the sole piece of so-called evidence that the opposition is running around with in which all Mr Marks says is, rightly, that it is workable—that is, you can make it work if you want to.
—`If you want to.'
—Correct!
—It is a stupid idea, anyway.
—It is still a stupid idea, as Senator McMullan says, in safety terms. It is safer to do it the way we are doing it. (Time expired)

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Was it the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, who was primarily responsible for closing off the east-west runway from normal operations or is Laurie Oakes lying?

—I have already said no. Senator Parer should have a look at the record of what the CAA said and talk to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation if he wants a second opinion. I have had enough briefings on the dangers of simultaneous operations over the years and the risks posed by them. This is cute coming from an opposition that has been running on a campaign of increased safety for aviation for the last 12 months. Now it wants to erode it; now it wants to white-ant it because it is a convenient political argument to run.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order, and it is simply one of relevance. I asked a very simple, short question: was the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, primarily responsible or is Laurie Oakes lying in his article today? Who is responsible?
—You clearly got an answer to that question.

—For the third time, the answer to the question is no. I will put it on the record again that a parallel runway operation is safer than a cross-runway simultaneous operation. If Senator Parer wants to confirm that, he should talk not to the Civil Aviation Authority but to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, which has to clean up the mess afterwards.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. We have at long last got a partial answer. It is very important, therefore, so that there is no confusion, to identify precisely which part of the two questions Senator Collins was saying no to. Was he saying that Mr Keating was not responsible or that Laurie Oakes was not lying? It is very easy for him to clarify that. I ask you to direct him to be relevant in answering each of those two questions.
—Mr President, on the point of order: this point of order that really asks a third supplementary question—
—No, it doesn't.

—Yes, it does. Senator Alston has rephrased Senator Parer's question simply so he can interrupt Senator Collins. We are all aware of this new technique that some brilliant tactics committee has come up with to interrupt every answer with a point of order. It is now nine minutes past two and we are still on the first question because of all these foolish interruptions from those opposite. What Senator Alston raised was in no way a point of order and should be totally ruled out.
—It was not a point of order, but the minister has only a second to go, in any case.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I understand that the Australian government has taken the decision to sign the Energy Charter Treaty. Can the minister advise what advantages will flow to Australia as a signatory to this treaty and, in particular, what the implications are for Australian industry?

—My colleague Senator Collins and I have issued a statement confirming that the Australian government has taken the decision to sign the Energy Charter Treaty. We will be signing it at a signing ceremony to be held in Lisbon on 16 and 17 December. The treaty will promote a fairer and more open playing field for our exporters of energy products by extending GATT rights and obligations to the countries of the former Soviet Union. It will provide much more predictable, transparent and secure opportunities for Australian investment interests in the signatory countries. It also provides an investment promotion and protection agreement with respect to the energy sectors of the countries of the former Soviet Union, which we would not otherwise have had.

PARA.TAB: The history of this negotiation is very interesting and illuminating. It began as a European initiative. Australia had some concerns that if it continued in that manner it might have developed into a preferential arrangement that discriminated against Australia's interests.
