If we had the silly policy of the opposition whereby we had hidden under a rock and not gotten involved in international treaty negotiations in case somebody might scare us, there would have been a European agreement and Australia would have missed out, our industry would have been disadvantaged and jobs would have been at jeopardy in Australia. The significant potential benefits from this treaty would never have emerged. I am happy to say, as a result of our active intervention and participation, the treaty is now being negotiated as a multilateral instrument.
Senator Alston and Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Alston and Senator Faulkner, I cannot hear what is being said.

—And you are missing a treat, Mr President. The treaty has now been negotiated as a multilateral instrument. It has been a significant benefit strongly supported by Australian industry, which has urged us to sign this treaty and which has complimented us on the consultative process which has led to this outcome. The industry has complimented us on this process which has taken place over the last couple of years. Industry associations such as AMIC, the Business Council, the coal industry and the companies involved have strongly supported the outcome and the process. I might also say, just to reiterate, that had we had the opposition's silly policy and hidden away from this, we would not have achieved these significant benefits for Australian industry.
—That is a lie.
—Senator Kemp!
—You are lying.
—Senator Kemp!
—The opposition would have been hiding under a rock, afraid to enter into negotiations, and we would never have achieved the benefit that the Energy Charter Treaty potentially provides for Australia.

PARA.TAB: The one final piece of advice that I wish to give the Senate is that the provisional application and ratification of this treaty will not come into effect until Russia, or at least one other major energy-rich country of the former Soviet Union, applies the treaty because that is where the concrete benefits to us will flow—they will flow from the benefit in either Russia or somewhere such as Kazakhstan, one of the energy-rich countries of the former Soviet Union.

This is a very good example of how multilateral negotiations and treaties can advance Australia's interests. It complements in a timely way the outcome of the Uruguay Round. It has, apart from significant benefits for Australia, significant consequential benefits in terms of sound economic growth in the countries of the former Soviet Union which, while not of such direct benefit to Australia, are important for global security and economic growth from which Australia is a beneficiary as is the rest of the international community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. During Senator McMullan's very interesting answer to that question, several times Senator Kemp interjected `That's a lie. You're lying,' et cetera. Mr President, you called him to order, but that expression by Senator Kemp is unparliamentary and he should be required to withdraw it.
—I was aware of it and, in the interests of getting question time through, I asked him to stop but I did not pick it up. I would ask you now to withdraw that, Senator Kemp.
—The senator was debating the point—
—Order! I ask you to withdraw unconditionally, Senator Kemp.
—I withdraw.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask: what are the inflation implications for Australia of the very high percentage growth of money supply in this country—a figure that leads that of most comparable countries?
—I do not have to hand a brief on that question. I will take it on board and refer it to the Treasurer.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —This question calls for quite a detailed exposition and, in four minutes, I do not have time to make it. Obviously, quite clearly, it is one that is directed to the Treasurer.

PARA.TAB: The central plank of the government's economic policy is to keep inflation low. We have been experiencing a period of high economic growth, to the level of 6.4 per cent for the year, but inflation remains extremely low at below two per cent. Indeed, we are going through one of the lowest periods of inflation in Australia's history. As well, we are probably at the lowest level of inflation of any country in the world at the present time; certainly, the lowest level of inflation of countries within the OECD.

All the government's settings in the economy are geared to making sure that the inflation stick, now that it has been broken, remains broken. All our settings in terms of decentralisation of wage fixing to workplace agreements and all our settings related to the broad macro inputs of the economy and the management of the economy are aimed at achieving that outcome. If this question is directed at seeing whether we have lost the discipline, I assure Senator Watson that that is not true. We have not, and we continue to ensure that inflation will remain low.

I might say as well that I have had the opportunity over the last few days to meet a number of leading businessmen from around the world. Senator McMullan is holding a very successful national trade and investment outlook conference. As a consequence, a number of business delegations are coming to Australia to attend that conference. All of them comment very favourably on Australia's economic performance. It would indeed be useful for members of this Senate to hear the views of the world business community when it comes to the growth of this economy, the increase in employment that we see is coming through, the very low level of inflation that we are experiencing, the responsible economic management of the government and the recognition of what is central to this question from Senator Watson, which is the need to keep inflation low.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Inflation in the past has, not surprising, been low, given that the economy is just emerging from the recession that the Prime Minister said we had to have. Given that money supply growth, which is amongst the highest in the OECD countries, is a very fair weather indication of future inflation, what action does the government intend to take to check inflation growth, recognising that we are perhaps leading the world in terms of the percentage of money supply growth?
—Cut it out. It is growing at six per cent.
—It would have been useful if Senator Watson had bothered to ask initially the real question that he wanted to ask. What Senator McMullan just said is worth repeating.
—Oh!
—It is worth repeating. Senator Hill may not want to hear the answer, but he is right.
—This is your big moment. Have a go.

—What does Senator Hill want to know? He ought to have asked the question. Why did he not have the courage to get up and ask it? We are experiencing one of the highest growth levels of any developed economy in the world. As a consequence, one would expect some implication for the other figures in the economy.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. The minister would be aware of recent media comment concerning Australia's attractiveness as an investment destination. Can he inform the Senate how Australia rates as an investment destination and what level of interest there is from the international investment community in investing in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Christopher Evans for that question because he is, I know, always interested in finding out what are the industry developments going on in the Australian economy. This morning I met a number of business delegates at a breakfast in Melbourne for the national trade investment outlook conference, a very successful conference which Senator McMullan is hosting and which focuses world attention on Australia as an investment location.

PARA.TAB: I had the pleasure of launching on behalf of the Australian government a booklet entitled Australia: your strategic investment location. I am pleased to table this publication for reference by honourable senators. Attending the launch today were business people from France, China, Saudi Arabia, Korea, Thailand, India, Japan, Vietnam and a range of other countries, and also many leading figures in the Australian business community.

In launching the promotion booklet entitled Australia: your strategic investment location, I was able to cite that it is not just the Australian government that is out there making a case for Australia as a site for international investment. For example, a major international accounting firm, Price Waterhouse, is now advising its clients that Australia is just such a location. In a most recent brochure it has said of Australia:

ANSWER.PARA: Australia's comparative cost advantage in the region is expected to continue to grow over time. It will continue to be one of the major incentives for multinational groups to establish regional functions in Australia.

As to that part of the question which asks, `How well does Australia stack up as a location for investment?' I can say that salary costs for qualified professional executives in this country are 59 per cent more competitive than in Singapore and 50 per cent more competitive than in Hong Kong. Australian universities and colleges turn out three times more engineers than Hong Kong and Singapore combined, six times the scientists and 10 times the economists and business management graduates.

PARA.TAB: The cost of locating in Australia is highly competitive, with a typical expatriate package in Australia costing 50 per cent less than in Singapore or Hong Kong. Office space in this country is up to half the cost in Singapore and one-third the cost in Hong Kong. Our world-class telecommunications infrastructure also gives us significant cost and quality advantages. Our lifestyle, original science and the availability of a pool of multilingual professionals competent in all of the Asian and European languages also are key attractions. People are surprised to learn that Australia has a competitive advantage in the breadth of Asian languages and Asian language support over both Singapore and Hong Kong.

Part of what international investors are finding compelling about Australia is the advantages that our integration with the fast growing Asia-Pacific economies gives us as a base for regional operations, and part of what influences their commercial decisions is the strength of our own economy. At 6.4 per cent a year, we now enjoy probably the fastest growth rate among the advanced industrialised economies. In the 12 months to September, quarterly productivity has grown by four per cent in this country; employment by 3.4 per cent; real household disposable income by 3.9 per cent; and inflation is at a low level of 1.1 per cent over that period. So we have strong growth of output, business investment, employment, productivity, real household disposable income and savings—all with low inflation.

This is one of the reasons why over the last year or so over 90 international companies have chosen Australia as a base for regional headquarters for the whole of the Asia-Pacific, and one of the reasons why there is great investor interest in this nation. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is he aware that the retiring chairman of the Murray-Darling Basin Commission asserts that the federal and state governments are doing far too little to address degradation, salinity and other major problems such as algal bloom in the Murray-Darling Basin? Does the minister agree with the forecasts that up to 1.3 million hectares of prime irrigation farmland will be salinised or waterlogged within 45 years? Finally, can the minister explain why there has not yet been a response tabled by the government to the December 1993 report from the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts on water resources and toxic algae?

—I am aware of Noel Fitzpatrick's remarks. I am also aware of the level of effort that is being directed at the problems that Senator Lees referred to. It should be pointed out that the Murray-Darling Basin Commission as it currently exists is a joint Commonwealth-state program, as it has to be. The states of Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia are inextricably linked in any proposal that deals with that area of Australia which is our most productive, but which also has some major problems associated with it. It is a joint initiative.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth contributes in the order of $20 million a year to the initiatives and that is matched by state expenditure. The total budget is around $70 million per year. Nationally, through the national landcare program, the Commonwealth contributes $105 million through the primary industries and energy portfolio alone to address landcare issues.

There are significant problems in the MDB that need to be addressed, but I also point out that resource degradation in Australia is not a problem confined to the basin. I have to say, regrettably, that one aspect of this drought in some areas of Australia is the feeling that all the problems currently being experienced by farmers are caused by the drought. Unfortunately, many of those problems are simply exacerbated by the drought.

I have seen just recently extensive areas where there is massive environmental damage. A lot of that has been caused by previous overstocking, block sizes being too small and so on, and this has been exacerbated by conditions that could not be described as exceptional in drought terms. But, because of the underlying problems, the effect of those factors has been massive.

There is a major national problem—I know Senator Lees is well aware of this—similar to the problems that are in the Murray-Darling Basin Commission. Competition for funds in the forthcoming federal budget will be severe. Any proposals for an expansion of funding made by the MDB Commission would need to make a strong case as to why additional resources should not be directed, for example, into the national landcare program or other national priorities. I point out that any funding proposals would have to have the support of the states, which are partners in every sense in the Murray-Darling Basin Commission.

The commission in its current form—this is relative to the last part of Senator Lees's question—has existed only since 1988. There were previous Darling River commissions and Murray River commissions, but the current joint attempt by the states and the Commonwealth to deal with the problems that Senator Lees talked about has, regrettably, been in place only since 1988. I do not think there is any doubt that it should have been established decades ago. It was this government that provided the leadership that was necessary to get it going.

The issue of rising water tables is a real problem. But it is a problem that has been identified. As to the problem Senator Lees mentioned about the estimate of the number of hectares, that is based on the assumption that nothing is done to prevent it. Those figures—I am sure I am correct about this; but I will check it later—were taken from a 1990 report which was actually used as the basis for the drainage programs that have since been established. In fact, Mr Fitzpatrick was making that point. That is a worst case scenario if nothing is done.

TALK.START.PARA: —If nothing at all is done.

—No. I think it was based on 1990 data, but I will check that. Since then, extensive community drainage programs and other drainage programs have been put into place to deal with the problem. But, of course, that kind of work has to be accelerated. As to the last part of Senator Lees's question, I have signed off a government response to that report. The only thing preventing it from being tabled, which it will be shortly, is the mechanical problem of having it printed and so on.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I certainly understand that the Murray-Darling Basin Commission is a joint project with the states. However, section 100 of the constitution clearly shows that it is the Commonwealth's responsibility to guarantee water quality and flow to South Australia. Therefore, if there is an algal bloom this year in South Australia's section of the River Murray, as 97 per cent of the nutrients are already in the river when it goes past Renmark, surely the minister would accept that it is the Commonwealth's responsibility. Therefore, far more resources than are now being put in to the Murray-Darling Basin Commission—as well as to Landcare and other sources—are needed to ensure that both water quality, in terms of nutrient levels, and salinity are far better than they are now.

—I wish it was as neat as that and that we could attribute the blame for particular algal blooms to one bit of the river. We cannot do that. I point out to Senator Lees that, as a direct result of the drought alone, no water has passed through the mouth of the Murray River for three months. The river mouth is progressively closing. If no further significant rain is received in Australia—and it is not looking very hopeful at the moment—during the course of this summer, the mouth of the Murray is expected to close completely. There is no doubt that this exacerbates the problems.

PARA.TAB: The system that drains into that system—as Senator Lees knows—is extensive; and it is what is put into the remainder of that drainage system that impacts on algal blooms, wherever they occur. One of the contributing causes to algal blooms is the lack of sufficient flow in the river. There is no doubt that the drought has severely exacerbated that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs. Australia is a country noted for its multiculturalism. Has any research and, if so, what research been done to find out whether there is any way this attribute can be employed to enhance its overseas trade?

—This is the sort of question that one could take most of question time to answer. However, I will just answer it in the context of the theme that Senator Cook was talking about in his answer to a question. The question is timely in the context of the national trade and investment outlook conference that Senator McMullan has been involved with and the theme of that conference, which is creating networks for global business.

PARA.TAB: With the increasing globalisation of Australian business, with some 90 per cent of our exports now going to non-English speaking countries, Australia needs to look at how we can best maximise our opportunities. In that context, we have an enormous resource—that is, our cultural diversity—and the government is committed to fully exploring and exploiting this resource. The Prime Minister, speaking at the conference this morning, made a point of saying that the government is implementing strategies to make productive economic use of this particular resource and to make productive diversity integral to our trade and investment strategies.

The starting point is very much that there is not one country in the world with which we wish to trade whose language and culture we do not have living within our own community. For this reason, in the context of making productive diversity an integral part of our trade and investment strategies, the government has commissioned the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry to conduct the first comprehensive study of our ethnic chambers of commerce and other business bilateral associations.

The study was funded by Senator Cook's department and the Office of Multicultural Affairs. It set out to identify the extent of the resource. It also set out to identify the potential for this resource in terms of networking and information sharing with mainstream business organisations. Senator Cook and I were able to launch that report this morning to coincide with the conference.

It is interesting to look at the outcomes of that research study conducted by the ACCI. The database we launched this morning is the first database of Australian bilateral associations to be launched in this country. The study found that Australia has a wealth of more than 170 bilateral associations, covering some 58 countries. Most of them are state based. Some 40 or so are in New South Wales. I think there are 36 in South Australia; 26 in Victoria; 22 in Western Australia; at least 6 in Queensland; and three in both Tasmania and the ACT.

As well as that, it should also be recognised that these associations are open associations between those overseas-born experienced people with backgrounds in both the culture and the language of countries in which they are interested and those in the Australian community who have a mutual interest with the former category in expanding trade between Australia and other countries.

In that context also, the study found that there is not one region in the world with which we wish to do trade that is not covered by these bilateral associations. Sixty-three of them relate to the Asia-Pacific region; 76 to Europe; 16 to the Middle East and Africa; and 17 to the Americas.

What we find in this database, in the study, is a total reflection of the benefits and of the sources of our migration program. The number of associations and the diversity of the regions they cover reflect both the source countries of our migration program and the growing commercial ties between those countries as major partners with Australia.

The database is not a one-off. It builds on an ongoing agenda—an agenda which the government is committed to pursuing with the ACCI and with other peak industry organisations. We are heavily involved with the ACCI, with the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, with Austrade, and with major banks in regularly staging business matching functions and linking business migrants with overseas-born entrepreneurs with potential exports.

The conclusion, basically, is that we have in this country enormous cultural productive diversity. It is something the government is committed to exploring and exploiting in the interests of Australia's economic future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, my question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Amendments to the Family Law Act in 1991 made provision for alternative dispute resolution and, in particular, for court referred and private arbitration. However, this arbitration must be carried out by an approved arbitrator. Nothing has been done since 1991 to facilitate the necessary regulations. The question is: what possible reason can the minister offer for this delay? The legislation was passed in 1991; it is now near the end of 1994 and nothing has been done. Does this inaction on the Attorney-General's part not show that his recent claims to wanting to increase access to justice are more about getting publicity for himself and his government than they are about actually doing the work of increasing access to justice—doing the hard work that gives family law litigants an opportunity to get a fairer deal? What possible explanation can the minister offer for this three to four year delay?

—I will pass on that specific question to the Attorney-General. I will provide Senator Vanstone with an answer to both that question and whatever supplementary question she may raise in respect of it.

PARA.TAB: In terms of access to justice, let me say to the honourable senator that the government, particularly the Attorney-General, has a strong commitment to expanding access to justice and making access to our legal system more open to all people, including, of course, those who have major disadvantages because of their financial status, their gender and language problems. That is a target, that is a project, that the Attorney-General is very heavily committed to. Senator Vanstone already knows that this will form the basis of an access to justice statement from the government some time early next year.

That commitment, that statement, will build on a long history of initiatives by this side of the parliament to ensure access to justice. Whether it is through government funded tribunals, whether it is through bodies such as HREOC, whether it is through access to our legal system and mechanisms to enhance that, whether it is through assistance, for instance, through legal aid, the government has an ongoing commitment. It is a commitment which will be continued and will be reflected very much in the statement to be delivered next year.

As I said at the start of my answer, I do not have a brief on the 1991 initiative to which Senator Vanstone referred. I am sure Senator Vanstone would not have expected me to have a brief on it. That is probably why she raised the question. If she thought I had a brief on it, she would not have raised it. I will send it off to the Attorney-General with, as I say, whatever supplementary question the honourable senator might seek to ask.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Surprisingly, I thought the minister might be competent enough to have a brief since, in the Australian Lawyer of November 1994, the now President of the Australian Law Council wrote an article entitled `Let's move on arbitration'. I thought even the Attorney-General's Department might have been smart enough to give the minister a brief on this and that he might have an answer. But in the answer he tried to give, he said that his government has a commitment. We are very pleased on this side that the Attorney-General has picked up the efforts of the standing committee. That committee operated on a bipartisan basis. What we want to know is: when is he actually going to do something instead of having seminars and announcements, leaking his cabinet's submissions—making a big Joe of himself. This is something he could have done three to four years ago. The simple question we want answered is: when is it going to be done and what is the explanation for its not having been done?

—Let me say at the start that this is probably a thing that Mr Lavarch would have liked to have done three or four years ago. He could only have done if he was in the ministry three or four years ago, but he was not. But I am sure he would have liked to have done it.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, in terms of commitment to justice, it was not our side of parliament that came in before the last election with a commitment to abolishing access to justice through the Fightback package. It is not our government that has a commitment to reducing public expenditure by $11.7 billion, as the shadow Treasurer has. Senator Vanstone cannot have her cake and eat it, though she would very much like to. The reality is that we cannot parade in the community, as Mr Costello does, wanting to slash $11.7 billion off public spending and have the sorts of programs that those opposite parade about. They cannot have their cake and eat it, and they know it.

In terms of access to justice, our definition of access to justice is not access to justice for the lawyers. Our definition of access to justice is having legislation in place to protect people and assist people; it is having mechanisms in place for litigants as well. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I draw the minister's attention to recent comments of the Salvation Army that the demand for its services is up by 53 per cent this year and that the Salvation Army, along with other welfare agencies, expects demand over this Christmas period to be the highest on record. Firstly, how many people does the government expect to be serving a social security penalty deferment period over Christmas? Secondly, does the government recognise that withholding a person's income support forces that person into a life of abject poverty? Thirdly, as it is likely that the welfare agencies will not be able to fully cope with demand for their services over Christmas, where else can these people go for assistance?

—I thank Senator Woodley for this question. I can tell him that it is not possible to be sure about the numbers, particularly in advance, of how many people might indeed be affected by a deferment period during Christmas. The latest figures that I have been provided with show that in the month of September there were 2,824 penalties imposed for administrative and activity test breaches. I am not sure what conclusion one could draw from that but that is a figure that might help Senator Woodley.

PARA.TAB: In answer to the second question of whether the government recognises that withholding a person's income support forces a person into a life of abject poverty, that is not quite an accurate conclusion. The DSS or CES do not arbitrarily impose a deferment period for either administrative or activity test breaches. In the case of activity test breaches, a person is interviewed to determine the reason for the failure of the activity test before the breach and before the deferment period is imposed. When the person can provide a reasonable explanation no breach is imposed.

A breach may also be imposed if people do not respond to attempts by the departments to contact them and in such instances they are given clear notice that they are required to contact and so on. So the concern is much as we were discussing this morning in a slightly different context, namely, balancing justice with mercy, if I could put it like that. We do make the penalties quite clear in the legislation and what people who offend or break those legislative requirements will suffer by way of penalty. Both the DSS and the CES are concerned that the deferment penalties are never placed by accident or for an insufficient reason and, again, if there is any reasonable explanation then, of course, no breach is imposed.

In answer to the third question of where else people can go if they are in fact found to be in breach and therefore lose their income, it is important to know that the poverty or difficult circumstances people might find themselves in can mean that the CES or DSS manager could authorise continuation of the payment for a period, particularly pending any review of the decision if there was a breach. It is also important to note that the majority of breaches are for voluntary unemployment or through misconduct at work and being put out of employment. Some 2,000 of the figure of 2,800 for September that I gave were for those sorts of reasons.

Even though a person can be disqualified from a jobsearch or a newstart allowance, it does not preclude the person or the person's partner from being able to claim other forms of income support such as family payments. And the partner of a disqualified person may also claim a payment in his or her own right, such as special benefit.

The point Senator Woodley raises is a very difficult matter of judgment. If people do offend against the requirements of social security or the employment provisions that are in place, the government cannot disregard those breaches. It must properly go through the process with as much concern and care for those people as possible. But, in the end, if one is confronting a breach then, clearly, the penalty must be addressed. On the other hand, one does not want to willy-nilly throw families into poverty. There are other payments that can assist. There is also the process of trying to make sure every reasonable step is continued to enable people to continue their payment.

I take Senator Woodley's point very much that when times are tough we do not want to make it tougher for people. At the same time, we do not want to ignore people who are flouting the law when so many other people are doing their best to comply with it. It is a matter of tempering justice with mercy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The minister would be aware that the price of Australian hard wheat—AH1—fell on Monday by $17 per tonne, which follows other price reductions of about $10 per tonne in recent weeks and another $4 in the last 24 hours. Given the short supply of wheat at present, what explanation does the minister have for such a drop? Is the minister aware of the concerns of some wheat growers that they believe the Wheat Board is not placing their interest first? Does the minister agree that the first responsibility of the Australian Wheat Board is, and must be, to its growers?

—Interestingly enough, I was asked an identical question at a meeting of bankers which I addressed in Sydney at 7 o'clock this morning. The answer is very simple. It needs to be said also that the drop in wheat prices may be of concern to the wheat growers but it has been greatly welcomed by the people buying it to feed their stock. The wheat harvest is well advanced. Quality and protein levels are above average for the bulk of the wheat being delivered to receival points. One of the by-products of the lack of rain is that it has actually increased the protein levels in some wheat.

PARA.TAB: Current indications are for a reasonable summer sorghum crop in New South Wales and Queensland of about a million tonnes. ABARE's next crop report is due out next week. Cash prices for prime hard and hard wheats have been volatile, peaking at about $350 a tonne in Queensland in October. They have fallen significantly over recent weeks as most domestic millers in Australia have covered their immediate needs for high protein.

International wheat prices have eased and the prospect of imports—and this is an important factor which it has been interesting to follow over the last four or five weeks—of milling wheats has brought the markets back towards import parity. In fact, after the government made it absolutely clear very publicly that we would be approving, if necessary, significant imports of overseas grain once the price went above import parity, within two weeks the price had started to ease significantly.

Growers with supplies of prime hard and hard wheats, including in the Tamworth district, still have the option of sales for cash or into the AWB pools. The Australian Wheat Board advised me today that estimated prime hard pool returns have remained at about their current level of $310 a tonne on an FOB delivered port basis for at least the last month. Equivalent cash prices are currently within $10 a tonne of the pool price. The recent substantial movements in cash prices reflect the volatility of the high protein wheat market around harvest time. It needs to be recognised that the Australian Wheat Board is only one of a number of buyers that are currently buying wheat in a deregulated wheat market in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. What is the import parity price?
—I do not know the exact price today.
—Do you have any idea?

—I have just said that it is continuing to fall. It is in the high two-hundreds or the low three-hundreds. It is continuing to decline on a daily basis. I will provide information—I do get daily briefings on it—as to the exact price, because I want to give Senator Brownhill the exact price. But the point needs to be made again that the government deliberately announced that we would process supplies of overseas wheat if necessary when the price of Australian wheat rose significantly above that import parity price. I am pleased to say that it has had the desired effect of easing those prices significantly.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the decision due to be handed down in Turkey tomorrow in the trials of the eight Kurdish members of parliament charged with treason for alleged ties with the Kurdistan Workers Party. I ask: does the government agree with concern expressed by the United States that they have been stripped of their parliamentary immunity and are facing the death penalty for expressing their own thoughts? Is the government concerned about the trials and their implications for democracy and freedom of expression in Turkey?

—The Australian government does have a concern about the suspension of parliamentary immunity of Kurdish members of the Turkish Grand National Assembly. We are also concerned that they do face the death penalty. This is based, of course, on our resolute opposition to capital punishment in all circumstances in all countries. The only ground for optimism in this respect is that the death penalty has not been carried out in Turkey for some 10 years. We hope this will not be the occasion for that policy to change.

PARA.TAB: The Australian ambassador in Ankara has made written representations to the Turkish ministry of foreign affairs about the plight of the parliamentarians. In response to these representations, he was called into the Turkish foreign ministry earlier this year, at which time he, the ambassador, again expressed the Australian government's hope that the parliamentarians would soon be released; and reiterated our concern that due process be followed and the democratic rights of parliamentarians be accepted. Our ambassador was advised in response to these representations that the prosecutor, in seeking to lay charges against the parliamentarians, took into account a substantial body of evidence linking them to the terrorist activities of the PKK. We do not know whether that is true or not, but that is what the Turkish government's position has been.

While acknowledging that the PKK itself is a terrorist organisation and engaged in thoroughly indefensible actions, we do and have continued to urge the Turkish government to respect the human rights of Kurds in Turkey. On quite a number of occasions I have personally raised the issue with the former foreign minister, Hikmet Cetin, who is himself of Kurdish origin. As I said in the Senate on 15 November, the Australian government strongly believes that it would be desirable for the rights of Kurds within Turkey and elsewhere in the region to be recognised and protected.

An Australian parliamentary delegation raised its concerns for the former deputies with the President and other members of the Turkish Grand National Assembly when it visited Turkey in March this year. The delegation explored the need, appropriately, to ensure freedom of expression for parliamentarians worldwide, ensuring that contrary views could be expressed while, of course, recognising that resort to violence in support of any cause is not acceptable.

On 2 October the Turkish government announced that the former deputies would be permitted to contest the upcoming by-elections and, if elected, would regain their parliamentary immunity. The Australian government is obviously monitoring this whole development with great interest. I have asked the Australian embassy in Ankara to continue to monitor the situation of the parliamentarians while in detention to ensure that they are treated fairly and to monitor progress on the trial and what happens thereafter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. On 29 November this year the minister advised me at an estimates hearing that he would be happy to look at the appeal in the matter of Robert Bowra, who, I remind fellow senators, is an Australian imprisoned in the United Arab Emirates. The minister undertook to ascertain whether the department would change its view and intervene on his behalf. As I have now provided the minister's office with a copy of the notice of appeal and as further questions are raised as to the irregularity of process, I inquire as to whether the department has reviewed the situation and whether it is prepared to change its view in this matter. If not, why not?

—Nothing that I have seen and no further advice I have received in relation to the papers that Senator Ellison refers to have led me to change my view, to date anyway, that there is no role for the Australian government in so far as this particular aspect of the judicial process in the United Arab Emirates is concerned. We are concerned with the process that was involved in the bail question, and that continues to be the subject of representations. But, on the basis of the material that I have personally seen so far and, I repeat, about which I have received advice, there does not seem to be any basis on which a further appeal by the government at this stage would be either productive or appropriate. I obviously share the concern that the family has for Mr Bowra in this matter and would like to be able to do more, but we do have to respect proper process when it is operating in other countries, as, by and large, it seems to be in this instance.

PARA.TAB: There is one further piece of information that perhaps people are not fully aware of, and that is that the 12-month sentence will be calculated in accordance with the Arabic rather than the Western calendar. That means that the estimated date of release for Mr Bowra is 8 June next year, 1995. So the sentence is not quite as long as I think was originally anticipated.

If there is an injustice involved, of course, a sentence of incarceration for any period is too long, and I do not say that in any spirit of trade-off. It does seem that the matters that are the subject of appeal, at least on the advice that I have received and papers that I have personally looked at, are all matters that are best and most appropriately dealt with in the context of the appellate process itself.

I repeat: it simply would not be productive or appropriate, or perceived as appropriate, for us to intervene in this any more than we would think it an appropriate action for some other government to take when someone is properly before our courts and undergoing an appeal process on the basis of questions of law or contested matters of fact. It is different if something seems to have gone fundamentally wrong so far as process is concerned or there is some other reason—as, for example, in the Peng case in China, to which I referred in the estimates committee—to make one think that a government to government appeal would be appropriate.

In essentially ordinary legal cases of the kind that this essentially, for all its personal connotations, appears to be, there really are limitations on what any government can sensibly do in these situations. I do hope that will be understood by the parliamentarians who have been active on behalf of the Bowra family and, indeed, by the Bowra family themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the minister says he has taken advice in relation to whether the proper process has been observed. I ask the minister: what advice has he taken and has it been from Mr Bowra's lawyers? I might add that the process being complained of here is the improper laying of a charge and, furthermore, incorrect taking of evidence.

—I have taken advice from my own department and I have had my own reading of the papers. I think I have read all the papers Senator Ellison is referring to. It may be, and I will check this again, that there are some papers that arrived since our discussion in the estimates committee which I have not yet personally seen. But on the basis of what I have seen and the advice I have received from the department, which in turn has taken advice on the ground from legal representatives and its own soundings, the matters in issue in the appeal seem to be essentially the kinds of matters that are in issue in appeal processes anywhere in the world where these situations arise—namely, there are questions of law dealing with process and involved questions of fact—and the judgments that I have been able to make so far are questions that are appropriately addressed in that appellate process.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. I refer to the fact that the minister and the former minister for health have allowed the DHS&H officers to carry the can for the importation of the drug RU486. Is it not a fact that a month before that importation exemption was given the minister, in a note to the Therapeutic Goods Administration, said that any application for marketing approval for RU486 as an abortifacient should be treated in the same way as any other drug? Does that not give a message to the officers concerned? Does the minister not feel some responsibility as Minister for Family Services representing the Keating government for allowing this drug into the country against widespread opposition?

—Most of this has been very extensively canvassed in estimates. To put the record right, Senator Harradine is correct to refer to that letter. I did make that note, and there is no dispute about that. But, as Senator Harradine has not stressed, it goes to the application for marketing of a drug, which is quite different from the application to import a prohibited substance for the purposes of medical research. That distinction is understood by anybody who really sees the difference between the marketing of a drug already possibly even approved where the role of the TGA is quite different from the clinical research and continuing clinical research of a drug.

PARA.TAB: To suggest there is some impropriety here on my behalf is very wide of the mark. In fact, in suggesting that this drug be treated like any other was to make absolutely sure that I was not going to put myself or the government under the prospect of being pressured by anybody because we wanted to favour this drug one way or another. If I had written just such a minute, Senator Harradine would be the first one in here saying that we were playing favourites or deliberately opposing it. It was precisely because we wanted to be objective and proper that I said we should treat the marketing application of this drug like any other. Propriety is a very important consideration in my making that note.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the minister that we are talking about an abortifacient drug, which is a prohibited import for which there has to be an exemption. My supplementary question is: is the minister saying that in her view, on behalf of the government, she sees no difference between this life destroying drug and any life affirming drug? Does the minister see no difference in that? What message did that give to departmental officers, whom the minister has been letting carry the can, for making a decision contrary to policy and undertakings?

—Senator Harradine should never let a fact interfere with a preferred view. He should know that RU486 is used in this country for the treatment of other conditions besides termination of pregnancy before he actually rushes to say that it is an abortifacient. It is also used to treat Cushing's syndrome and tumours of the adrenal gland, to name just two.
—Very common conditions!
—They are not common conditions, but they are not abortifacient uses of this drug.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The minister is not being relevant. I referred to her minute. In her minute she talked about the application as an abortifacient, not for any other purposes. So she should stick to the truth.
—There is no point of order. It is a nice statement that Senator Harradine made.

—In fact, Senator Harradine has probably made the rest of my point for me. The important thing is that these medications are examined for the conditions that permission is being sought for their use in a proper scientific, dispassionate, objective way. If I had done other than what I had done, I think Senator Harradine would be in here accusing me, and much more properly, than for this wild claim. The fact is that RU486 is not only used in abortifacients. If Senator Harradine wants to say for when it is being used though, he should shape his question more accurately.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—During question time on Tuesday, 5 December, Senator Newman asked me about the status of a security clearance for the officer selected for the position of Defence trade commissioner in Jakarta. Austrade advises me that a security clearance for the officer concerned has been denied. However, an appeal has been lodged by the applicant with the Merit Protection Review Agency; therefore, it would be inappropriate for me to comment further.

PARA.TAB: I am also advised there is no link between this matter and the Fluitman case. The inability to deploy the Defence trade commissioner in Jakarta has delayed the full implementation of the program in Indonesia. At present the functions are being managed cooperatively between the Defence attache and Austrade officials at the post.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Parer this day, relating to the east-west runway at Sydney Airport.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole point of this debate over the past week has been whether the decision to close the east-west runway was, in fact, a decision of the Civil Aviation Authority, or any of its parties associated with that, or whether it was a policy decision. It is quite clear from all the evidence provided that it was a policy decision. What I referred to was an article in today's Bulletin by Laurie Oakes. Laurie Oakes made some very interesting remarks. Among other things, he said that `it was Keating who really swung it in the end.' He quoted Senator Ray. He then goes on further—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the decision to construct the third runway.

—Senator Collins interjects and says that it was the decision to construct the third runway. The construction of the third runway had tags put on it. For him to pretend otherwise is just plain dishonest. The article says:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Keating proposed that the new north-south runway be fully operational from both directions and the old east-west runway be virtually made redundant.
That is in the Oakes article. It continues:
The east-west runway was supposed to continue operating, but it was Keating who killed that idea, too, and ensured that all planes operated on the north-south axis.

When Senator Collins came in here today, I asked him that question. I think his answer was no. If that answer is no, he is saying that Laurie Oakes has made up the story. Everyone knows that that cannot be true, because those characters opposite feed him. I bet any money that Laurie Brereton said, `Let's get the heat off me and put it back on my old mate Keating. Let's put it on my mate.' Brereton was certainly opposed to it. But the decision was made by Prime Minister Keating. I will be interested in Senator Collins's views.

PARA.TAB: Another thing the minister said in his response was that he could not wait to get the famous Marks letter out. Mr Marks is an officer of the Civil Aviation Authority. He tried to get it out yesterday. It was not relevant to the question I asked yesterday or the question I asked today, but at last he got it on the table. He said that we had rested our whole case on that. I have news for Senator Collins. I have to say `Gotcha.'

I have a letter from Flight Transportation Associates to the Hon. Barry Cotter, the mayor of Marrickville, dated 28 November 1994. Flight Transportation Associates is a very well-known organisation. It is an offshoot of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. It completed a capacity study of the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport in February 1989 for the Federal Airports Corporation, or FAC. It points out in the letter that this sort of configuration—two parallel runways and a crossing runway—exists at Los Angeles International airport; La Guardia airport; Chicago O'Hare International airport, which is the busiest airport in the world; and Boston-Logan International airport, which all routinely conduct crossing operations. This includes the crossing of active runways by taxiing, arriving and departing aircraft.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct.
—Senator Collins says that that is correct. I am glad to hear him say that it is correct. The letter says that crossing-intersecting runway procedures are used both to enhance capacity—
—Of course it is correct. It is better not to do it.

—Senator Collins should listen to this. He should not be blind or cover up. This well-known organisation says that crossing-intersecting runway procedures are used both to enhance capacity and equitably distribute noise exposure among surrounding communities. That is what the whole thrust of the problem is in Sydney. All the noise has been taken away from people who bought into those areas and who have lived under east-west flight paths and sent north of Sydney airport. The government knows it, we know it and the people who live there know it.

PARA.TAB: Other remarks made by the authority are these:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we can say—
I would like Senator Collins to listen to this—

that internationally accepted standards exist for the simultaneous operation of crossing/intersecting runways, and, as such, these standards should allow for the safe and efficient operation of Kingsford-Smith International Airport as has been the case in the past.
I think our case rests there. Let us receive an honest response from the minister. I seek leave to incorporate this letter in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Flight Transportation Associates, Inc.
November 28, 1994
The Honourable Barry Cotter
Office of the Mayor
Marrickville Council
Administration Centre
2 Fisher Street
Petersham, NSW 2049
Re: Operation of Runways at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
Dear Mayor Cotter:

Established in 1970, Flight Transportation Associates, Inc. (FTA) provides professional consulting services on the technical, operational, economic, and management problems of air transportation. FTA was originally founded as a consulting outlet for faculty and staff of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The company handles a wide range of assignments in both the public and private sectors. Airport projects have included computer modelling of airside and landside facilities, aviation demand forecasting, environmental analysis, airspace and facility design, air traffic control procedures design and analysis, and safety audits of airport and air traffic control operations.

As you are aware, FTA completed a study of runway capacity for Kingsford-Smith International Airport in February 1989 for the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC). In our study, we estimated the saturation capacity of several alternative scenarios including simultaneous use of all three runways.

We used only accepted Australian or International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) separation standards for our computer modeling. These standards allow for the safe simultaneous operation of crossing/intersecting runways. In the United States, several airports including Los Angeles International, La Guardia (New York), Chicago O'Hare International and Boston-Logan International, routinely conduct crossing operations. This includes crossing of active runways by taxiing, arriving, and departing aircraft. At Logan Airport, a common configuration involves the simultaneous use of parallel runways 4L/R for arrivals and departures, and Runway 9 (which crosses the approach-end of Runway R4) for departures.

Primarily, these operations are conducted in weather allowing visual separation standards to be used by tower controllers and pilots. Crossing/intersecting runway procedures are used both to enhance capacity and equitably distribute noise exposure among surrounding communities. FTA has developed a computer program for Logan Airport which provides recommendations on configuration use. The recommendations consider projected demand, runway capacity, and cumulative noise exposure. We would be happy to provide additional information on this program at your request.

Although simultaneous use of crossing/intersecting runways may increase controller workload and airspace complexity, the opposite effect is also possible. This can occur when the additional runway capacity is used to segregate arrivals from departures or smaller aircraft (e.g., commuters) from air carrier jet traffic.

Further consideration of the unique situation at Sydney would be necessary before conclusions regarding the position of the Australian Civil Aviation Authority may be made. However, we can say that internationally accepted standards exist for the simultaneous operation of crossing/intersecting runways and, as such, these standards should allow for the safe and efficient operation of Kingsford-Smith International Airport as has been the case in the past.

Since we delivered our report in 1989, changes have undoubtedly occurred in many of the input parameters used in our model. FTA's Flexible Airport Simulation (FLAPS) is a highly advanced program capable of modeling complex combinations of runways, separation standards, fleet mixes, and demand levels. Updating the FLAPS capacity estimates using current information on these parameters along with the finalized third runway location may be desirable. Please let us know if we may be of further assistance.
Sincerely,
William C. Hoffman
President
xc: Sandra Kwa
Residents Airports Action Committee

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to have this further addition to the debate by Senator Parer. I know that Senator Parer has only recently entered the shadow ministry, but it is clear that he has not even bothered to read all $9 million worth of the environmental impact statement. There are reams and reams of material. Senator Woodley has asked for papers relating to the third runway to be tabled. I understand that the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) has agreed to do that. There are masses of them. They would be useful to Senator Parer because Senator Parer—I know this to be a fact from his comments in here—has not even bothered to read the EIS.
—How can you say that? How do you know?

—It is a central issue, and Senator Watson has not bothered to read it either, so he should not come latterly to this debate. From day one, the decision was announced. It has been a feature of this proposal for literally years. It is a major issue in the EIS. Public statements have been made for years. It was always intended—
—It was a policy decision.

—Whether it was a policy decision or not, Senator Parer asked me about what happened in 1989. I am happy to table further papers from the noise management plan of Sydney airport which make it absolutely clear that there is an option of using the east-west runway. Why does Senator Parer not read this stuff? This is a recent document, the actual noise management plan. The re-opening of the runway on safety grounds I have already canvassed. It is easy for Senator Parer to sit there—
—That is phoney.

—This is a matter of public record, so there is no difficulty in talking about it. There was a rather famous incident at Sydney airport involving three jet aircraft that almost intercepted on the intersection—
—There was one in Melbourne last week.

—Senator Parer will never get a chance to ask that. That aircraft accident, if it had happened, would have been—and I know it does not impress Senator Parer—one of the worst on-ground aviation disasters in the world. It was 3 1/2 seconds away from happening and it was only avoided by the professional actions of the Ansett pilot who in fact aborted his landing and did a go-around. There would have been a collision between a DC-10, a 737 and a Qantas 747 parked on the intersection. I say again to Senator Parer that, of course, we know these simultaneous operations operate throughout the world. I might add that to the best of my knowledge—and I will check this—we suspended simultaneous operations on that day for all international operators into Sydney airport. To the best of my knowledge, to this day—
—Why did you re-introduce it?

—Why does Senator Parer not wait for the answer? I will check this, because I have been out of the portfolio for a year now, but to the best of my knowledge that is still the situation at Sydney airport. The only international operator that is cleared for simultaneous operations as a result of this incident is Qantas—and none other, still to this day. It really angers me, with this campaign that this lot have been running all year about aviation safety, to hear Senator Parer come in here and, because it is a convenient political argument, blithely dismiss the potential safety problems of operating intersecting runways at the busiest airport in Australia. It is not a minor issue.

PARA.TAB: As I keep on saying to Senator Parer—and I have checked; he has not done it—if he wants a second professional opinion, he should get a briefing from the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, which investigated the incident I have just referred to and briefed me on it immediately after it happened. He should ask them about the relative safety—not the workability—of operating a two parallel runway system or a three intersecting simultaneous operation system. It is not an argument he wants to hear, but I have to say that it makes an absolute mockery of the crocodile tears that the opposition is crying both here and in the other house about its concern about aviation safety. I will say again—and it is demonstrated and proven internationally—that parallel runway operations are safer than intersecting simultaneous operations.

I would make it clear for the public record also that I did assume that Senator Parer's question—and I have not yet read the Laurie Oakes article—related to an assertion that Mr Keating interfered in recent days, as Senator Parer has asserted Mr Brereton did, with the operation of the east-west runway. It has been pointed out by a colleague who has read the Laurie Oakes article, which I have not had time to read, that the article referred to the original cabinet decision in 1989. I point out to Senator Parer that I could hardly comment on that because not only was I not a member of cabinet in 1989 when the decision was taken, but I was not even in the ministry. I was still a backbencher in this Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Harradine this day, relating to the drug RU486.

SPEECH.PARA: For quite some considerable time now the government has been allowing the Department of Human Services and Health to carry the can for making a decision to exempt the drug RU486 for the purposes of importing the drug. That decision was made in March of this year.

PARA.TAB: Subsequently, at estimates committees, by inference, the department has more or less expressed regret at making that decision, which was contrary to undertakings that were given and policy decisions that were made. One month before then, Senator Crowley wrote a minute to Dr Vaughan, the National Manager of the Therapeutic Goods Administration, indicating that the TGA should treat any application for RU486 in the same way as for any other drug. The first line of the minute says, `The TGA sought guidance'—I interpret here that it is guidance from the minister—`on how to deal with an application from the sponsor of RU486 for marketing approval as an abortifacient.'

In response to me, the minister talked about how the drug had possible uses for ailments. This minute dealt with the drug as an abortifacient. The minister was trying to mislead the chamber and the country on a very important matter. We now have to judge whether the department officials are properly carrying the can. Of course, that approval was for a CTN.

Given the sort of favourable advice that the minister had given just one month prior to the decision of the department, I suppose one could see that had an ameliorating affect on the decision. One therefore has to decide, in this International Year of the Family, who is responsible for the fact that the abortion drug RU486 has been imported into Australia because, quite obviously, the minister does not distinguish between this life-destroying drug and other drugs, many of which are life-affirming.

This is a matter that should be considered not only by the parliament as such but by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Here is the Minister for Family Services in this International Year of the Family making that sort of decision. She is giving the department the message to treat this drug in the same way as any other drug when, of course, that drug is a prohibited import as an abortifacient.

It is, and will be seen as, a decision of the Keating government. I do not think I have referred to the Keating government before, because I do not like personal politics. But it is time that Mr Keating took the reins on this and on a number of other matters, which he is not doing. He is leaving it to incompetent ministers such as Senator Crowley, whose incompetence is well recognised by this chamber. When giving some of her answers, she ought to look behind her and see the smiles and smirks on some of the faces of government senators. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Ellison this day, relating to the detention of Mr Eric Robert Bowra in the United Arab Emirates.

SPEECH.PARA: I say at the outset that I implore Senator Gareth Evans to look carefully into this matter. I ask him to look at the appeal papers himself and, in particular, to look at the areas that I mentioned previously—that is, the lack of opportunity for defence counsel to take evidence on a matter which was not believed to be a charge at that time; and, furthermore, the process by which the fourth charge was brought. Mr Bowra might be up for release in June, but incarceration is always very serious—very serious indeed for his family, his business and himself.

PARA.TAB: I ask the government to perhaps put in the same effort as what it is putting into the Peng case. I understand fully the reasons for that; I applaud the government for what it is doing in that case. But I fail to see why the government cannot put the same sort of effort into the Bowra matter. After all, I believe that there are some matters here which need looking into. The bail question was the first and most notable one where the court ordered Mr Bowra to be released on bail, but the police would not abide by the court order.

It is not good enough to put the effort into one matter and not into the other. Saying that some of these matters are really grounds of appeal or usual grounds of appeal really does not suffice in this matter. A plea from the highest level of the Australian government to the government of the United Arab Emirates could go a long way to assisting Mr Bowra's cause.

I note that on the 10th of this month there is a hearing to set an appeal date. That is merely a formality. The appeal date could be some months after that. To say, `Leave it to the appeal process,' is not good enough because, quite frankly, that will take some time. Even if it is a couple of months, two months in gaol is two months too much if it can be avoided. I am sure that if representations were made by the Australian government, they would be well received by the United Arab Emirates. I am sure that country would not have a deaf ear to any plea from a very senior level of the Australian government.

I further ask Senator Evans to look at the advice that has been given to him by his department and ensure that it, in turn, is advised by people on the ground in Abu Dhabi, particularly Mr Bowra's lawyer, who was instrumental in putting this appeal together.

I note that the situation is one which perhaps the government might not regard as being at the top of its list. It is not a heavy sentence. It is a matter which does not involve life or death. The fact is that there are no aspects of abduction or anything by the authorities. There is nothing as dramatic as that. But I do say this: it involves the imprisonment of an Australian national overseas. It involves an allegation of irregular process.

No matter how long the term of imprisonment is, it is a matter of grave concern for this man and his family. It is of great concern to Australians in the wider community because, after all, this could happen to any one of us. It was a simple accident which caused this man's misfortune. It is something that any one of us, or anyone who is near and dear to us, could find ourselves being involved in overseas. I ask the government to bear that in mind.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to just add a word or two to what I said in answer to Senator Ellison at question time. I have had occasion to check with my office. It does appear that the appeal documents, the detailed documents, were sent to my office the day before yesterday, but for one or other reasons to do with the absence of the relevant person in my office, they have only just come to the notice of the relevant person and me, as a result of Senator Ellison's question at question time. So we lost a day and a half. But I certainly will undertake to look at that material myself and get further advice on it.

PARA.TAB: The relevant consideration is whether there has been some irregularity of process, such as to constitute prima facie an improper process, an absence of the kind of reasonable due process that we would expect, or, indeed, a miscarriage of justice. All sorts of process considerations can arise which are essentially the kind of stuff of which ordinary legal appeals are made—such as technical misapplications here or there—and I think Senator Ellison would know that. There must be some limits on the extent to which governments can be expected to intervene in normal judicial process where these things are working themselves out.

I think I stated clearly enough the kinds of criteria or ground rules we apply when I answered a number of questions from Senator Ellison on this subject in the estimates committee hearing. I repeat: I acknowledge that there is an area in which it is proper for governments to take action. Certainly, we have done that already in relation to the bail matter. I am happy to check it out further in light of the material which has just now come to hand.

I think it is important to appreciate that, on the face of what I have seen so far, there is a significant difference between this case and the Peng case. The latter involves a capital charge, with the man actually facing death if charges are proven and the Chinese law works itself out. We also have a situation where he has been incarcerated for some 13 months without any process at all visibly occurring—no formal charges having been laid. We also have the circumstance of an apparent abduction, or certainly some serious misapplication of process in getting him to China in the first place. On the face of it, there is a whole series of grounds there for justifying quite a high level of governmental concern from a very early stage.

The UAE case, to which Senator Ellison refers, is a most unfortunate one but it does not seem to be in the same league as the Peng case on any of those criteria. Nonetheless, I am not prejudging the issue of irregularity and mis-process. If I am satisfied that there is something of the kind that would justify government action on the basis I have indicated, we will take action accordingly.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Woodley this day, relating to Social Security payments.

SPEECH.PARA: I was appreciative of the answer that Senator Crowley gave because it was quite extensive. But I want to draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that we are talking about people right across this country who are not benefiting from the upturn in the economy. I hear what the government is saying about those who are benefiting from a very much better economic performance which this nation seems to be enjoying. But at the same time—this is the amazing thing—not only the Salvation Army, which I quoted, but also Lifeline, St Vincent de Paul, Anglicare, and other welfare organisations, have said that the number of clients, the amount of distress in the community and the amount of assistance those organisations have to give is rising all the time. Somewhere along the line there is a problem because those at the bottom are not benefiting from the upturn in the economy. What worries me is that today, just before question time, we passed further legislation imposing further penalties on the people at the bottom.

PARA.TAB: I also want to say that many of the people who will suffer from these penalties are not the people that the government wants to catch—those defrauding the system, who are probably smart enough to keep on defrauding the system no matter what we do—it is the people who are illiterate, the people who have psychological problems, and so on.
