SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Economics References Committee entitled CSIRO—The Case for Revitalisation—Administration and Funding of Rural Research, together with the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: On 7 June 1994 the Senate referred the matter of the administration and funding of CSIRO's rural research to the Senate Economics References Committee. This reference arose because of the concerns of both scientists and the rural community that CSIRO was attempting to meet budgetary constraints through asset sales and staff reductions in a way that had become highly detrimental to rural research. In particular, there was a serious concern about a set of proposals that had been made in May this year by the Institute of Animal Production and Processing to sell several CSIRO field research stations and laboratory sites.

PARA.TAB: While this was the catalyst for the inquiry, the Senate referred a range of broader issues to the committee for examination. These other issues included: the structure and administration of CSIRO; the influence of private funding on the effectiveness and direction of research; aspects of CSIRO's commercialisation process; and the effectiveness of communication between CSIRO and the community.

The committee received 166 submissions to the inquiry. Seventy of those submissions were from CSIRO scientists in personal capacities. Other submissions were received from universities, CRCs, government organisations, community and business organisations, graziers, members of parliament and individual citizens. This high level of interest was a reflection of the concern that these people held about the future of one of Australia's best-known and most successful organisations. The fact that almost half the submissions received came from within CSIRO is indicative that there are indeed serious issues to be resolved, and the report draws extensively on the submissions and evidence provided to the committee.

However, these submissions, while they put heavy emphasis on the range of problems currently being felt by rural research scientists, also made a positive contribution by making suggestions as to the steps that need to be taken to ensure that the standard of excellence that has been synonymous with CSIRO's name worldwide is maintained.

During the inquiry the committee made a particular effort to visit those field stations and laboratories where serious debate had arisen as to whether the properties should be sold. These inspections and the hearings held in conjunction with them gave the committee a very clear understanding of the issues involved. The committee met with CSIRO scientists, with stakeholders and with the beneficiaries of CSIRO research.

I will outline the committee's findings in a moment but, before I do, I emphasise that they are the unanimous findings of the members of the committee. This is a highly significant point, given the contentious nature of the reference and the fact that the structure of all Senate committees changed shortly after the matter was referred to the former industry committee to place the reference before the Economics References Committee, which is now chaired by the opposition rather than the government.

At the outset, I wish to say that I am a great supporter of CSIRO and, as a former farmer, have been a beneficiary of its research. While much of the evidence that we received was in some respects critical of aspects of the organisation's operations, much was also positive. This aspect is reflected in our short title `The Case for Revitalisation'. The report picks up on many of the positive suggestions made in evidence. However, the title also makes it clear that, to achieve the goals that CSIRO sets for itself, changes will need to be made.

Evidence presented to the committee was very critical of the way that CSIRO is currently structured. Scientists in the rural institutes who gave evidence to the committee were unanimous that the structure of CSIRO was archaic, hierarchical and top heavy. Most of the criticism was directed at the institute level, and strong arguments were put to the committee that not only had the institute structure not been a success, but it had actually been most unhelpful to the organisation. Many submissions suggested abolishing the institute level of management.

The evidence given to the committee argued that structural problems within CSIRO have resulted in barriers between research staff and administrators, a conflict between the line management and corporate responsibilities of institute directors, and difficulties in communicating with external funding agencies. Similar problems were presented to the committee concerning CSIRO's administration. These problems include: an excess of institute involvement in internal management matters; accountability and review such that scientists are now over-managed and under-resourced; claims that the management system is old-fashioned and inefficient; problems with promoting scientists to management positions; and division between research staff and management staff caused by the inequities in funding arrangements.

Over the last three years the board has met on quite a number of occasions to set research priorities and to review internal administrative arrangements. Most recently the board has announced that it is conducting its own review of structural management and will report early next year. However, in the past these reviews have not led to any great change within CSIRO and have seemingly led to only a proliferation in management positions at the expense of research programs.

After considering all the evidence put before it, the committee came to the unanimous conclusion that CSIRO has been governed by an ineffectual board in that it has allowed a cumbersome and outdated management structure to remain in place, to the detriment of the organisation. The committee believes that the board must now move to address these problems in structure and administration. To achieve this, the committee has specifically recommended that the board must take a stronger role in the leadership of CSIRO.

Accordingly, the committee recommends that the board's current review of the management structure should, as a priority, restructure the CSIRO to reduce the layers of management, including the need to modify or eliminate the institute structure; introduce a business line model of structure based on having direct communication with the work places within CSIRO; set up a new administrative structure around the chief executive officer to replace the executive committee based on the board leaving internal administrative matters to the chief executive officer and such new structure; introduce a world best practice program of management across the organisation, including industrial participation; clarify its formal reporting mechanism to the minister; and, as part of this process of streamlining of administration, report on how excessive accountability can be reduced.

Further, the committee is of the view that, if the CSIRO board is unable to address the foregoing reforms in its report, the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) should consider establishing an independent assessment of the above proposals.

As the committee took evidence, it became clear that there is a crisis in rural research funding within CSIRO which has been brought on by the multiple effects of reduced appropriation funding, a downturn in the rural economy, increased competition from other public research organisations, an increased administration burden and, most importantly, a drop in the priority ranking of rural research within the CSIRO itself. In demoting rural research, the board made a decision which was inconsistent with its own priority ranking process and, in doing this, the committee believes, the board has acted in a manner inconsistent with its own stated goal of serving the public interest by maintaining a research effort in areas of national importance.

The committee agrees with the bulk of evidence put before it: firstly, the consequences of reducing rural research funding within CSIRO have already been and will continue to be extremely detrimental to some vital areas of rural research; and, secondly, there are many important reasons why Australia and in particular CSIRO should continue to give funding of rural research a high priority.

The message that the committee received in evidence was universal: in the nation's interest, the cuts in funding to rural research must stop and be reversed. Accordingly, the committee recommends that CSIRO reinstate the high priority ranking of rural research and ensure that the share of appropriation funding of rural research is increased commensurate with that ranking.

I now move to the significant proposals made by the Institute of Animal Production and Processing. The committee is particularly concerned about the decision making processes associated with the property sales proposals that were the genesis of this inquiry. Let me make it clear that the committee accepts that the IAPP had to address its funding problems. However, the manner in which the institute approached proposed property sales was poorly thought through, caused great anxiety amongst staff and put offside the stakeholders who had originally contributed funds towards the purchase of the properties. As an example of decision making and communication, the property sales proposals left a great deal to be desired.

CSIRO's position on the proposals was never made absolutely clear to the committee. However, some decisions have now apparently been made by CSIRO not to sell the properties. The committee believes that CSIRO, having made these decisions, has an obligation to convey them to the interested parties, including scientists and stakeholders, as a matter of urgency. Independent of CSIRO's decisions, however, the committee has unanimously come to the conclusion that CSIRO should not sell the field stations at Longford and Arding in Armidale and Yalanbee in Western Australia and has recommended they be retained. The committee was also convinced that the laboratory site at Long Pocket in Brisbane held too much valuable infrastructure to be disposed of in the near future and has recommended that it also be retained.

With regard to the institute's proposal to move part of the Division of Wool Technology from Ryde to Geelong, the committee concluded that there were both advantages and disadvantages associated with the move and that the decision was largely dependent on the future of wool industry funding. Accordingly, the committee has recommended that a decision be deferred until the direction of funding becomes clear.

Because some divisions are highly dependent on external rural industry funds and because those funds have fluctuated considerably in recent years, the committee considered the issue of countercyclical funding—that is, the nexus between government and industry contributions to rural research which accentuates the peaks and troughs of agricultural production. This issue is far more complicated than it outwardly seems and, accordingly, the committee has recommended that CSIRO, in collaboration with industry and government, formulate a package of mechanisms to buffer research programs from wide fluctuations in rural industry research levies.

The way in which proposals for the property sales was handled by the organisation revealed that communications within CSIRO are less than adequate and the committee thus makes specific recommendations about the need for greater industrial democracy within the organisation and the need for staff representation on the board to assist in that process. The committee also took evidence on the role of communicators in the CSIRO and has concluded that CSIRO has failed to adequately define the role of its communicators and to ensure that they are adequately trained for that role. To overcome this, the committee has recommended that the role and responsibility of CSIRO communicators be more clearly defined and that CSIRO ensure that people employed as communicators either have the necessary skills to do the task or receive appropriate training for the position.

The committee has also recommended that CSIRO ensure that those scientists who are required to communicate regularly with stakeholders and the public have the necessary skills to do so. In addition, the committee has recommended that CSIRO review the procedures used for the approval of media releases with a view to increasing the speed with which they can be issued.

In relation to external funding targets, the committee believes that, while there have been significant benefits arising from the target figure of 30 per cent, particularly in focusing CSIRO towards the needs of industry, there have also been some considerable disadvantages. The committee believes that CSIRO has not adequately addressed these negative aspects and, more importantly, has not sufficiently taken note of the concerns of its scientists who pointed out the very real difficulties the targets have caused them.

It was clear to the committee that the demands of obtaining external funds are placing considerable stresses on scientists and that this is hampering their research. The committee considers that the CSIRO has taken a too rigid approach to external funding and should now have a more flexible attitude. The committee thus recommends that CSIRO address this problem by developing multidisciplinary teams within the divisions to assist with obtaining and retaining external funds. The committee further recommends that management play a stronger role in external fundraising.

CSIRO has played a very active role in the commercialisation of its research over the last few years. There are signs, however, that in pursuing this goal CSIRO was not adequately prepared. The committee has concluded that CSIRO aggressively pursued commercialisation without first establishing a suitable structure and without adequately preparing its staff for commercial transactions. For this the board and the senior officers must be held accountable.

Despite recent lessons in litigation, and despite the production of a commercial practice manual, the committee believes that CSIRO still does not have sufficient structures and mechanisms in place to prevent legal liability emanating from one area having a significant detrimental impact on other areas of CSIRO. The committee therefore recommends that the CSIRO board commission a study to determine further ways in which CSIRO can limit its legal liability arising from the commercialisation of its research.

The committee also recommends that CSIRO clarify its respective roles in commercialisation and development and make its policy in these areas clear to its staff and stakeholders. The committee believes that CSIRO has not sufficiently upheld its role in the adoption of research findings in the rural sector and has recommended that CSIRO examine ways in which research results can be transferred to the rural sector, given the demise of state extension services.

Finally, the committee considered the broader concerns of CSIRO scientists and concluded that there are serious problems with employment security and a deterioration in conditions of employment within CSIRO. In some areas this is hampering the efficiency of its research scientists and is a major cause of low morale among its staff. The committee is concerned that if the CSIRO board continues to ignore this situation, increasing numbers of scientists will leave the organisation to work elsewhere. The final result will be that the critical mass necessary for efficient research will be lost in many areas vital to Australia's agricultural economy.

The committee recommends that the CSIRO board address the problems of employment insecurity, poor conditions of employment, low career status, excessive accountability, the stresses of fundraising, ineffective industrial participation and low morale amongst its rural research staff as a matter of urgency. Rural research has always been given a high priority by CSIRO. But with recent changes in priority status by the board, agricultural science is now at the point of crisis. Overall funding is inadequate, morale is poor and CSIRO is not attracting the quality people it must have for the continued future of good scientific research. The committee has concluded that if something is not done fairly quickly rural research is likely to suffer a further decline that will ultimately be detrimental to Australia's economy.

I would like to thank the secretariat, particularly our secretary Rob Diamond and Pippa Carron, who are both in the chamber at present, for their tremendous effort in what has been a very concentrated inquiry with a very large number of submissions and a very tight time frame to prepare this report. Their efforts have been noted by the committee and we certainly commend them for the effort that they have put into this inquiry.

In conclusion, I believe personally that rural research has always been regarded as Australia's sacred cow, both within CSIRO and by the Australian community. The recommendations of this report have been made in an effort to ensure that our sacred cow does not become a sacrificial lamb.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to go over everything that Senator Ferguson so ably put to the chamber, but I will cover some sectors of the report of the Economics References Committee on the CSIRO. Some honourable senators may remember that it was my motion that got this inquiry going. At that time, Senator Childs was the chairman of the committee. It is one of those inquiries that we started with one chairman and finished with another, and both, of course, did a top class job.

PARA.TAB: I am very disappointed that Senator Cook, the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, and Senator Collins are not in the chamber at the moment. My main reasons for proposing the inquiry were: the $20 million drop in rural funding for CSIRO in real terms; the shifting of priority for rural research; the selling off of research stations; and the fact that in 4 1/2 years, or thereabouts, this government had had four ministers for science, including Senator Schacht.

This inquiry was opposed by the NFF—for any good reasons unknown to me. It was opposed by Senator Cook and Senator Collins. These two senior ministers came into the chamber and tried for half an hour to shout down my motion to have this matter referred to a Senate committee for inquiry. It was also opposed by CSIRO chairman, Professor Adrienne Clarke, and by the CEO of CSIRO, Dr Stocker. I hope that Dr Stocker's attitude has changed somewhat, but I will come back to that later. It was also opposed by some of my National Party colleagues in this place. I think they have now seen the light.

It might be interesting to some people, not all, how it came about that I got interested in this situation; I found out about some of these points a bit later. There is a fellow in Perth who works for CSIRO—and I will not name him for obvious reasons because I think CSIRO is suspicious of him enough already—who rang me and said that he knew me from somewhere in previous years. I could not remember him, but when I saw him he pointed out what he used to do; I had better not say where he used to work either. Before I met him, I said, `Look, meet me at the airport. I'll only have 20 minutes. If you can convince me in 20 minutes, well you've convinced me.' So he turned up, and I have never seen a fellow talk for 20 minutes so flat out.

One of the main things he told me was that Yallanbee in Western Australia—the research station at Bakers Hill—was to be sold off. Mr Deputy President, you might have seen it in your mining experience, or you might have seen the turn-off on the odd occasions you go through Bakers Hill. So, that was the reason. Yallanbee is a property of some 3,000 acres, close to Floreat Park where the scientists have their laboratories and animals.

I then followed that up and spoke to a nephew, Bernie Panizza, who has a Bachelor of Agricultural Science from the University of Western Australia. That is a good plug for him. He was doing experiments there at the time, and when he warned me I thought it was time to look into the matter. When I did look into the matter, I came up with these points. I really found out what was being done. Of course, there were other top research stations at Longford and Arding in Armidale in New South Wales, of which I got a good independent view from Ian Sinclair, a member of the other house. He told me that those two institutions were certainly well worth hanging on to. That is the reason that I decided to go for this inquiry.

As honourable senators have already been told by our chairman, we had 176 submissions from all around Australia. Of course, as Senator Ferguson already pointed out, those submissions mainly came from within CSIRO—CSIRO was leaking like a sieve. I believe that this must be somewhere near a record number of submissions. It is certainly the highest number of submissions that I have seen on any inquiry in the seven years I have been in this place. They were very good, detailed submissions.

We started off hearings all around Australia, as Senator Ferguson already mentioned. The main thrust that came out of that was that the CSIRO board must take a stronger role in the leadership of the organisation. As pointed out, it was thought that there may be conflicting roles here because we were told at the inquiry that the CEO of CSIRO reports directly to the minister and also to the board, as would normally happen. In any commercial board, the CEO reports to the board. On examination of the act, it was discovered that that is not so. The CEO reports to the board and then the board is supposed to report to the minister. Exactly which member of the board reports to the minister is unclear. In a commercial organisation, Mr Deputy President, you would know that the CEO reports to the board and then if the board has to report to a minister it should be the chairman of that board.

If we take the case of a large company that has subsidiaries, we have a board of the parent company and a board of the subsidiary. If we take CSIRO to be the subsidiary in this case, the CEO of the subsidiary reports to the chairman of the subsidiary. The chairman of the subsidiary then reports to the board. That is how I believe that this should be done. If it is not being done, from a reading of the act that seems to be the way it has to go. So that is where the board has to take a more proactive role.

What we heard in Melbourne from Dr Adrienne Clarke, who I was very impressed with, was that with the encouragement of this report that is the way it will all go. As Senator Ferguson already pointed out, restructuring of the layers of management obviously has to be done. I believe from looking at it, and I always look at most things with a commercial point of view, that there is a lot of room for improvement there.

I move to the point of reinstatement of the high priority ranking for rural research. To my knowledge CSIRO, and I do not think anyone would disagree with me, was set up exactly for that, for rural research, many years ago. Exactly how many, I do not know. The year 1926 or something like that has been mentioned.

I believe that is where the research should remain because rural industries need—this is different from manufacturing industries and other service industries and communications—long-term research. I believe that long-term research can only be done in an organisation such as this that has long-term funding. Manufacturing, processing and communications—they all want quick results. Otherwise, by the time they get their research done, some other organisation has beaten them to the punch. So I believe that rural research has to go to the top of CSIRO's priority list again.

I also question the amount that is being spent on telecommunications research in CSIRO. In Australia we have Telecom, Optus and other electronic organisations and then there are the worldwide organisations such as AT and T, British Telecom, Italian Telecom and Motorola—all of those can do all the research for communications in the world without being duplicated too much by CSIRO. That is why I mention that we should have priorities.

Then we need an independent study of rural levies. We need to know how they are applied to research and expansion and whether all industries and organisations which benefit from this research currently pay levies. I did not know that the horse industry did not pay any research levy whatsoever.

We had that big case in Queensland only a couple of months ago of that virus that killed 20 or 30 horses and a human life was lost. The authorities were able to call on CSIRO which got to the heart of the problem quickly and dealt with it. So I can see that in times to come there will have to be some sort of levy coming from that industry. My colleague in the other place, Mr Wilson Tuckey, as chairman of the galloping association of Western Australia, will probably not be too pleased at my suggestion, but it will have to come as well as a lot of others, including showjumping competitions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Put the hard word on him!

—Put the hard word on him, yes. He is a chairman, incidentally, of the WA Turf Association rather than the galloping association. I have never been to the trots or the gallops in my life, so I would not really know the right names.

PARA.TAB: Manufacturing also has to do a lot more. I know it puts in specific grants; that is, specific grants to a quick end. I believe for the medium term sort of situation manufacturing has to do a lot more.

Another recommendation is that the CSIRO, industry and government should cooperate to achieve counter-cyclical funding. A good example in the last few years is the big downturn in wool prices that was caused by the disastrous reserve price scheme. The 1988-89 high prices caused a big build-up in the stockpile, and the industry collapsed. There was a big build-up in levies for wool research. I suppose that the CSIRO cannot be blamed for committing funds instead of putting some away for a rainy day. Not all woolgrowers thought that those prices would last forever, and the prices did collapse. Having been committed to research and having committed its funds, the CSIRO was not able to keep everyone going when the downtown came around. I will not go into it deeply now, but there has to be some way of achieving counter-cyclical funding.

The CSIRO undertakes extension projects, where it conducts research and then gets outside organisations to develop its findings. It has had a couple of big losses. Cassegrain was one. The other one escapes me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Charter Pacific.

—That is right; it was Charter Pacific. The cost rose to $20 million, $30 million or $40 million. I do not have the exact figure. Our report recommends that a commissioned study be undertaken to determine how the CSIRO can limit its legal liability arising from the commercialisation of research. Certain measures can be undertaken, but in the commercial world today that might not be quite as easy as it seems on paper. These days, hiding behind the corporate veil is, quite rightly, not so easy.

PARA.TAB: We heard a lot from communicators when conducting our inquiry, so there is a recommendation to streamline and upgrade communication skills. The CSIRO employs 150 communicators. I said to Dr Stocker at a social function one night that if his communicators were half as good at communicating the good things about the CSIRO in research as they are at communicating what is wrong with the CSIRO—I was told this at Perth airport—the CSIRO would be held in a better light and people would appreciate it. Dr Stocker said that he would write a promise on his wall and get me to sign it. I hope that he keeps his promise. I will sign it.

The final recommendation concerns the retention of the research farms at Longford and Arding, and Yalanbee in Western Australia so that in years to come scientists will be able to use them for the advantage of all. Yalanbee is the only research station in Australia that is located in a Mediterranean climate. It may be hard to believe, but it is a fact.

Mr Deputy President, you may realise by now that Dr Stocker has decided not to seek to renew his contract. He told me in answer to a question that he reckoned this inquiry was a waste of time, as Senator Cook and Senator Collins said it was a waste of time. I said, `Dr Stocker, we are coming towards the end of our inquiry. You are not applying for this job again. If we had a new government tomorrow and you were the minister for science, what would be the way of the future?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you offering him preselection?
—That is only a side line. It would be well worth while for any party to offer him preselection. This was his answer:

PARA.TAB: I would argue very vigorously that the nation gets an excellent return for its investment in science and technology, that there is a real need to recognise and continue to recognise the contribution of research and development in that innovation pathway, and that the privately funded research which I dealt on a little bit at my previous hearing needs to increase very sharply in Australia. The government needs to get its mind around ways in which that can be stimulated and it needs to maintain an unequivocal commitment to excellence, both in basic research funding and in the more applied areas.

I happen to think that both of those are enormously important in the national interest, and I would have thought that by the time my [hypothetical] appointment is announced in this new capacity it will be a time when CSIRO has a number of performance indicators against which it can report and justify a very strong case for a budget in each triennial negotiation. I have already indicated to you that I do not think that is the situation at the moment—

SPEECH.PARA: I underline that remark—

and I think CSIRO has needed to take this initiative to put in place a number of criteria agreed to by the government against which it can state what it has actually achieved, and why what it achieves is important. I think that opportunity is now being seized.
I thank Dr Stocker for that answer, because I believe that it sums it all up.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I thank Senator John Coulter of the Australian Democrats for his support in getting this motion up. I was also supported by the WA Greens. Senator John Coulter has always wanted an inquiry into the CSIRO and science in Australia. There is no way that I would have put to my party room a motion for having a wide-ranging inquiry. Perhaps this inquiry was not what he wanted—if he is listening in South Australia, I hope he hears that I am thanking him—but it went some way down the track towards achieving it. I certainly believe that this inquiry has not been a waste of time. I certainly hope that the two ministers who criticised the motion so much take note of what has been said. I thank Senator Coulter for his support.

I also thank the two chairmen who conducted the inquiry. Senator Alan Ferguson from South Australia was the second chairman. Before the restructure, Senator Bruce Childs of New South Wales was the first chairman. I also thank my government colleagues for their cooperation. We have come down with one report—there is no minority report—which is not often achieved with contentious matters in this place. I also thank Rob Diamond and Pippa Carron of the secretariat. I will finish with a quote. We owe a lot to research in Australia. Although we have to put a lot of finance into the CSIRO in years to come, I believe that the IOU we give to the CSIRO today will be our prosperity tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak to this report. I congratulate the chairman, Senator Alan Ferguson, on his statements with regard to the report. All committee members would endorse what he has said. I will also at the outset thank the staff of the committee, because they did a marvellous job. In addressing this report, I will go back in the history of the CSIRO in terms of the benefit that the CSIRO has delivered to this country over a long time. I do not think anyone is under any misconceptions about the fact that it has been, and is, a very worthy organisation and that it has done tremendous work. Some of it has probably been immeasurable in dollar terms, particularly in the rural sector. I guess that it was for some of those reasons that this inquiry was started. Albeit I believe that it was partly political at the beginning, at the end of the day we may well have come up with something that may help the CSIRO into the future.

PARA.TAB: As has been already stated, the inquiry received a huge number of submissions. Although they primarily came from three of the six institutes within the CSIRO, those submissions did raise a number of serious concerns. Those concerns related to the way in which the CSIRO was either structured or managed. It is my view that sometimes we find problems and we quickly point to the structure or the way in which the umbrella of an organisation is set out rather than analyse the management that operates within the structure. It is certainly my view, and I think the findings of the committee demonstrate it, that if we take a look at the overall structure of all the institutes we see that there are problems associated with the management of a number of institutes within the CSIRO.

The board during its time has not necessarily had the input to the management or policy or strategy making of the CSIRO that it ought to have had. When the government set up the board—which was a change in the old act from an executive committee to a board structure with a chief executive officer—I think the members of the board did not realise what their task was. It certainly appears that they did not adequately carry out their responsibilities in ensuring that the CSIRO had a management system that would enable it both financially and strategically to deliver the results that it should be able to deliver to the country as a whole.

Within the CSIRO research does not totally revolve around the rural sector. It is clear, as the nature of this country has changed, that research is relevant to a whole host of areas within the make-up of this country's industries and businesses. That has been a strategy that the government has set about during the course of its term in office. I would like to pick up the matter of funding and read into the Hansard a statement by the minister which is contained at chapter 2.3 of the report. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, the Honourable Senator Peter Cook, has stated that `the base level funding for CSIRO has been increased from $418.9m in 1993-94 to $442.3m in the 1994-95 budget. During the 1991-94 triennium, in addition to base level funding, there were three special allocations by the Commonwealth to CSIRO to replace outdated equipment and upgrade building assets. These allocations were clearly intended to apply to that triennium only. In the 1994-95 budget, however, the Government decided that CSIRO would permanently retain part of these special one-off allocations, thereby increasing the base level funding for the Organisation. As a consequence, CSIRO's 1994-97 triennium funding represents a real increase of about $20m per annum in base level funding'.

The government grants to the CSIRO a one line appropriation. This is where we really started to find the problems with regard to funding for rural research. The board makes the decisions on the allocation of that appropriation across its various institutes depending on which areas of research it finds the most attractive. The executive committee is now made up of the directors of the institute and the CEO, as I understand it—and I think evidence has shown—did make recommendations to the board with regard to the funding allocations, and the board did indeed overturn two of the three recommendations in respect of rural research.

PARA.TAB: As I have said, I had a view at the start of this inquiry that it was somewhat politically motivated and aimed at the government with respect to funding, but during the course of it we started to find things that were very pertinent and relevant to the CSIRO in the way it has operated. One of the things that other senators have raised already is its commercialisation. It is clear from the fact that CSIRO has already suffered significant losses through settlements of litigation that it still does not have sufficient protection and skills within its organisation to enter the field of commercialisation that it is endeavouring to enter into or has entered into.

The committee recommended with regard to rural research a proposal for counter cyclical funding in that it be looked at in conjunction with industry and other bodies to see whether or not there may be a possibility of organising counter cyclical funding for commodity prices and/or climatic changes which cause downturns in certain sectors of the rural industries.

There was another recommendation with regard to the CSIRO and the funding of it, particularly from an external point of view, and one that I think is very worthwhile. That related to the contribution of post farm gate industries that receive significant benefits from CSIRO research but make little or no contribution. On page 39 of the report, paragraph 2.62 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Government commission an independent study of the system of rural levies, which would focus on:
.(i) how they are applied to research in both on-farm and post-farm sectors, and;
.(ii) how the system could be expanded to includeindustries not currently contributing to, but benefiting from, CSIRO research.

I think those things are very worthy. If we are to have a national research organisation such as the CSIRO, it is important that not only the public of Australia understands but certainly the other industries in this country understand that if we are to get to the forefront and to maintain that place in research terms, it will take a contribution from everybody.

PARA.TAB: Another important point that has been touched on is that of communication within the CSIRO and with its stakeholders and the general public. It is quite clear from evidence that we took with regard to the decision making process that has to be gone through for press releases of findings or other things that may have happened within the CSIRO that the process is inadequate. It just takes too long. Journalists outside CSIRO identified very clearly that quite often by the time they get information on particular findings their newsworthiness has passed. From a public promotional point of view, that is another very serious aspect that has to be addressed within the CSIRO.

There is the other very important element of industrial democracy. It was very clear from the evidence we received from a very large number of scientists and other people who work for the CSIRO that they feel that industrial democracy of the type that we should have in this country today clearly does not exist within CSIRO. There were very good examples of that in the way in which notices were issued to staff with regard to decisions that may be going to be taken or may have already been taken. They clearly showed that the CSIRO really has a long way to go in addressing the type of industrial processes that should exist in this country today, particularly if we look at the types of enterprise bargaining arrangements that are being put in place in other industry sectors.

I said that I only wanted to make a few brief remarks. Some of the evidence we received clearly showed that some members of management have a lot to answer for and I certainly think that the board has not really lived up to what should and could be expected of it. I make one comment with regard to the chief executive officer's statement that he felt he had a conflict of interest in having to report to two masters. I want to reiterate what was said earlier, that the act requires the CEO of the CSIRO to report to the board and the board to the minister. In fact, under the act, the board is required to provide to the minister a strategy for up to a five-year period. The CEO is then required to provide an operational plan to the board on an annual basis.

From the evidence we received and the replies to the questions we asked, it appears that little has come out of the internal review processes that the CSIRO conducted itself. Yet, there were clearly problems existing. It is almost a shame that some of those people have not addressed the issues. There seems to have been a lot of infighting at senior management level, and this has had a detrimental effect on the overall operation of the CSIRO, particularly within two of the key institutes in the rural sector.

Those are the things which must happen if we are to see changes brought about by the CSIRO. Some of the scientists said to me, `It would not matter if we had another $100 million; the problems would still exist.' Therefore, it is not just a question of funding; it is a question of management getting its act together and the board actually doing its job.

I think there should be communication down to the shopfloor level in CSIRO, because many of the scientists also said that they had many ideas about how CSIRO could operate and still deliver the goods within the budget that it received. Yet they were never given the opportunity to contribute to the decision making process. If this report is to be taken account of—and I hope it will be—at the end of the day we will see a better managed, much more efficient and, I hope, more communicative CSIRO, one that ensures greater participation of its work force.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who have cooperated and allowed me to speak now about the CSIRO report. I acknowledge the remarks made by Senator Murphy. He said that when the terms of reference on this issue were first referred to the committee to be dealt with, it may have started off as a bit of a witch-hunt against the government because the reference was on a narrow basis about the funding in the rural sector. But the committee, whose unanimous report is before us with recommendations made on a tri-partisan basis, got very quickly into wider issues.

PARA.TAB: As a former science minister, I believe that most of the major issues in this report, particularly about management structure, are relevant. I say to Senator Murphy and Senator Ferguson that, in some ways, I consistently raised the problem of the structure within CSIRO during 1993 when I was minister. Though I have not had much time to read the report since it was tabled an hour ago, there is much in the recommendations about structure and the descriptions that go with it for careful consideration, not only by the government but also by the community.

I think that the CSIRO structure is too top heavy. That was an issue I raised with it. Unless we can get more flexibility and discretion in the way it is managed in the new paradigms of the way science and applied science are conducted in Australia, we will not get a good return for the community's $500 million investment each year in CSIRO. The remarks made by one of the witnesses, Professor Jerry Freed, quoted in paragraph 1.31 on page 8 of the report, are very pertinent. These were issues I raised with the CSIRO management that could not be ignored for the future. Professor Freed said:

SPEECH.PARA: The newer structures [of other organisations], which are very parallel and involve a lot of people working together across disciplines, seem to be working much better. It is difficult for CSIRO to fit in with those because it has a culture which is based on a very vertical command structure.

I think that is a very apt description of the problem CSIRO has. Unfortunately, there is a large conservative element in CSIRO committed to the present structure because of the status, and ego and career commitments that go with the work. But, if CSIRO stays with the present structure, we will never get the best return for the community's investment. Above all else, we will not get the best out of the scientists who work in CSIRO.

PARA.TAB: I was involved in some controversy last year when I suggested that maybe the best way to get research going in the marine area was to create a new marine institute separate from CSIRO with a couple of its divisions being added to it. The main argument raised by CSIRO management against that was that this would break down the interdisciplinary arrangements within CSIRO. This report clearly shows that there are not enough interdisciplinary arrangements across institutes or divisions. That was the issue I tried to raise with CSIRO last year without much success, in view of the response it made publicly. A fundamental issue about getting discrete flexible science is to have multidisciplinary approaches.

I note that in the report there is strong criticism of the institute structure that was proposed by the McKinsey report a few years ago. I think that criticism is correct in many ways. An extra level of management is being put in with no clear definition of good management or what they are doing—whether they are putting another level of managers in per se.

The question to be looked at is, if the institute structure is removed and it goes back to the old divisional structure that many people in CSIRO seem to want, unless there are clear structures, will there be divisions running themselves as little feudal cells separate from everybody else? That will only exacerbate the problem. The real issue in CSIRO's structure is to break down the vertical silos and go horizontal.

That is the great challenge for an organisation with 7,000 staff and a budget all-up of $700 million plus—$500 million from the federal government. It is a challenge for the board, the chief executive and the senior management. Unless those challenges are taken on, as this report shows, in the long run, the community will not get the return it would expect from an investment that runs at about half a billion dollars a year.

Honourable senators have to acknowledge that there are thousands of excellent scientists in CSIRO. The real issue is: what is the best way they can contribute to the development of a cleverer country—as we say in Australia—in technology and science and getting it out to industry?

The bottom line is that CSIRO is, above all else, an applied research agency to help industry—whether it is in the rural, manufacturing or environmental sector. No-one disputes that. John Stocker himself has said that; 90 per cent of the activities he sees at CSIRO involve applied research to help Australian industry, in whatever area, develop new ideas and techniques to help the output of Australia's economy. Some scientists in CSIRO think it ought to be a pure research body, not applied. That is a fundamental dilemma that has to be sorted out. I think the parliament has been correct in the past by saying that CSIRO is an applied research organisation there to help industry.

One of the big challenges for any agency the size of CSIRO—this is mentioned in the report and is part of my portfolio as minister for small business—is how do we help small and medium-sized enterprises get access to the wonderful, intellectual power that is within CSIRO in a sensible, sensitive and cost-effective way. That is one issue that people in CSIRO realise they have not yet developed well enough. It is a challenge for the future.

CSIRO is able—quite rightly and very effectively in many cases—to draw up contracts and arrangements when dealing with a scientific research laboratory in a big company, such as BHP or CRA. But the very small companies often need a day's help on a little technological problem. How does one get that information, flexibility and quickness of response? That is a major challenge for CSIRO. It is not the only science organisation in the world faced with that challenge. In most of the industrialised world, organisations similar to CSIRO are facing that same difficulty.

We all know that CSIRO's name is a very effective brand name. It is well received in the Australian community and overseas. However, my argument always will be that it is not the institution that is important, it is what it produces and how the people within it go about their business in providing that output. With this identified very vertically structured organisation, we are not getting the best output from the people within. People are more trapped into the structure and arguing over structure, not over science and technology developments. That is what we always have to be flexible about.

The report—from just a very quick read of the major recommendations—moved on to wider issues, thank goodness, from what was to be initially, I suspect, a bit of a witch-hunt about the funding of the rural sector. In that way, it has been very valuable. It is noted that it was a bipartisan report. All honourable senators from all sides agreed to the recommendations. They give the community, as well as the government, a lot of food for good thought.

TALK.START.PARA: —The background to this inquiry by the Senate Economics References Committee into the administration and funding of rural research of the CSIRO—the report of which has been tabled today—was the decision by the present federal Labor government to cut funding for the CSIRO by some $60 million in the last budget. The second issue which led to the inquiry was what appeared to be the redirection—either at the behest of the government or by a decision by CSIRO itself—of its research priorities away from rural industry towards, particularly, manufacturing and information technology.

PARA.TAB: Those two facts—the reduction in funding and the redirection of priorities—were occurring despite the fact that, in all the evidence presented to the committee, it was shown that CSIRO research in the field of agriculture generates very high returns on investment. It was also happening despite the fact that the provision of government appropriation funds for the rural research undertaken by CSIRO is very important because of the large amount of public good that comes out of that research. Again, that is a contrast between the rural research side of CSIRO and the research that CSIRO might conduct into the other areas I mentioned such as manufacturing and information technology.

It is in the rural sector that that public good research involves a very large degree of basic research, or what might be described as pure research. Mr Acting Deputy President, with your background in the history and philosophy of science, you would understand only too well the high priority that must be retained for basic and pure research. It was with those concerns and considerations that this inquiry was established.

As Minister Schacht said a few moments ago, despite the fact that the inquiry has found problems and difficulties in CSIRO that need addressing across a wide range of areas, nevertheless the basic funding problem has also been highlighted in this report. Certainly, the government cannot escape the blame that should quite accurately be levelled at it for its cut in funding to CSIRO and particularly for the reduced funding available to rural research within CSIRO. The report, despite the fact that it deals with other issues, as I said, still highlights the shortage of funds available.

The first issue which attention is drawn to in this report is the structure and administration of CSIRO. There was certainly a lot of evidence which we, as a committee, found justified, that the structure of CSIRO has become archaic, hierarchical and top heavy. That criticism was in particular directed at the institute level of the CSIRO, which a large number of witnesses regarded as being unhelpful to the success of the organisation. The conclusion of the committee was that there needs to be a flattening of the administrative structure of CSIRO, with one less layer of management in place in the future.

We also found certain difficulties with the relationship between the board and its responsibilities. In theory, the board answers to the government, but in practice it seems that it really does not answer to anyone. In fact, rather than acting as a true board—as would operate in the private sector—it has become far more involved than we believe is necessary in the day-to-day running of CSIRO and in what ought to be administrative and management decisions. Certainly, the board ought to reconsider its role with regard to CSIRO. Because a number of the board members are part time—in fact, I think all of the board members are part time—there are also conflicts that develop between their other responsibilities and their responsibilities as members of the board. One other shortcoming of the board, on which we were unanimous, was the absence of a staff representative to provide staff input.

I referred a few minutes ago to the problems with the structure at institute level. What has occurred in particular is that instead of the institutes providing, as we believe they ought to have been, advice and decisions on business systems and establishing the visions for their areas of responsibility, at the next level down, as with the board, they have got too much involved in internal management issues and decisions which really ought to be the preserve of the division level of CSIRO.

Another problem with the current structure of CSIRO is that both science and management have suffered because of the practice of promoting scientists into management positions. This has been done in part because the only way of ensuring that very competent scientists receive appropriate levels of reward and remuneration was to promote them out of doing scientific research and into management positions. The consequence is that they have been lost to scientific research because they have been forced to take over this management role for which, in most instances, they are ill-equipped.

While scientists may make good managers, a lot of them do not. It is not their particular skill or perhaps their particular interest. Most scientists want to be involved in undertaking scientific research rather than in day-to-day management and administration. On the one hand, this promotion of scientists into management roles has deprived CSIRO of some of its best scientists in terms of their capacity to undertake scientific research while, on the other hand, it has provided poor managers for CSIRO. This is not only because many of them are basically ill-equipped to be managers, but also because they really have not received any proper management training. That is a difficulty that was clearly evident in our inquiry.

I have already referred to the funding issue, and that was the second issue to which the committee directed its attention. Between 1983-84 and 1993-94, in real terms in 1993-94 dollars, appropriation funding for CSIRO declined by almost $100 million from $562 million to $467 million. That paints very starkly the neglect of the government with regard to funding for CSIRO. On the other hand, research levies charged to rural producers increased by about $60 million annually over that period. Although the appropriation funding for CSIRO declined, the extra funding provided by rural industry research because of the increased funding from rural levies largely offset that.

The overall funding available to CSIRO does not seem to have declined by a significant amount. Yet when we look specifically at appropriation funding, which is particularly important for rural research because of the public good aspect and the long-term nature of a lot of rural research, we see that certainly there has been a diminution of government responsibility in that area. For many years CSIRO strongly funded rural research because of the need to improve production and processing in agricultural industries, and because of the previous strong financial support from both the government and the rural industries themselves.

We need to remember with CSIRO and its research in this area that a lot of our agricultural problems are unique: the nature of our soil is unique; our agricultural industries themselves are unique. Therefore, it is not possible to take the results of research off the shelf from other countries and apply them to Australia in the way it is possible to do that with a lot of manufacturing industries and other industry sectors where, because of the increasing globalisation of the international economy and the development of multinational companies, research in relation to manufacturing industry, information technology, and so on, can be imported from other countries. But with agricultural research in relation to Australia, that is simply not possible because of the unique nature of our agricultural environment and the agricultural industries themselves. Again, for that reason, it is very important that funding for rural research be given a very high priority.

Apart from the cuts in funding, the money actually available for rural research within CSIRO has also been eroded by the increasing burden of the administration and corporate management, as well as the devolution of the administrative support function down to the division levels. An increasing share of the funds that CSIRO has available to it is being eaten up in administrative support rather than going to real scientific research.

So there are several factors that have contributed to the reduced funding. I have referred to the reduction of $100 million in real terms in appropriation funding provided by the government, but the downturn in the rural sector over the relevant period has also contributed to a reduced availability of funding from that area. As I said, there certainly seems to have been a shifting of priorities within CSIRO as regards the importance of rural research.

That certainly appears to be at odds with CSIRO's stated priority for rural research. In terms of CSIRO's corporate plan and all its statements, it appears that rural research is still given a very high priority by that organisation. Yet, when we looked at the actual allocation of resources to rural research, we found it was sadly lacking. As I said, there is a clear inconsistency between the stated objectives of CSIRO on the one hand and the reality of the funding made available on the other.

It is important that Australia at least maintains and ideally increases its overall commitment to rural research in the public sector, particularly if we are going to meet the objectives that this government has of providing the products of agriculture to the rapidly growing markets of Asia. We must retain a high level of rural research if we are to maintain the competitive advantage that we have in rural industry. If we maintain that competitive advantage, the whole of Australia will benefit from the additional markets that our rural producers obtain in Asia and other regions. Small cuts in research will significantly reduce our competitiveness with a consequently large impact on export earnings.

Another issue that has emerged from this inquiry is the shift, even within the funds available for rural research, from on-farm research to post-farm gate research. Again, if we recognise the importance of maintaining sustainable agriculture, it is important that the emphasis on on-farm research is retained and its priority restored.

It is interesting that the committee noted the importance of the levies which primary producers pay on the ad valorem value of their produce to provide funds for rural research, not only to CSIRO but through the various rural industry research and development corporations to universities, state departments of agriculture, and so on. Certainly, a significant part of CSIRO's funds comes from those levies but no equivalent levy is placed on manufacturing industry or other industry sectors. One of the conclusions of the committee is that some mechanism should be found to encourage manufacturing and information technology industries to contribute more to research in their particular industry sectors. Whether it is practical to apply levies to those industries is debateable but, certainly, a mechanism needs to be found to ensure that a much higher level of contribution from those industry sectors goes to CSIRO. I conclude on the funding issue by saying simply that the committee has found that CSIRO must reinstate the high priority ranking of rural research and ensure that its share of appropriation funding—funding from the government's own budget to rural research—is increased commensurate with that ranking.

The committee also looked very closely at the restructuring proposals for the Institute of Animal and Plant Production, particularly looking at the decisions which CSIRO had taken to sell a number of its research stations or field stations which are critical to the capacity of CSIRO to maintain its research efforts with regard to rural industry. Virtually without exception, we have recommended that the decisions taken by CSIRO—some of which have already been reversed in the course of our inquiry, largely as a result of the evidence given to the committee—be rescinded and that those research stations be retained.

In particular, we have recommended that the Division of Wool Technology postpone any decision to amalgamate its two laboratories until the future direction of the wool industry and funding from that industry becomes clearer. We have recommended the retention of the site and infrastructure at Long Pocket in Brisbane. We have also recommended the retention of the properties at Armidale, which go under the names of Longford and Arding, for the particular benefits that they provide to the animal industries. Also—this pleases Senator Panizza no end—we have recommended that the Yalanbee research station in Western Australia, with its Mediterranean climate farming research, also be retained.

During the course of the inquiry, CSIRO tried to fudge the fact that it had taken decisions for sale, saying they were only recommendations for consideration, but the clear evidence was that decisions for sale were taken. We believe that those decisions were very short-sighted, not only because they would have meant the loss of the future benefit to rural industry of those research stations but also because in many instances CSIRO would have gained nothing from the sales.

As we conducted our inquiry it became clear that a number of those research stations had been purchased with funds provided by the wool industry, the wheat industry, or by some other rural industry funds. In fact, had they been sold, most of the money derived from the sales would have had to go back to those industry funds rather than directly into the pocket of CSIRO. So CSIRO would not have gained any capital out of the sales and, in most instances, would not have achieved any great operating savings either. We believe that our recommendations were valid. As I said, it is pleasing that, by and large, CSIRO has already adopted those recommendations and has agreed not to sell those properties.

Another issue of importance to funding is that of counter-cyclical funding. When there is a downturn in rural industry and a downturn in returns to farmers, there is a consequential downturn in the income available through the research levies that farmers pay. To offset that, there should be a consequential increase in appropriation funding provided by the government through its budget. While it is difficult to formulate an easy formula for how the principle of counter-cyclical funding should be applied, the committee found that it should apply and that a strategy was required to assist those industries most vulnerable to wide fluctuations in research levy income. Whatever scheme is introduced—whether it is based on a rolling average or a system whereby rural industry research funds can accumulate reserves from which to borrow in periods of economic downturn—we believe it is essential that some form of counter-cyclical funding is made available.

The next issue to which attention was addressed was external funding. Since 1989 the federal government has required CSIRO to achieve a funding target of 30 per cent from external sources. There are certain difficulties with this. Most importantly, it is possible for CSIRO to lose control of the direction of its research. There is an administrative difficulty in that many scientists find they are spending more time obtaining grants and satisfying reporting requirements to the external bodies providing those grants than actually undertaking the scientific research itself. Therefore, there are significant shortcomings with regard to the principle of external funding. In fact, while the overall target for CSIRO of external funding is 30 per cent, we found that in some areas it was averaging over 50 per cent and, in an even smaller number of areas, 100 per cent, which, of course, made the job of scientists extremely difficult.

External funding also brings us back to the issue of fundamental, basic or pure science research as against applied research, which I mentioned earlier. Certainly, there is a tendency in the move towards externally sourced funding for research to become more applied and less fundamental and basic. While applied research is obviously very important, as I pointed out earlier, particularly with regard to primary industry, basic and fundamental research and the maintenance of effort in that field is also of great importance.

The final issue that I want to deal with is communication. The committee found a number of shortcomings in the communication skills of the CSIRO. The CSIRO has a number of responsibilities as far as communication is concerned: it must communicate to the general public; it must communicate to the stakeholders, that is, under the external funding provisions, those people who are actually putting in the research funding up to or greater than the 30 per cent level; and it must communicate internally with its own research scientists and staff. In each of those areas we found significant shortcomings in communication skills.

In particular, reputable journalists told us that it was very difficult to get positive stories out of CSIRO because of the maze of bureaucracy which had to be negotiated before approval could be obtained for particular details of a story to be released. Certainly, it is important that that bureaucratic approach to the release of information, which can provide a source of beneficial stories as far as CSIRO is concerned, is removed.

As some honourable senators have said in the debate today on this report, CSIRO has always been regarded as the pinnacle of scientific effort in Australia—an icon in the Australian community. It was sad that during the course of our inquiry it became clear that today many farmers and, indeed, peak farming organisations cannot name one benefit that they are currently obtaining from CSIRO. Going back 10 or 20 years, farmers could name benefit after benefit that they had obtained from the research undertaken by CSIRO and yet today they cannot do that. Again, it shows a dramatic shortcoming in the communication capacity of CSIRO today which obviously needs to be addressed.

With regard to internal communication, the fact that this matter had to be referred to a committee in order to highlight many of the shortcomings in administration, structure and funding of CSIRO and the fact that we received so many submissions from CSIRO scientists and staff themselves, again shows the failure of the senior levels of CSIRO to communicate adequately with the staff and scientists. Clearly, this is an area where experienced and skilled communicators—people with journalistic and other communication skills—need to be employed by CSIRO specifically to fulfil the role of communication so that the general public's image of CSIRO is maintained and therefore pressure can be maintained on the government for adequate funding; so that its stakeholders can continue to provide funds; and so that its employees retain confidence in the organisation.

CSIRO has a history of being a very highly regarded organisation in Australia but that regard is somewhat tarnished as a result of shortcomings not only on the part of the government in respect of the funding that it has been providing in recent years and the direction that it has provided to CSIRO but also because of obvious problems with regard to the internal structure and management of CSIRO. This report has highlighted those, it has delved into them in great detail and its recommendations, I believe, are worthy of adoption. The fact that this is a multi-partisan unanimous report simply adds strength to that.

I urge the government to adopt these recommendations to ensure that CSIRO maintains its paramount position in the Australian scientific community. In particular, the recommendations should be adopted to ensure that the benefits to be derived from a continuing high priority to rural research not only for rural producers and farmers but for the whole community through the export earnings generated are maintained and increased in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994
This bill reflects the continuing commitment of this Government to securing legitimate title to traditional lands on behalf of the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory.

The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 provides a mechanism whereby traditional Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory referred to in Schedule 1 of that Act may be granted to Aboriginal Land Trusts to hold title on behalf of Aboriginal people. Since the Act came into operation in 1977 a total of 58 separate parcels of land have been scheduled under the Act.

Mr President, the effect of this bill would be to bring within the Schedule to the Land Rights Act that area of land which is the subject of the Hodgson Downs Land Claim. The Northern Territory Government, the Northern Land Council and Claimants in the Land Claim have entered into an agreement which settles that Land Claim. As part of that agreement the Northern Territory Government agreed to request the Commonwealth to exercise its powers under the Land Rights Act to grant the claim area, excluding the Hodgson River road and the Miniyeri Community access road, to the traditional owners by scheduling that area under the Land Rights Act. The result of such scheduling would be that no further hearing or report by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner would then be necessary in order for the Aboriginal people concerned to be able to have the full rights of enjoyment of their traditional lands in fee simple.
Mr President, the Government has the assurance of all parties to the negotiations that representative views of all Aboriginal people concerned have been obtained and their wishes taken into account.
There are no financial implications arising from this bill.
I now present the explanatory memorandum.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS AMENDMENT BILL 1994

Honourable senators will be aware that on 1 March 1994 parliament passed a package of seven agricultural and veterinary chemical acts. Commencement of those acts is dependent on the States and Northern Territory passing legislation adopting the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code (AGVET Code), and thereby commencing the national registration scheme for agricultural and veterinary chemicals.

Five states, including the Northern Territory, have passed the necessary legislation. It is by no means certain, however, that the other two states will pass their legislation by 15 March 1995, which is the legislated commencement date for the AGVET Code.

As a contingency, it is therefore proposed to extend that date to 1 July 1995 and thus provide additional time for the remaining two states to pass their legislation. The AGVET Code can of course be proclaimed to commence at any time before then, once the state legislation is in place.
I commend the bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.
ARCHIVES AMENDMENT BILL 1994
The Archives Amendment Bill 1994 will make amendments of a minor policy nature to the Archives Act 1983.

The Australian Archives plays an important role in ensuring that the history of Government in Australia is preserved and is available for access by future generations of Australians. These amendments are intended to clarify the application of the Archives Act to two types of records namely the records of Government Business Enterprises and other commercialised bodies and the records of the National Witness Protection Program.

The proposed amendments will not have any significant financial impact. However, the amendments relating to Government Business Enterprises will result in indirect savings through improved efficiency in the process associated with the commercialisation, incorporation and sale of Government bodies.

The first category of amendments concern the application of the Archives Act to Government Business Enterprises. In the last few years, the Commonwealth has been reviewing the structure and operations of Government Business Enterprises. As a result, a number of these bodies have been commercialised, incorporated or privatised in order to improve the efficiency of their operations.

Unfortunately, the method used to incorporate or privatise these bodies in the last few years has resulted in problems for the Australian Archives. The first is that legislation used to privatise or corporatise the Government Enterprise has, on several occasions, had the effect that the body was no longer subject to the Archives Act.

The second problem is that a particular legislative process used to incorporate bodies also had the effect of removing all the pre-incorporation records of the body from the operation of the Archives Act. As a result of this process, the Australian Archives has lost control of the pre-incorporation records of bodies such as the Commonwealth Bank, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, the International Wool Commission and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation.

The amendments concerning Government Business Enterprises are intended to prevent the inadvertent removal of records from the operation of the Archives Act as a consequence of a change in structure of certain bodies. To this end, the bill provides for:
bodies that are either established for a public purpose or subject to Commonwealth control to remain subject to the Archives Act unless specifically excluded from the operation of the Act; and
the prior records of bodies which are subsequently removed from the application of the Archives Act to also remain subject to the Act unless specifically excluded from its application.
These amendments will preserve established statutory rights of access to records of national significance or public interest.

It should be recognised that the bill will not prevent the transfer of Commonwealth records where the Government decides this is necessary. The amendments provide for the Government to preclude the application of the Archives Act to commercial government bodies either by means of the legislation relating to the incorporation of sale of the body or by an amendment to the regulations to the Archives Act.
The bill will not apply to bodies that were excluded from the application of the Archives Act prior to the commencement of these amendments.

The second category of amendments concern the application of the Archives Act to the records of the National Witness Protection Program. Earlier this year the Government enacted the National Witness Protection Act 1994. This Act provides a legislative basis for a program run by the Australian Federal Police which is designed to facilitate the provision of high level witness protection, including the issuing of alternative identity documents for protected witnesses.
This bill makes special provision for access to and custody of records of the National Witness Protection Program. The bill:

permits the Australian Federal Police to retain custody of certain sensitive documents relating to the National Witness Protection Program rather than requiring those records to be transferred to the Australian Archives;
ensures that certain highly sensitive documents relating to the National Witness Protection Program are exempted from public disclosure under the Archives Act; and

makes specific provision for the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, or a staff member associated with the National Witness Protection Program, to provide documents and or evidence to a private hearing of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill and commend the bill to the Senate.
BROADCASTING SERVICES AMENDMENT BILL 1994

The Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill 1994 seeks to amend section 115 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. Section 115 deals with subscription television broadcasting services and the protection of the free availability of certain types of television programs.

To obtain a full understanding of the operation of the provisions, section 115 must be read in conjunction with paragraph 10(1)(e) of Schedule 2 to the Act. Paragraph 10(1)(e) prohibits subscription television licensees from acquiring the right to broadcast a listed event unless a national broadcaster or commercial television broadcasting licensee has acquired the right to broadcast that event.
Subscription television services, or pay TV services as they are more commonly known, hold the promise of expanding the range of television programs available to Australian viewers.

Satellite subscription television licensees have indicated that they will be broadcasting services devoted to movies, children's programming, news, documentaries, sports and music. This will reflect experience overseas. For example, in the United Kingdom, subscribers enjoy many services including news, sports, movies, travel and "lifestyle" shows, and children's programs.

Of course, not everyone in Australia will want to, or may be able to afford to, subscribe to pay TV. It is for this reason that Parliament included the provisions contained in section 115 which empower the Minister to publish in the Gazette any event of a kind that, in the opinion of the Minister, should be available free to the general public.

On 31 May of this year the Minister for Communications and the Arts announced details of a list of events he had specified under section 115 of the Act in order to ensure that Australian television viewers continued to see the most popular sporting events free of charge.
The list of events is contained in the Broadcasting Services (Events) Notice No. 1 of 1994, which was gazetted on 6 July 1994 and tabled in both Houses of Parliament on 23 August 1994.
