We feel it would be foolish for the Commonwealth government to sponsor ventures for two years only to have them fail at the end of that time.

—The Democrats will be supporting these amendments for two reasons. Firstly, we believe that a time limit is, in fact, arbitrary. It might as well be one day or ten years. It does not really matter in time. The real measurements are something else. The measurements are the capacity of the person, the nature of the business plan and the proposition and the capacity of the enterprise to be sustainable and to continue in a viable fashion. Such judgments are not necessarily related to time.

PARA.TAB: I mentioned in previous discussion that there are some famous enterprises in Australia which existed for a few years. Nevertheless, questions were asked about their viability during that period—sometimes unfashionable questions asked about the viability of some of the enterprises of the mid-1980s. Eventually they proved to be non-viable; in fact, disastrous. Time had nothing to do with that. It was the very speculative nature of the business itself. So time is not necessarily a good measurement of the viability of a business.

Secondly, if we are to have a time period then it ought to be flexible and long enough. I agree with Senator Margetts's description that people with disadvantages and disabilities may need time to be involved in learning how to operate a business and how to make themselves employable by themselves. Because of their very disability and disadvantage, the first 12 months could well be spent in learning those lessons, leaving no time to demonstrate the viability of the enterprise. So we believe that a longer time is more desirable if we are to have a time. So for that reason we will support the amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes these amendments for the same reasons that it opposed Senator Margetts's amendments 4 to 7, noting that parallel amendments to the Employment Services Bill have been rejected by the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The youth training allowance is aimed at helping young people become financially self-sufficient. Clients receiving the allowance are between 15 and 17 years old and financial self-sufficiency for these people almost always means participation in paid employment. The government, therefore, considers it is not appropriate to liberalise the conditions under which youth training allowance is paid for alternatives to paid employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that information, but is it not true, when we say up to 12 months, that there is actually a requirement that people on this kind of self-employment under this scheme are required to do a course of six months minimum?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is not true.
—Perhaps the minister could outline for us what are the parameters for being involved in this area. I am surprised at the latest bit of information. What is the situation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The client must have been receiving the youth training allowance continuously for six months.

—Has the minister not just said exactly what I said, which is that the youth training allowance requires that youth be in training? That is what the youth training allowance is supposed to be. Therefore, if they have to be on the youth training allowance for six months at the same time as they are getting a business going, how can they make sure they get a viable business in the clear six months they have left?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, they have to be in training or receiving the jobsearch allowance.
—As done previously, I ask that the votes of me and my colleague Senator Chamarette be recorded as a yes vote.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 10Clause 18, page 69, proposed section 124, omit lines 17 to 20, substitute the following:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Double benefit payment on release from gaol or psychiatric confinement

TAB.TAB: (a)a person is released from gaol or psychiatric confinement after spending at least 7 days in gaol or in psychiatric confinement; and".

SPEECH.PARA: In this case, we have accepted the suggestions of the government to alternative wording and have revised our amendment. This amendment is a minor amendment to correct the anomaly in subclauses 124(a), (b) and (c) where, after release from gaol, people can get back-paid for the payment they missed. However, there is no same way of dealing with psychiatric confinement, although both are specified in subclauses 123(a) and (b) as having the youth training allowance suspended after admission into gaol or psychiatric confinement. It is not fair to back-pay one and not the other, especially if the psychiatric confinement has been voluntary and in accordance with the wishes of the young person who is under temporary mental hardship.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we passed amendment No. 1 on behalf of the government, is the amendment now being moved by Senator Margetts exactly parallel to it?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to cover that point in my comments. It is not exactly the same. Senator Margetts's staff indicated that Senator Margetts's amendment was to make proposed section 124 parallel to proposed section 123. The government has agreed to this. This was addressed in the government's amendments. As it stands, Senator Margetts's amendment is too wide. It does not merely apply to cases dealt with in proposed section 123 but applies to anyone released after psychiatric confinement.
—In that case, the opposition will be opposing this amendment.
—I seek some clarification from the minister. Does that mean that government amendment No. 1, which the Senate recently passed, makes amendment No. 10 redundant, or does it refine it?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —We understand that Senator Margetts's amendment is now broader than our amendment No. 1. But in discussions with Senator Margetts's staff—I do not say that there is anything untoward in this—we have come to the belief that our amendment No. 1 addresses Senator Margetts's concern.
—I will accept that. I thank the minister.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that amendment No. 11 may be withdrawn. I seek clarification from Senator Margetts.

—The revised amendments have removed amendment No. 11 because of the definitions. This is perhaps one of the best indications of the benefit of the Senate. During discussions, the Greens put forward amendments with regard to definitions of independence and the away from home rates. The Australian Democrats also put forward amendments. I believe that Senator Troeth has also done work in amending them once again and gained the consensus of all parties. It is the way that the Senate should work. I believe that there are amendments by Senator Troeth to deal with those definitions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That process will work only if the agreements originally reached are honoured. We have already had a stunning example of original agreements not being honoured. I proposed on behalf of the Australian Democrats an amendment which set about defining independence and so forth. Senator Margetts withdrew in favour of ours. I recognise the superiority of the proposition put by the coalition. If Senator Margetts withdraws her amendments, I withdraw ours and we favour the coalition amendment, it will work. But it will not work if we see a petulant display by the advisers in trying to override what is proposed here.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—I take it that you are withdrawing your amendments at this time?

TALK.START.PARA: —Simply put, that is so.

PARA.TAB: Request (by Senator Troeth) proposed:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:
Clause 18, page 219, proposed Schedule 1, subclause 2(11),omit the subclause, substitute the following subclause:
"(11) A person is independent if that person:

TAB.TAB: (a)does not live, and for a continuous period of at least 18 weeks has not lived, at a home of the parents, or of a parent, of the person; and
(b)has, at a time when the person was not living at such a home:
(i)been employed for at least 20 hours per week; or
(ii)been registered by the Commonwealth Employment Service in an allowance category as being unemployed;

PARA.TAB: for the period of, or for periods that total, at least 13 weeks; and

TAB.TAB: (c)does not receive regular financial support from a parent of the person.".

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the proposition that has been put forward.
—Why?
—I am just about to go through it.
—I would like to hear it.

—Be patient. The government has noted the consistent position of the opposition parties with regard to extending the qualifying period of the independent criteria from 18 weeks to 26 weeks. The government has explained that it has increased benefits by the establishment of an away from home rate. The opposition has indicated that it does not accept this view.

PARA.TAB: In a spirit of compromise, the government therefore decided, albeit reluctantly, to present an amendment which would retain the 18-week criteria for unsupported young people participating in the work force. The government does not support the opposition's view that 13 weeks registration with the CES within an 18-week period should qualify a person as being independent, given that an away from home rate is also available.

The government is taking a responsible position on this issue, because including the 13 weeks registration means that young people would merely have to leave home for 18 weeks, irrespective of whether they were supported by their parents, to become independent. This may encourage more young people to leave home in order to qualify.

Concerns already exist within the community that the existing jobsearch allowance encourages young people to leave home and causes family breakdown. Since the current JSA independence criteria was introduced in 1992, the proportion of 15- to 17-year-old recipients of the independent rate increased from six per cent to nine per cent of all 15- to 17-year-old JSA recipients. The new away from home rate will assist those young people who legitimately need to live away from home to undertake training or search for a job. This rate is subject to the parental means test. However, the minimum payment of $62.90 per fortnight is also available. The away from home rate is subject only to standard waiting periods.

The opposition amendment does not require young people to be unsupported during the 18-week period to be entitled to claim the independent rate after 18 weeks away from home. They would only have to establish that they were unsupported from 18 weeks onwards. This creates a situation where a young person may claim the away from home rate to support themselves during the 18-week qualification period and can then transfer to the independent rate thereafter. In addition, young people who are homeless will receive the independent rate and will not have to serve a waiting period.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few explanatory comments about our requested amendment. Firstly, about a week ago I did request some costings from the department on the implementation of this amendment. Although a lot of water has flowed under the bridge since then, we have had no indication whatever of any costings. As I tend to take a rational economic view of life, I would have been extremely interested to see some of those costings in order to see what they were talking about. But absolutely nothing has been produced. So I am still in the dark totally as to what this will cost.

PARA.TAB: However, as we indicated at the non-existent briefings that took place, we also established that it was a relatively small number of people who would be affected by this. As I will indicate in my ensuing remarks, the fact is that it is a small number of children, which is what they are, in this age group who will be affected. But if the government goes ahead with its proposals, the proposals still have the capacity to inflict a fair degree of misery, I feel, if it is not taken back to the 18 weeks with the other proposals that we talk about.

For eligibility under the jobsearch allowance, persons were required to live out of the family home for at least 18 weeks and to have been employed for at least 20 hours a week for 13 of those weeks or to have been registered as unemployed with the Commonwealth Employment Service. In the light of the government's new proposals, I would like to refresh the memory of the government as to whom the independent rate is supposed to be assisting.

The independent rate is for young people who, for whatever reason, feel that they can no longer live in the family home. These people may not have experienced sexual or severe physical abuse and there may not have been severe family breakdown. However, there is a compelling reason that makes the young person feel that it is no longer possible to live at home. They make a decision to leave home, they know that they will have to live away for 4 1/2 months—18 weeks—at least before they will receive any form of Commonwealth financial assistance.

I remind parliament that it is a condition of the independent rate that during this four months they receive no financial or non-financial support from their parents. If they cannot get a job, they will be without any income whatsoever during this time. Yet they still feel so strongly that they cannot live at home that they are prepared to put up with this situation.

The government is now proposing to raise the waiting time to 26 weeks, and I accept what it said in some of its amendments. It is six months that a young person is supposed to survive without any form of income. Apparently forgetting the atrocious unemployment rate that the government has created in Australia, it is proposing that if that person is not in paid employment for at least half of that time, then they will be ineligible for the allowance. If the person is one of the hundreds of thousands of unemployed at risk of becoming long-term unemployed, then they will not qualify for this unemployment benefit.

In the past the coalition has been outspoken about the need not to create an artificial incentive for young people to leave home. We were very critical of the situation with the youth homeless allowance earlier this year when many parents expressed their concern that the payment was inducing their children to move out. We still are concerned about this. We strongly believe that young people should be encouraged to remain in the family home and that there should be no artificial inducement to leave home.

The government has been claiming that the new away from home allowance is in place of, or will alleviate, any disadvantages of the stricter requirements. This is totally false and misleading. Firstly, the away from home allowance will be available only to those persons who are required to move away from home to participate in a stipulated training program. It would be extremely unlikely that any person living in a capital city or major regional centre would be eligible for this allowance.

Secondly, those persons who are eligible are subject to a parental means and assets test as strict as that currently applying to Austudy. This has two consequences. Students from rural areas, who are those most likely to qualify for the allowance, if they live on a farm will be beset by the same problems currently facing rural students attempting to get Austudy. They will generally be disqualified on the basis of the asset value of their farm, regardless of whether or not the farm has been producing an income.

Also, eligible students who have to live away from home will be receiving a reduced allowance on the basis of their parents' income and assets regardless of whether or not their parents actually provide them with financial support. Another factor that I would like to present for the committee's attention is that the age range of the people affected by this problem is in the 15- to 17-year age group. We are looking at people who are 15, 16 or 17. They are not going to stay on this allowance forever. It is a comparatively short time that they will be affected and that the government will be paying out for them.

For heaven's sake, it is about time we looked at the real situation of these people and looked at what they have to contend with. When they are 18, they move on to something else. It is not a long-term problem. The proposed change in the independent rate eligibility by the government, even given the fact that it has conceded, I believe, that 18 weeks is fairer, is unnecessary, unfair and will, the coalition believes, further disadvantage an already disadvantaged group of young people who have suffered greatly as a direct result of Labor policies. Therefore, I commend the coalition amendment to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we heard from Senator Troeth was a sensible explanation of the reasons for moving the amendment. Before you took the chair, Mr Temporary Chairman, Senator Margetts and I had indicated our ascending deference to a better amendment, starting with one amendment, moving to another and finally arriving at that point. We were able to see the sense of it.

PARA.TAB: In a meeting which has been described as a non-existent briefing or at least non-resolving, we heard the reasons that the minister restated. Again before you took the chair, I had difficulty in restraining myself from insisting that the minister give reasons as to why the government would not be supporting this properly sensible amendment. We did not get in the meeting which we held with departmental staff a reason which was superior to those advanced by Senator Troeth.

I was amazed to hear a restatement of the excuses that have been given for arriving at the government proposal, a proposal which does not recognise that the living away from home benefit and the independent benefit will be received by two different sets of people. The benefit which accrues to one will not necessarily pass along to the other. But the government has a view that there is a sort of conveyor belt, that a person starts off on the away from home allowance, trundles along and arrives at a prize of independence.

As Senator Troeth has described the real world, one benefit will accrue to people who are engaged in one sort of activity and the other benefit will eventually, after a great struggle, arrive for another group of people not engaged in the same thing. The away from home allowance will most likely benefit young people from rural areas. It is unlikely that young people from capital cities will be able to justify living away from home on the basis of needing to live in a certain place to attend a certain course.

The independent rate will arrive after a demonstrated period of independence. I will illustrate the ridiculousness of the tests for independence. Under the definition of not having received financial or non-financial support from parents for six months, I do not think I would be independent. Over 40 years, I cannot demonstrate that I have had a period of time longer than six months without having received some support. It would now come from my in-laws; my parents are both dead. It was only a couple of weeks ago that my mother-in-law arrived with a cake and a bucket of vegetables.

Let us be sensible about this. How many young people who are independent, establishing their own home and living away from their parents can honestly say that they have had no support whatsoever for six months? What sort of society would we be living in if that sort of thing happened? Of course that is how the real world works—parents visit their children and continue to support them well into adulthood. In my case, I am pleased to say that the relationship I had with both my parents and which continues with my in-laws is one of a close family where I would not like to say that I was so independent that I had not received some sort of support in my endeavours.

It could be taken to the extreme by saying that child care by grandmothers for young people is some sort of non-financial support. It is ridiculous to put this sort of thing in legislation, and it is ridiculous to ignore what happens when people move out of home for the first time to establish their own premises and independence.

Let us look at the reality. I think Senator Troeth is quite right to say that these measures are not suitable. The government is insisting that its view of the world is right—and I say it is the departmental advisers' view of the world, rather than the philosophical view which the government has taken. I have read a couple of quotes of what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) sees as the government's role in supporting young people in these endeavours.

I do not think this legislation reflects the opinion that the Prime Minister expressed. It reflects a bureaucratic version of the world; it does not reflect the enlightened view that the Prime Minister proposed in his speeches announcing the youth training initiative. If the government wants people to applaud what the Prime Minister has announced—and it sounds good—it needs to recognise that this improvement proposed by Senator Troeth brings about what the Prime Minister was talking about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a brief comment. It has occurred to me over the last few days when debating the employment legislation—and, in particular, the student assistance youth training allowance—the responses we are getting from the government in regard to such things as flexibility, negotiation and reasonableness indicate very strongly that, if the voting age were 16, these bills would not be delivered in this form. I would like to remind the government that, in two years time, these 16-year-olds will be old enough to vote, and they will clearly know what the government has done for them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment further. The government, in a spirit of compromise, offered to reduce the period from 26 weeks to 18 weeks. That was in our first amendment, which the opposition voted against and we were defeated on. We were a little surprised at the opposition's position on that; nevertheless, that was defeated, but we did offer it as a compromise.

PARA.TAB: Senator Troeth has asserted that the away rate is available only if a young person has to live away from home to undertake training. That is not correct. The away from home rate is also available for jobsearch.

Senator Troeth has made some assertions about not being contacted about the costings. I am advised that an officer of the department attempted to arrange meetings with Senator Troeth or with her staff, and also with Dr Kemp. We have the costings available. This will cost the government an estimated $3.8 million over the next four years. I do not want to get into an argument about who said what to whom or meetings that did not take place or should have taken place. All I can say is that, in good faith, we wanted to pass those figures on to Senator Troeth. I do not know why that did not occur, but the officers believe they acted in good faith in attempting that.

Senator Troeth says she is an economic rationalist. I am still waiting for the economic rationalist's explanation as to how we are supposed to reduce the budget deficit when the Senate keeps increasing expenditure and the opposition, in particular, keeps saying that it is not going to agree to any tax increases. It is a fascinating position to be in. I hope that at the next election the electorate wreaks the appropriate revenge on the opposition's amazing position.

We do not accept the comment by Senator Bell that this issue primarily affects young rural people and not young urban people. We think it is nonsense that Senator Bell can differentiate in that way. There is no evidence that people who live in urban areas will not apply in the same way that people in rural areas would. I conclude by reading a case of a young person who is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . sixteen and fed up with living with her parents because of the strict rules they try and enforce. She applies for the away from home rate of YTA so that she could leave home and stay with friends several suburbs away but is not eligible as employment prospects are not improved by moving. She is told that she can qualify for the independent rate once she has been out of home for 18 weeks so she decides to leave anyway and try to survive on her own, on the minimum payment of $62.90 per fortnight.

The opposition has attacked the government fairly consistently about these types of measures leading to the break-up of the family. The opposition is now supporting amendments that destroy its argument and position.

PARA.TAB: I got two letters about this issue on my desk two weeks ago. I am going to write back and say, `Write to Senator Troeth and the opposition. Let the opposition explain why they are, in their own words and their own position, attempting to encourage people to leave home.' We will be very happy to refer those people on to the opposition, because its stance is in direct contrast to the position that it has adopted in recent times.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to place on the record once and for all that, after our initial request for costings, no further mention was made by the government or its advisers of costings that were available. Mention was made of further briefings. They were simply to go over the same ground that we had gone over at the initial briefings, and we were not interested in doing that. There were no further instances of costings being provided or any figures on that, so I refute that.

PARA.TAB: Also, Senator Sherry should know that any true economic rationalist also has a dash of compassion, and that is what we are trying to put forward in this amendment. The government has made the laws under which it is possible for students to leave home. We are simply trying to inject a note of reality into this debate by saying that if these 15-, 16- and 17-year-olds are put in these invidious positions, they should be allowed to access the allowances that the government made six weeks earlier with other conditions applying. I would be very happy to justify the coalition's position to any of those people Senator Sherry mentioned in his remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to illustrate to the parliamentary secretary how I reached this position without surveys and the benefit of charts and diagrams from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Drawing from what I know about young people and employment prospects, it seems to me to be fairly self-evident that, if the government has legislation—which we have been unable to amend—stating that it is reasonable to ask people to commute for 90 minutes to attend training courses and to engage in job compacts, it would follow that the away from home rate would not be available to anybody who is within 90 minutes of a training course.

PARA.TAB: It would also follow that if the main eligibility factor for the away from home rate was having to leave home to attend a course, it would not be easy for a metropolitan student to qualify. A metropolitan person applying for this rate would be able to find a training course for just about anything in 90 minutes of commuting within a major metropolitan area.

However, that is not the case for rural people. People living in our country towns would most likely be able to demonstrate the need to move away from home to attend a training course and therefore claim the away from home rate. Surely the parliamentary secretary understands that there are young people in Devonport who would want to go to Hobart to participate in particular training courses—he spends a considerable amount of his time there—and that other parts of Australia would immediately leap to his mind as being rural places where people would need to leave home to attend the training courses.

In relation to the other debates we have had, none of the information that has been given here convinces me that we are doing the wrong thing by proposing that people who are independent—who are not living with their parents—should be able to qualify for the away from home rate after 18 weeks of independent living and receive recognition for that status at that time. I do not believe that the case study read to us proved one thing or another. It said that, like many 16-year-olds, a certain girl wanted to leave home and qualify for the away from home rate. She was denied that for the very thing I have just described. Yet she persisted, wanting to be independent.

Whether someone in that situation would be successful is another matter. But it does not alter or change our position that 18 weeks is a more appropriate demonstration of independent living than 26 weeks. Quite rightly, whoever was involved in that case study determined that the person was not eligible for the away from home rate. This proves my first point, that this measure is not a conveyer belt; it is not an easy way of qualifying for the independent rate. The case study the parliamentary secretary read demonstrates what I have been saying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the matter of briefings, the officers advise me that if Senator Troeth had taken up the offer of briefings we would have given her the costings.
—Are we supposed to be telepathic?

—No. I am just indicating to Senator Troeth that if she had accepted the offer of further briefings—it was not just to go over old ground—we would have given her the costings. There is no great secret about them. As for the issue of budget deficit and compassion, what is another $3.8 million on the deficit to opposition senators? What does it matter to them?
—Nothing.

—Of course it does not matter to them. When parties are in the airy fairy position of not having any policies or leadership, taking a position of not increasing taxes and just increasing expenditure all the time, what does it matter to them? Frankly, it means nothing. The opposition does not have any responsibility for care. It can wrap this matter up in compassion but the government has to wrap it up in responsibility. But we will slug this issue out in the electorate before the next election, just as we will slug out the other issues to which I referred earlier.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPPORTED ACCOMMODATION ASSISTANCE BILL 1994SUPPORTED ACCOMMODATION ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 16 November, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, today we have before the Senate two bills, the Supported Accommodation Assistance Bill 1994 and the Supported Accommodation Assistance Amendment Bill 1994. The Supported Accommodation Assistance Bill 1994 is a substantial and significant piece of legislation which fully deserves the scrutiny of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Scrutiny of this bill gave rise to some serious concerns on this side of parliament which have already been reflected on by two of my colleagues in the other place, Dr Michael Wooldridge, the shadow minister for community services, and Mr Philip Ruddock, the shadow minister for social security. We condemn the Labor government for: weakening the bill; failing to specify any structures for accountable and measured outcomes; neglecting the importance of long-term, secure and affordable housing; and failing to develop appropriate services in rural and remote communities.

The SAAP bill we are debating provides an additional $18.8 million over four years to significantly reform the way in which assistance is provided to people who are homeless or at risk of being homeless. In 1994-95, excluding this additional assistance, SAAP's total allocation is $185 million, of which $105 million will come from the Commonwealth. The break-up of the additional assistance in this bill is: for 1994-95, $3.9 million; for 1995-96, $4.8 million; for 1996-97, $4.9 million; and for 1997-98, $5 million.

The legislative framework of SAAP mark III was based on the government document SAAP: Strategic Directions, which reflects the strategies and objectives of the senior officials group. It was largely bureaucratically driven with little or no consultation within the community. The bill redefines the terms `people who are homeless' and `homeless' for the purposes of this program; restates the purposes and objectives of the supported accommodation assistance program and the services expected of service providers; and specifies the key matters to be included in SAAP agreements between the Commonwealth and the states.

The key matters listed in clause 8 include: implementing case management; developing assessment and referral mechanisms for SAAP clients; introducing early intervention and outreach; enhancing the skills of service provider staff; strengthening links between service sectors; program management; allowing for the protection of client rights; measuring outcomes; and reporting and accountability.

The bill establishes the Commonwealth Advisory Committee on Homelessness, CACH, the members of which will have expertise and understanding of the principal issues effecting homelessness. The Commonwealth advisory committee will advise the minister on matters referred to it by the minister. The other major provision of the bill is the establishment of a national SAAP coordination and development committee—known at the moment as the senior officers group—as a condition of the new SAAP agreement between the Commonwealth and the states.

Is this not starting to look as though the government is using this bill to subtly assume control over the direction of SAAP? Perhaps more importantly we should be asking whether it is using this bill to expand the scope so widely that service providers will be providing many services at less than optimum efficiency rather than delivering more tightly focused assistance with the greatest possible benefit.

At the Senate estimates hearings on 15 November, officers of the Department of Housing and Regional Development, in answer to my questions concerning the allocation of additional SAAP funding, revealed:

SPEECH.PARA: None of the money will go to expand the number of existing services. All of the money will go to improving service delivery. Some of that money will be expended on salaries in services, other monies will be expended on improving data collection processes and on a range of best practice service which we may be setting up.
There is also no commitment from the Commonwealth or the states to incorporate growth funds into any agreements for SAAP mark III.

PARA.TAB: The preamble to a bill, if one is included at all, is supposed to set out simply the broad intentions of the bill as a guide to subsequent interpretation of the main body of the act. The preamble to this bill attempts to give to a statement of policy the standing of a declaration of law. It makes a statement about empowering homeless people to maximise their independence. It cites certain international agreements and treaties as mandating this legislation. We on this side of the chamber have grave concerns about the way this government is making international treaties and agreements central to its social policies.

In his second reading speech, the minister, Mr Howe, alluded, albeit briefly, to the 1995 United Nations International Year of Tolerance. I understand that the government intends to undertake an awareness campaign to increase the community's understanding of homelessness. This national community education program will be funded from the 1994-95 additional allocation. The additional allocation of funds will go to three areas: improving data collection; implementing case management; and a national awareness campaign on homelessness in 1995.

In my speech today I urge the Senate to condemn the government for: weakening the strength of the bill; failing to specific any structures for accountable and measured outcomes; neglecting the importance of affordable housing options; and failing to ensure the development of appropriate services in rural and remote communities.

Nobody knows exactly how many homeless people there are in Australia today, but it is obvious that there are too many people in dire and desperate straits. A recent report by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare found: every night, approximately 11,500 people seek accommodation in shelters and refuges; only 17 per cent of families and sole parents requesting assistance are able to find accommodation; one in three homeless people seeking government assisted accommodation is fleeing domestic violence; and only 23 per cent of requests by young homeless people are successfully met. What damning evidence!

The department of housing, which commissioned the report as part of its evaluation of SAAP, played down the significance of these findings, saying that it was `very sceptical' about the figures and questioning the validity of the data. The bill does nothing to address those disgraceful statistics.

The report also mentioned that by far the greater proportion of service provision is concentrated in major centres of population. This would imply an underservicing of regional and rural areas, particularly if people from these areas are drifting to the cities to find support. Most studies report that the incidence of homelessness will worsen over the coming decade. So, unfortunately, homelessness will increase.

Not all people who become homeless gain access to crisis accommodation. The National Inquiry into the Human Rights of People with Mental Illness reported that Aboriginal people, young people, and women with children who have a mental illness, and those with dual or multiple disabilities, are particularly disadvantaged in accessing crisis accommodation.

The actual level of unmet demand for women escaping domestic violence and sexual abuse is difficult to assess because shortages in medium-term supported accommodation place added strain on short-term services. Women's refuges are designed to meet short-term needs only and were not intended to provide for the needs of women and children whose unmet need for a longer term alternative results in the disruptive practice of refuge hopping. Service gaps in crisis accommodation have also been identified in rural locations, including regional centres, mining and company towns, and services catering to the needs of older women escaping domestic violence.

If we look at youth, there are literally thousands of young people who no longer live in their original home. There are many reasons for that—family violence, severe economic hardship, lack of parental support, drug and alcohol addiction within families, to name a few.

But the numbers are increasing. Insecure and low incomes, an extremely depressed youth labour market, and lack of affordable and appropriate youth housing are problems which confront youth today in their search for independence. The supported accommodation assistance program or SAAP has been a positive program since its development. The supported accommodation assistance program is a jointly funded Commonwealth-state program which was established in 1984 in response to the needs of homeless people or those in crisis.

SAAP has evolved over a period of nine years. Its transition from SAAP Mark 1 through to SAAP Mark III has occurred to ensure the provision of much needed support services in addition to supported accommodation. The program's performance has been evaluated at regular intervals—in 1988 and in 1993—under forms of agreement within this bill. In response to these reviews the program's focus has shifted from crisis services to facilitating the transition of service users from homelessness to independent living.

The evaluation of SAAP Mark II entitled `Moving forward' released in June 1993 stated that SAAP had been successful in achieving its aims; SAAP should retain its primary role as a safety net; SAAP should incorporate an early intervention dimension; SAAP's objective should be to assist the homeless or people in crisis to make the transition to independent living through the provision of support and accommodation; and contained a recommendation that urgent action be taken to improve the availability of and access to appropriate and affordable housing, including public housing.

I understand that both the Commonwealth and the states have generally been satisfied with the operation of SAAP Mark II. Peak organisations like the National Youth Coalition for Housing, National Shelter and the Salvation Army have been satisfied with the current mix of crisis accommodation and transitional assistance.

SAAP Mark II has accommodated, referred and advocated for large numbers of homeless people. It has assisted large numbers of people to obtain their rightful entitlements in terms of income, in court or through other systems. It has provided support and safety to many suffering domestic violence and child abuse. It has developed and maintained links within the community and government sectors. However, the main barrier and one of the most overwhelming problems with SAAP is the lack of secure, affordable and appropriate housing for SAAP clients who wish to make the transition to independent living and the lack of community support structures to complement the transitional housing support role of SAAP. The government has continued to ignore the issue of supported accommodation and affordable housing.

The amendments that Senator Lees and I will be moving later today will bring these important elements within SAAP back into focus. Many SAAP clients have a need for supported accommodation and are not ready for independent living because of the life stage they are in or their crisis. Many outreach workers have articulated the difficulties in dealing with issues in a neighbourhood when people are placed inappropriately outside a residential supported service.

SAAP Mark II has not been successful in assisting people in the transition to independent living because of inadequate exit points to assist people to move on. There is clear evidence of the pressing need to resolve the supply of affordable long-term housing which is falling far short of demand. The government has not addressed these problems in SAAP Mark III.

My colleagues in the Liberal and National parties have listened to the concerns of service provider organisations and peak housing bodies about the broader focus of this bill, which goes to the heart of the new direction of SAAP Mark III. The Senate committee last week, on which I know the Australian Democrats shared many of our concerns, also heard the evidence of key community organisations—and amendments to be considered in the committee stage later today reflect the sympathy that Senator Lees and the Democrats and my colleagues in the Liberal and National parties are prepared to give this legislation.

Clauses 5(2) and 5(3) aim to assist homeless people to achieve the maximum possible degree of self-reliance and independence. However, these clauses need to be amended to fine tune the legislation. This aim is to be achieved by service providers providing or arranging for the provision of services to resolve crisis; re-establish family links where appropriate; and re-establish clients' capacity to participate in community life and access related services.

In order to fulfil these aims clients must have secure and supported accommodation in the interim until he or she is ready for transition towards long-term housing. Clause 7A sets out a new range of responsibilities for service providers, including case management, assessment and referral, and early intervention. Clause 7B states the types of assistance to which SAAP service providers should increase access for clients under SAAP including employment, education and training; health services, including mental health services; disability and rehabilitation services; children's support services; and income support. In short, what we have here is the government's expected framework on case management under SAAP Mark III.

It is unclear in this bill as to what case management will comprise and departmental officers were unclear on this issue at last week's detailed committee consideration. Many service providers have been case managing since the inception of the program. I would like to make a few points here.

The government's Working Nation document envisages that over 500,000 unemployed people will be individually case managed. DEET is already experiencing significant problems in getting the case management system for long-term unemployed people up and running because of inadequate staffing resources. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs has also raised concerns about case management in the restructuring of SAAP. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Unless well co-ordinated the potential exists for an overlapping and duplication of services.

That report raises the issue of whether SAAP services are an appropriate auspice for this interventionist approach. It calls for close consultation with other Commonwealth and state departments which are providing similar case management to the same target group.

PARA.TAB: This leads us to clause 10 of the bill which specifies that `SAAP will not replace or duplicate a service that is already provided by, or is the responsibility of, any other government, program or organisation' qualified, of course, by `other than with the consent of the federal minister and the state minister or ministers concerned.' We need to ask how often this consent will be sought if case management under SAAP Mark III comes into competition with other services and programs directed at the targeted group. In a letter to me Mr John Clegg, Chairperson of the National Youth Coalition for Housing, says:

SPEECH.PARA: SAAP has never been about specialist intervention in homeless peoples' lives, and nor should it be. Specialist services . . . will always be required by some homeless people. However, this does not mean that SAAP ought to deliver these services.

These . . . are largely the responsibility of (other) state government and . . . Commonwealth program areas, and SAAP should not attempt to provide services in this area, simply because the supply of related services is inadequate.
The ACT Council on Social Service asserts in its response to the SAAP draft national consumer outcome standards concerning resolving crisis:

. . . the effective provision of a service which aims at resolving crises must also address the causes of the crises, and this, of necessity, demands considerable resources over and above what is already provided for treating the symptoms.

PARA.TAB: Any move towards a pro-active program must not be undertaken at the expense of the current level of service provision, even though that service might only be equipped to act in a reactive manner.

SPEECH.PARA: This broadened focus increases the responsibilities of SAAP service providers and widens the target area to include prevention work without providing additional resources to do this work effectively.

PARA.TAB: However, the way this bill is framed it increases the problem of measuring SAAP's success against external factors which will now include high unemployment, poverty and the lack of other support services as well as the lack of affordable accommodation. Measured outcomes are a necessary and important element of measuring SAAP's success and we would hope that outcomes and/or targets in relation to people who are homeless will be clarified under the form of agreement within the bill. A letter from Mr Nathan Stirling of the Open Family (Aust.) Inc. states:

SPEECH.PARA: Currently there is little attempt, or even acknowledgment by service providers, that outcomes should be measured. Yet it is fundamental. What other business in this country doesn't have measures of its service to clients?

SAAP already assists clients through their immediate crisis by helping them to access a range of services that they might require in meeting their needs. The reality is that some clients simply cannot achieve self-reliance or become part of the work force or participate in community life. Homeless—how does one define it? There are many interpretations and definitions of the word. The definition of `homelessness' within this bill is another weakening factor. I would have thought a person is deemed to be homeless if he or she does not have affordable, safe and secure accommodation or housing rather than having inadequate access to shelter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like first to comment on Senator Baume's remarks relating to the tabling yet again of an enormous number of reports in the Senate. We have only half an hour to deal with them, which means there is an opportunity for only six senators to speak at this time, yet there are 43 reports to be considered. How can we scrutinise the other 37 that are missed? It gets worse than that. Eleven of these reports are in the area of arts and communications. It is an area of particular interest to me.

PARA.TAB: Like Senator Baume, I would have liked to comment on a number of these reports—in particular, the report by the Australian Broadcasting Authority on R classified programs on pay TV, which has been the subject of inquiry by the Senate community standards committee. What has happened is that the ABA has put out a highly flawed report in terms of its research design and, therefore, in terms of its conclusions. When it started this research I was optimistic that one could measure these things. Having been a university researcher myself, in the end I concluded that what it was trying to measure, one could not really measure, anyway, because it was dealing with the area of attitudes, without giving the people who were to formulate an attitude sufficient data on which to base their opinion. I refer particularly to the qualitative research in which they actually showed people R-rated film clips. What they did not show was the full range of R. If we allow R-rated material to be shown on pay TV, it would mean that the full range of R-rated material could be shown. Yet in this research design it just showed middle-range R material.

In the quantitative research it did not even do that, of course, because it had a much bigger sample. So what it relied on was a definition of R. Again, this definition was highly flawed. How can people make a decision on whether they want R-rated material on pay TV if they are working from a flawed definition and if, in particular, one-third of the people who are asked the question had never seen an R-rated television program? So how can these people make a sensible decision on this matter?

The report is dishonest in some of its statements. It states areas of disagreement between the Senate community standards committee and the ABA. It mentions a number of areas of disagreement but just happens to miss out the main area of disagreement, which is the wording of the questions. What the research has done is to phrase questions in such a way that it will get the answer it wants. On Yes, Prime Minister there was a delightful story in which Sir Humphrey said, `Well, Prime Minister, if you build the railway tracks in a certain direction, that's the way the train will go.' That is what it has done with some of these questions. It has put propositions that hardly anyone could disagree with. A number of the questions are worded in this way. Question 9e reads:

SPEECH.PARA: R Rated movies provide entertainment which is of interest to many adults and should be available to them on pay TV in the home.

The options for answering are to strongly agree through to strongly disagree. I do not disagree with a statement like that, nor would many people. But on the basis of that loosely worded question which is totally out of context it has delivered a report such as this and has made such a recommendation. When the committee said, `This research design is flawed,' it said, `Professor Durkin over in Western Australia has checked all this and it's all right.' We called Professor Durkin before the committee and he could not recall much about this.

PARA.TAB: In its dealings with us it was most unreasonable. It did not take our advice. It gave us impossible deadlines and now it has presented this highly flawed report. I suggest that the Senate should not take very much notice of it. As someone who used to supervise research, I say that this sort of research design would not be acceptable for a pass grade in a master's degree at a third-rate university. The Senate should reject it.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must admit that I do not agree with the previous speaker that the document entitled R-Classified programs on pay TV is not a useful document. Obviously, I have not had the chance to read it, but I think it contains some very useful material. Its final conclusions and what impact the document may have on the committee that Senator Tierney and I are working on to provide advice to the Senate before a decision is made about whether and under what circumstances R-rated material should be shown on pay TV are yet to be considered. But I think some useful material is contained in this document, although I accept Senator Tierney's legitimate criticisms in other areas.

PARA.TAB: What I suppose I reject is the news release that accompanied this particular document which has a banner headline that may be shown across Australia tomorrow. It says `Australians say yes to R-rated programs on pay TV'. That is not what the research says. It is what the press release says, but it is not what the research says. In this respect I guess I am coming round to having some sympathy for certain aspects of what Senator Tierney said. In actual fact, what the research says is that people are uncomfortable about the unrestricted availability of R-rated material. People want controls and limitations to be put in place should R-rated material be approved for broadcast on pay TV and are keen to have information about the content of programs. That picks up on Senator Tierney's point about the range of film in the R-rated category that was shown for research purposes.

The ABA's research also found that there is more concern about the availability of R-rated sexual violence than there is about R-rated sexual content or R-rated violence. I think that indicates to members of this chamber that we will need to consider a range of issues when our report is finally brought in for debate and this whole question is being considered by this chamber. Clearly, the research does not give the green light to unrestricted R-rating, yet people would assume from a casual glance at the press release that the research has been done, it is all A-okay and R-rating on pay TV should go ahead unrestricted. That is certainly not the message of the very limited amount of material that I have looked at to date.

I draw the attention of the Senate to something which I think is extremely important. I refer to a table on page 102 which is headed `Attitudes to R-rated sexual violence on pay TV by gender'. I remind all members in this place and indeed in the other place that gender is a very important influence in Australia in 1994. Women vote on these issues, and women have very definite attitudes about certain matters. When it comes to R-rated sexual violence being shown on pay TV, 52 per cent of women said that R-rated sexual violence should not be permitted on pay TV under any circumstances. That is not a feature that has been picked up in the press release.

While I do not want to be totally negative about this document—I think it contains some useful material, some of which I have just referred to—and I am not going to dismiss the findings, I think that this report needs very careful consideration and analysis. Complementing that will be the work of our committee. We hope to bring our report into the Senate early next year, prior to any decision being made about R-rating on pay TV.

SPEECH.PARA: This document relates to the 48th session of the United Nations General Assembly held in New York from 21 September to 23 December 1993, at which the Hon. David Simmons and I were the parliamentary delegates. I must say that I commend the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) for his success at that assembly. I also thank him for his remarks in this report:

I greatly appreciated the participation of the Hon David Simmons and Senator Michael Baume in the Australian delegation. Their interest and input into the work of the delegation contributed very positively to the results achieved.

I must say that shows a level of perspicacity by the foreign minister for which I commend him. I would, however, like to make a few points about the problems that we parliamentary advisers had in relation to the United Nations General Assembly. I quote our report, which is contained in this report of the Australian delegation:

The potential for Parliamentary Advisers to make meaningful contributions to Australia's participation in the United Nations General Assembly has been considerably enhanced by the changing role of the UN since the end of the Cold War. The proliferation of regional problems (armed conflicts, both between and within member states, economic crises, natural disasters, human rights abuses and the denial of democratic processes), which may have been dealt with during the Cold War through ideological competition or dampened by the threat of worldwide escalation as superpowers protected their "clients", has required a greater level of broad political input into UN problem resolution. The Australian electorate is increasingly involved in or concerned about those problems that are now imposing such huge demands on the UN that its capacity to deal adequately with them is at risk.

In domestic political terms, the Australian public has a natural interest in the widespread deployment of our defence force personnel in UN missions in foreign countries with many of which Australia has little evident relationship; the Australian migrant community is concerned about conflicts affecting their original homelands; Australian taxpayers question the rapidly expanding costs as against the benefits of support for the UN's activities; many Australians disagree about the merits of Australian support for UN intervention in overseas disputes or the impact of its conventions on Australia's internal affairs.

The role of Parliamentary Advisers in this crisis time for the UN, when it has unlimited demands being made upon it but severely limited resources, is two-pronged: firstly, to contribute on the spot to the debate about Australia's proper role in all these matters and secondly, to seek (where appropriate) to enhance the understanding and support within their own political parties and through the parliamentary process, not only for Australia's actions within this world forum, but support for the UN itself.

The Australian electorate's preparedness to continue to fund the United Nations depends on its acceptance of the bipartisan political message that without an effective UN, Australia's peace and prosperity could be at greater risk. At the same time, Australia's mission at the UN benefits from having access to professional political views as to the likely political consequences of the positions it takes in the UNGA negotiations, particularly those that may generate political concerns and put bipartisanship at risk.

So the proper role of a parliamentary adviser is essentially that of a two-way information and advisory street, allied to a key role of active participation in UNGA committees to share the workload with mission staff and, in doing so, gain a greater understanding of the practical difficulties involved in attempting to get the Australian point of view understood, accepted and converted into positive action at the United Nations.

While coming away from New York with a heightened understanding of, and respect for, the institutions of the UN, we nevertheless have some serious concerns about aspects of its activities. The loss of key, and in our view very impressive personnel under the Director-Generalship of Mr Boutros Boutros-Ghali has not enhanced the status or competence of the organisation (the high level briefings given to parliamentarians by top UN officials had indicated to us the high calibre of those executives who subsequently left the organisation); the clear conflict between the US, the major source of finance for the UN, and the Secretary-General (along with justifiable dissatisfaction about inadequate budgetary controls); growing disenchantment with Mr Boutros-Ghali by many delegations; and the continuing power struggle between the General Assembly and the Security Council, had added to the difficulties the UN faces in seeking to demonstrate its capacity to handle the world's problems.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to speak briefly because, due to time constraints, unfortunately I could not speak on the rural adjustment scheme report that was handed down by my colleague Senator Brownhill yesterday. PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note the total expenditure of RAS during the last year was $172 million, of which the Commonwealth government contributed $150 million and the states $21 million. There were something like 16,600 applications of all elements of RAS and approvals totalled 11,882. These numbers and the amount of money and the fact that we have a rural debt of something like $17 billion, point to the fact that we all know of, and that we have been talking about in this place for quite some considerable time, and that is the dire straits out there in the rural areas. It is not just the drought areas. As we toured around Australia looking at how the RAS scheme was operating we saw that it was not just the drought areas that were suffering; it was just about everywhere for all sorts of different reasons, but mainly the rural recession, the recession we had to have, and also dry times.

I notice the government has announced three new policy directions for RAS 1992, and I have noted them here: the need for greater focus on assisting farmers to improve their technical, financial and risk management skill; the need for a better linking of RAS to other Commonwealth and state-territory farm improvement programs, including agribusiness and landcare programs; and the need for rental assistance to be better tailored to address the regional adjustment needs. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: (1)That, pursuant to paragraph 8(1)(d) of the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951, the following matters be referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for inquiry and report, on or before 30 March 1995:

SPEECH.PARA: Whether the proposed sale of the Australian National Line (ANL) has been conducted with the prudence, discretion, integrity, skill and propriety necessary:

TAB.TAB: (a)to protect the value of ANL and its assets;
(b)to realise the maximum price for ANL and its assets; and
(c)to avoid prejudice to the interests of the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: (2)That in considering these terms of reference the committee is to examine and report on the following issues and questions:

TAB.TAB: (a)whether public officials (elected or unelected) associated with the proposed disposal of ANL have acted with prudence, discretion, integrity and propriety;

(b)whether the actions of the Department of Transport, the Department of Finance (Asset Sales Task Force) and the boards of ANL, as individual organisations and collectively, have been effective in serving the taxpayers' best interests;

(c)what was the status of the Price Waterhouse-Salomon Brothers report in the sale process, and was there any reason for preferring the Price Waterhouse-Salomon Brothers valuation to other valuations;

(d)whether the Minister behaved with prudence, discretion, integrity and propriety by publishing the Price Waterhouse-Salomon Brothers report and by making the comments he did when publishing the report;

(e)whether the disposal of Australian Stevedores to Jamison Equity, against the advice of both the old and new ANL boards, was justified, whether the sale price was maximised, and whether the financing arrangements were acceptable on legal and commercial grounds;

(f)the circumstances leading up to the agreement with the Maritime Union of Australia, the nature of the agreement including financial arrangements, and whether the agreement was in the best interests of the Commonwealth;
(g)whether the Government should proceed with its agreement with the Maritime Union of Australia or whether it should seek to review the agreement in the public interest and, if so, in what terms;

(h)the circumstances surrounding the resignation of the old board, and whether there has been damage to its members' professional reputations and their potential earnings capacity for which they should be compensated; and
(i)any other issues or questions, reasonably relevant to the terms of reference but not referred to above, which have arisen in the course of the inquiry.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few brief remarks during this adjournment debate to address the excellent work of the Senate Economics References Committee in its work on the CSIRO report, which it entitled The case for revitalisation: administration and funding of rural research. The chairman, Senator Ferguson, and his South Australian colleague Senator Chapman I believe deserve considerable congratulations for the report that was brought down.

PARA.TAB: The report highlights a number of areas where reform could take place within the CSIRO—matters which I note in June of this year were completely and utterly rejected by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook). I had the opportunity earlier today to reflect on some comments I made on 6 June 1994 concerning this very matter of CSIRO funding and its future. It was interesting for me to note in the debate in which the minister interjected with such comments as, `Cloak yourself with ignorance, then,' and things of that nature that I raised a number of issues—which I happened to have found in the recommendations at the very front of the report—which have been addressed and were seen as issues worthy of addressing.

I raised issues such as whether the abolition of the institute structure, as institutes ought be considered because of the fact that they did not add any value to CSIRO. I also posed questions as to why, when private sector management is flat with minimal middle management, does the CSIRO have so many levels of management? I note that in chapter 1, recommendation 1, there is a recommendation to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . restructure the CSIRO to reduce the layers of management, including the need to modify or eliminate the Institute structure;
So I am very pleased that the committee made those findings.

PARA.TAB: I further questioned whether it was the best use of working scientists to require them to spend so much time in administration as opposed to research related activities. It is pleasing to note that, as part of recommendation 1, there is the talk of streamlining administration and reducing excessive accountability.

I also raised the question of countercyclical funding to ensure a sustainable long-term research base for those industries that are providing funds on the levy basis. I happen to note that recommendation 10, in fact, is headed `Countercyclical Funding', and that seems to have been taken on board.

I also raised questions about why the CSIRO placed agricultural research high in its priority setting, but appears to disregard these criteria when allocating appropriation funding. I note that recommendation 3 of the report suggests that CSIRO reinstate the high priority ranking of rural research and ensure that the share of appropriation funding of rural research is increased commensurate with that ranking. Before I move on, there was also the question of the sale of a number of their research stations. I am very pleased to see that under chapter 3, where it deals with restructuring programs, the committee came out in favour of retaining a number of the research stations.

Overall, I believe this report is a most satisfactory outcome for the CSIRO and the rural industries in Australia that have come to rely upon the CSIRO for a lot of research. The CSIRO clearly did have a lack of morale. I believe it still has that problem. During the past months, I have had the opportunity of discussing privately with a number of CSIRO researchers the problems as they perceived them within the organisation.

This report of Senator Ferguson, Senator Chapman and other senators has really addressed those issues very well. I believe they can feel confident that if these recommendations are picked up by the CSIRO board and by the government, CSIRO and, in particular, the agricultural research area will be restored to the glory that they deserve and they that they enjoyed in the past.

I simply conclude my remarks by congratulating the committee on its wide ranging report and for addressing some of those issues that were made known to me some six months ago. I trust that the people who provided me with the information I raised in the Senate some six months ago are satisfied that those matters have now been addressed in this report, which was brought down this afternoon by the chairman of that committee, Senator Ferguson.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, it is said that evil prospers when good men do nothing. I take this opportunity to raise a matter of apparent evil which does need examination. That arises out of a letter which was sent to me by the council of Cherbourg elders, dated 27 November 1994, which details apparent misappropriation of money at the Cherbourg community—money which has been supplied by ATSIC. I seek leave to table that letter.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I have taken the step of raising this matter and tabling the document because this is a very serious matter. It is not a matter of bashing Aboriginal communities; it is a matter of trusting Aboriginal elders who are going to raise matters in the public interest.

PARA.TAB: The allegations which they have made in this letter, which honourable senators will be able to read in detail when they get a copy, clearly show that there are matters that require investigation—particularly the use of money which has been provided by ATSIC to take groups of Aboriginal children as dancers away on trips. The end to which that money seems to have been applied certainly requires investigation—as do some of the other matters that have been raised in relation to money supplied by ATSIC to pay Mr Burt Button to attend ATSIC meetings and functions and how that was money was accounted for. Those matters are of serious concern, as are the concerns raised on the third page of the document in relation to the Aboriginal Legal Service.

As honourable senators will note from this document, one of the names that appears in it is the notorious Mr Sugar Ray Robinson, who seems to leave a trail of disaster wherever he goes in western Queensland and about whom many concerns have been raised in other places. This is just one of a number of them. I do not wish to prejudge Mr Burt Button but I believe that the matter must be investigated.

I hope that over the period in which the parliament rises the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) will take the appropriate steps to ensure that this matter is fully and adequately investigated and that all the funds referred to are properly acquitted. I say that because in the past I have had very good relations with Minister Tickner. He understands that I am concerned to ensure that money that is appropriated for the benefit of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples is given to the people who need it and not skimmed along the way.I take this opportunity to thank Minister Tickner for the assistance that he has given in these matters in the past. I assume that he will provide the same assistance in the future. I will leave the matter in the hands of the department. But I will take an active interest in the matter when the parliament resumes.
